description:
I had a great lunch here with my friend who is Taiwanese. I don't eat Taiwanese food that often so it was good to go with someone who can order for the both of us!

We were hungry so we ordered lots of snacks to eat:

Cold salted soy bean milk - this went well with the dishes - sometimes when things come out piping hot, you need something to cool it down. 

Popcorn chicken - a delightful snack food of perfectly fried pieces of chicken that was crunchy on the outside and yummy on the inside. 

Marinated cucumber - crunchy cucumber, pickled with chili sauce to add a kick. 

Braised Beef With Noodle Soup  - tender braised beef with spicy noodles, this is one of my favorite dishes. This is comfort food to me. 

Stinky tofu - I used to be afraid of stinky tofu but I've grown to love it. And I love the stinky tofu at Taste of Formosa. Perfectly fried - crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. 

Steamed sticky rice with pork - steamed in banana leaf with bits of pork. Lots of flavor and sticky rice is perfect texture - not too gummy.

Everything was really good and I loved all the dishes my friend picked. The restaurant is a little small so it can get busy fast.
author: Nette T.

description:
We have dined here four times & every time has been fantastic! Truly a taste of Taiwan! 
If you go, I would recommend dining with a small group so that way you can try more dishes!
author: Ashley G.

description:
3 stars only because my "main course" was ok, though the appetizers were quite good!  Came here on advice of my date's friend, since he liked the "authenticity" of this spot.

Venue / Service: small and dimly lit, but not too crowded.  We sat on the first floor but there seems to be more spacious second floor, based on the large groups of families that were coming down after their meal.  The servers don't speak the best English but are able to understand it.  They were also quick in the kitchen since food came out quite quickly but perhaps it was because we came at an unusual time (late lunch on Sunday).  

Food: we ended up preferring our small dishes vs. their specialty, the noodles.  
-- Preserved Egg and Tofu ($6.95) - for those who are unaware, preserved egg is an acquired taste to some, though luckily my date and I are HUGE fans of the funky smelling and tasting egg.  Tofu was firm enough to pick up without completely falling apart.  The sweet sauce should help counteract the strong flavors of the egg, but again, the egg is an acquired taste and may not be great for some peeps.  

-- Salt & Pepper Chicken Tender ($7.50) - almost reminds me of popcorn chicken with some added spices to it, and this was one dish that we quickly finished.  The chicken was surprisingly still moist after being fried and they are served in great bite-sizes for easy eating.  Would highly recommend!

-- Squid with Vegetable Soup (with Noodles)($7.95) - since this place is famous for its noodle dishes, I ordered this one.  Unfortunately a miss for me- the noodles were overcooked to the point that they would break apart when I tried to pick it up.  Didn't help that they were in a somewhat goupy soup (guess I was looking for something less... viscous?).  Lots of vegetables but I had a hard time telling what was a veggie and what was a slice of squid- not that it matters but I couldn't tell how much squid there actually was in the dish.

All in all, perhaps I'd choose a different noodle dish, but the appetizers we got were good!
author: Audrey H.

description:
The first thing you'll notice when you step into this restaurant is the pungent smell of stinky tofu. It might be a little overwhelming as you step into the restaurant. For those who love it, you will be thrilled. To those who hate it, be warned that the smell of stinky tofu is strong.

I happen to fall in the former camp. In fact, I had ventured all the way to this cafe to try out their Taiwanese street snacks. My bf and I got the oyster pancake, curry chicken and rice, intestines noodle soup, and of course the infamous stinky tofu. The soup was our favorite. The stinky tofu is not as good as I had remembered it to be. It used to be one of my favorite snacks growing up.

The portions of all the dishes were a little small, but the taste was on point and very hearty and delicious!

All the dishes were around $6-$10, so it's pretty cheap. It's definitely not anything fancy, but a great place to get your Taiwanese snack fix. There are quite a couple dishes I don't find normally elsewhere such as the Taiwanese meat dumpling. I'll definitely will be back to try that.

We also tried their watermelon smoothies. I was super excited to get these as I hadn't had drinks like this since i was last out of the country. It was really delicious!
author: Sherica L.

description:
Was overall a bit underwhelmed by this place.  

Pork Chop Rice - good flavor, but skimpy on the meat as most of the chop was just bone

Braised Ground Pork Over Rice - too heavy on pig skin for me and flavoring was only ok, also a little stingy with the pickles

Chili Wontons - average in taste, I've had better in multiple eateries

Service was decent.  Not a bad place, just not my first choice for Taiwanese food.
author: Sheila C.

description: Their rice rolls (fan tuan) are delectable and made-to-order (as far as I know..). The you tiao is so crunchy and warm and reminded me of visits to Taiwan.
author: Donna L.

description:
Our friends took us here saying it was the best Taiwanese food in SF. We are all from Cupertino, so we know what good Taiwanese food is like. This place was pretty good, the menu was large and extensive and had all the classic dishes we wanted and more. It has offerings in both English and Chinese with some pictures to help those that eat with their eyes! 

This restaurant is in the suburbs of SF, takes a little bit of time to get there. Parking is alright though, just find some street parking and parallel park, it's just a short stroll over. The restaurant has two floors of seating, the downstairs area looks smaller but go upstairs and it's larger and nicer. 

The food was delicious and satisfied our craving for Taiwanese food. I'd recommend this restaurant for those living in SF and crave some good home cooked Taiwanese food. 

Some classic dishes we ordered: 
- Taiwanese sausage with garlic
- beef noodle soup! (A must) 
- rice with shredded pork 
- hot and sour soup
author: Sonya K.

description:
Taste of Formosa gets a solid 4 stars in my book, but I need to add 1 extra star to offset some of the low star reviews from people that simply don't like the smell of stinky tofu.

The food here is authentic, cheap, and tasty. I've been here twice now and each time have left incredibly satisfied. During lunch today, I ordered the thousand year old egg with tofu - a dish I love making at home, and I was very happy with their rendition of it. The pork floss and scallions in the dish really enhanced an otherwise mundane dish. 

In addition to the tofu, I also ordered fried pork chop with tea egg over rice. While the tea egg wasn't as fragrant as others that I've had, the pork chop was fried perfectly and seasoned just right. I would definitely come to here again if I'm craving Taiwanese food.
author: Austin W.

description:
Authentic and delicious Taiwanese food! With the exception to the stinky tofu, pigs ear & intestine, I could not muster the courage to eat these let alone smell that stinky tofu.  But my friends loved it.  Prices are very reasonable.

I enjoyed all the other dishes, such as the pork belly over rice, salt & pepper fish, really loved the beef noodle soup, popcorn chicken, & oyster omelette.

It's a small family business and I love supporting small local business.  If you're looking to expand your palette, definitely give Taiwanese food a try.  You won't be disappointed!
author: Melanie N.

description: Just pick up my lunch and found a hair in my bowl!!!!!!!!! Ewe !!!! I lose my appetite and don't wanna go back anymore!!!!!
author: 珊珊

description:
Disclaimer: I've only had the food as takeout (thank you, Postmates) and yes, it's still a solid 4 stars. My boyfriend and I were craving Taiwanese food and I was searching through Yelp and landed on trying this place based on pretty much one thing: pig ears. 

While there are some eh items on the menu (the chili wontons and hot and sour soup really aren't that great), I will 100% vouch for the following: pig ears, cucumbers, bamboo shoots, salt and pepper fried chicken. All 4 are SUPER delicious - really really flavorful and the best part? You can customize spice levels for some...which is cool. Not everyone wants super spicy or mild. 

It's been tough to find a good Taiwanese place that has those side dishes (esp those darn bamboo shoots and pig ears!) but so glad I found this place! It's not as cheap as you would want, but what place in SF is?
author: Steph S.

description: Pretty good spot for Taiwanese food! I love the beef noodle soup most of all, but their sautéed dishes are good as well. Small family-run place, but I haven't had to wait long or at all for a table.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Very mediocre Taiwanese food. I grew up in the 626 San Gabriel Valley in LA and had experienced many outstanding and authentic Chinese food there, especially Taiwanese cuisine. This place pales in comparison. I wouldn't call this place unauthentic because what they offer is authentic Taiwanese food. But the quality simply cannot compare to what I've had down south. I ordered their beef noodle soup and lou rou fan (minced pork over rice) and I was still hungry at the end. Portions of both dishes were small and the quality of the noodles is just average. They don't give enough beef, which is mostly fat.

I would not waste my money on this place again.
author: Brian C.

description:
If you like bland food, terrible smells, and very little concern for customers, this place is your spot. We went here for dinner tonight. We ordered the chicken wings, spicy wanton, sticky rice, and vermicelli soup. 

The food across the board was all bland. The vermicelli that we ordered had such a terrible smell that we took one bite and could not continue eating it. It smelled like something was rotten. 

The owner/decision maker apparently comes from the kitchen. When we had an issue and tried to ask if we could switch for something else on the menu, we were told it's already been cooked, so no. 

This will definitely be the last time tee eat here. We should have taken the empty restaurant at peek dinner hours as a sign. This meal was one of the worst meals that I've had in a long time. When you can't eat your soup because it smells so bad, and something as simple as chicken wings comes out bland, you're doing something wrong.
author: Vu N.

description: My husband and I are from Taiwan. We have been living in the US for a while and miss Taiwanese street food so much. We were very excited to try this restaurant when we found it. The food is delicious. Salted sticky rice roll, oyster and pork intestine vermicelli noodle soup, and fried squid balls are all yummy and close to what we had in Taiwan. However, I give it 2 stars because of a health issue. We found a white, fluffy mold on the cold marinated seaweed when we already finished 1/3 of it... Also, the restaurant is not clean. The wall is greasy and dirty. I really want to like this restaurant because the food is good, but I think we will not go back again because of the health issue.
author: Tiffany C.

description: If I could give this a zero, I would. Our noodles came, with a side of hair. When we complained about the noodles, our waiter practically took our noodles (with a side of dirty looks), LEAVING THE HAIR THERE and gave us another dish with less noodles than before. The food itself was fine, nothing out of the ordinary except our side of curly hair in our noodles. I don't think I would go back to a restaurant where the waiter makes you feel nervous about asking anything.
author: Nikolas T.

description:
Her friends are abroad all around the globe,
She is here with me and the San Francisco rain.
Half past six on a Sunday night,
The media feed lighted with pictures of places she wished to go.

A date night, I urged, 
a humble consolation prize
It's not the Eiffel, the Ben, or towers under the Shanghai sky. 
I have not the means to feast your eyes to the wonders of the world,
but a A Taste of Formosa is the best I can do.

I took her by the hand and dove under the sea,
for a plate of Jellyfish as refreshing as June. 
It smelled of a field of sesame under the tropical sun,
She smiled as she savored on the crunch of the texture.

Next we flew out of the present and back to my past,
holding two sides of a Sticky Rice with my five year old hands.
The small side for you and the big side for me,
she accepted my childhood favorite with a kiss on the cheek.

We landed in a different culture with the Water Cooked Fish,
the spicy region of the Chinese cuisine. 
Our minds wandered to the red chili farms,
tongue slowly numbing after each little nibble. 

This is not the glamour of a Trans-Atlantic flight,
just a little trinket in lieu of a well-deserved gift.
Princess Carewee held my hand in the rain,
and gladly traded a kiss for the Taste of Formosa.
author: Ringo M.

description:
Hey, it ain't bad... there is a lot of good Chinese food in San Francisco.  If you cannot find a good Chinese in the City, you are not looking hard.

I would say that the food is "good but not great."  It was tasty but I would not say it was outstanding.

With other Chinese restaurants, I would say things like "fresh" or "authentic."  I cannot say that this place is not "fresh" or "authentic" but I just think that there are other places where you can do better.
author: Gary A.

description:
Taste of Formosa is consistently delicious. I have ordered delivery multiple times and dined in as well. My favorite dish is the beef noodle soup. Even when delivered, the noodles are cooked to perfection and the broth and beef taste like they've been simmering for hours in savory, umami goodness. 

Can't wait to try other dishes! Taste of Formosa has become a staple in my Outer Richmond diet.
author: Staci T.

description: Wow! This gem of a place is a block from home. Our tummies were hankering for Chinese/Taiwanese takeout, and Taste of Formosa did not disappoint! We ordered potstickers (great dipping sauce!), marinated cucumber, sweet and sour pork, lemon chicken, garlic eggplant (perfectly spicy), and of course steamed rice. Each dish was fresh, tasty, and not overly salty. I didn't know this was possible, but even the rice was better than most places. Really impressed! We'll definitely be eating their food again.
author: Christina S.

description:
Wavering between four or three stars...

We weren't too hungry on Sunday night and ordered:
- braised ground pork rice bowl with egg
- pork belly rice bowl with egg
- popcorn chicken (salt & pepper)
Total after tax $21

Considering the portion size, this was an expensive dinner. Flavors were so-so, nothing really stood out but nothing was bad either. It wasn't memorable except for the service...

Either they're very short-staffed or they're not professional at all. 
1) tables were dirty and took time to clean for the waiting patrons
2) server only spoke accented Mandarin and corrected us when we pronounced correctly what was on the menu
3) server lost our order and waited to tell us to reorder
4) lights flickered constantly
5) lights were accidentally turned off and took a while to turned back on...
author: Lucy Z.

description:
I miss Taiwan therefore I was so happy that they have a taiwan restaurant in the city. It's nothing like taiwan but I still like coming here. This place is pretty pricey, especially for their portion size, isn't big. Can't come here everyday. Not everything is good, work close by so I have tired many things on the menu. I love sticky rice roll but their rice is moist/wet and doesn't stick together. 

My favorite dish is the braised pork over rice, make sure you add an egg. Also I like their cold braised tofu. Since other things on the menu isn't great, I just get the same thing every time.
author: Sandy B.

description: A very solid Taiwanese dining food experience. Just finished up a quick dinner here where I ordered a Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup. The beef was a little too fatty for my tastes but the broth and the noodles especially were excellent. It's hard to find a restaurant in the city that does Taiwanese food well but I think this place fits the bill quite nicely. Overall I'd give it 3.5 stars--food was solid and the service was very quick.
author: Max S.

description:
Two words. Tea egg. 

Also had the Taiwanese fried chicken over rice. It was amazing!  Thank you
author: Jason G.

description: I've never left any reviews but this is unacceptable. This used to be my favorite spot, but I stopped going ever since i ordered rice and it came infested with dead bugs. I had mixed it with my won ton soup, so who knows how many bugs I ate before I noticed.. i saw little black things floating around and figured they were spices.. i looked closer and noticed little legs. I called and wasn't even given a refund. Needless to say I'll never go back again. LOOK AT YOUR FOOD BEFORE YOU EAT IT
author: Maribel S.

description: This is not Taiwanese food. Shouldn't call it taste of Formosa. It doesn't taste like Formosa at all.... and it's not tasty at all. :( disappointed.
author: Ariel L.

description:
I've always thought I was fairly well-versed in Taiwanese food because I knew more than the common knowledge of  beef noodle soup and boba--I was acquainted with 3 cup chicken, beef wraps, pickled veggies, and tea eggs. However when I came here with a Taiwanese friend, I realized that was the tip of the iceberg (or tip of the island, since TW has no icebergs...?)

TL;DR: Flavor and texture explosion!

Situated in the Richmond i.e. culinary Chinatown, Taste of Formosa is a 2-story restaurant with a family-owned vibe. The decor is nice: traditional and zen-like, in fact so traditional that you are greeted by a waft of burning incense when you walk in.

The menu is one of those wonderful yet overwhelming colorful glossy booklets you find at many Chinese cafes--wonderful because there are plenty of pictures, but overwhelming because there are endless pages and everything looks good. 

(++) Oyster noodle soup: The thin rice noodles are tasty in the flavorful broth and cilantro topping. It was quite strong in vinegar, so if you are not a fan of acetic acid I may suggest that you try another noodle soup. Also, I was expecting the ginormous oysters you get in tofu clay pot, so I was surprised when the oysters turned out so tiny. Overall though, I really liked it because it was delicious, simple and, perfect for SF weather.

(++) Oyster crepe: FYI I've also seen this called pancake (or, as my relatives call it, Chinese pizza). It has a good proportion of Chinese vegetables, egg, oyster, and batter, drizzled with this tasty sauce that's something between honey and sweet and sour, only it's too good to be compared to the artificial sauce of Panda Express sweet and sour chicken. It looks a bit odd with the puddle of thick bright orange sauce, but it's better than American pizza.

(+) Taiwan dumpling: This seemed like an interesting variation of lotus wrapped sticky rice, except that the sticky rice was formulated into a jelly-like wrapping around the chicken and mushroom filling. I think it could have used more filling relative to the rice wrapping, but it had a nice, complex blend of savory sauces and seasonings.

It came out to a little over $20 before tip, not bad! At first we were skeptical when we heard the servers chatting in Canto, but we also heard them talking in Mandarin later... maybe they were practicing their Canto? In any case, TW food is surprisingly difficult to find in SF, and my TW friend thought this was pretty authentic and also nostalgic (which is the restaurant name in Chinese).
author: Edna C.

description: The food was good here, but the service was terrible. It took 15 minutes just for someone to take our order and another 30 minutes to get our food. We will definitely not be returning.  If you have limited time, don't bother coming here. Oddly enough, a Taiwanese couple next to us had their order taken right away, and their food came after 5 minutes. They paid their bill at the same time we did. Our dining experience was three times longer than theirs. We were the only non-Asian customers.
author: Barbara B.

description: finally some Taiwanese food that's totally on par with what I had in Taipei. I've been to a couple other places in the bay and this is easily my favorite. Sweet soy milk, chinese donut, and the spicy beef noodle were all on point. We also had the salty rice roll and the Taiwanese fried noodle which were also good. As we were leaving I was excited to see a Free Delivery sign. This just gave me another reason to stay in Inner Richmond.
author: Andrew D.

description: I always really like this place, but it is pretty far from where I live. I like the beef noodle soup, rice cakes, minced pork with rice (and an egg), the seaweed or cucumber apps, and etc. I am glad they have 2 floors as it can get really busy.The dumplings are really good too. The street parking is the only thing that would make you question this place and if you can eat here.
author: Lily P.

description:
A very simple neighborhood restaurant for Taiwanese food. The dinning place inside is quiet small yet they deliver in San Francisco area. I live very close by so most of the time I just walk there to drive over to pick up because there's NO parking ANYWHERE in clement and they charge extra for delivery.
As for the food, it's all fair price and very easy to get full. A few must try if you are here for the first time:
Braised pork over rice - traditional taiwanese dish. One of this plus another small dish and you will be full!
tofu with thousand year egg - good to have on a hot day; interesting chinese favor.
garlic pork belly - a personal favor, little spicy appetizer 
All the food has a strong taste so some veggie would be good as nice -- I'd recommend the fresh cucumber in garlic.
Staff - all girl and pretty nice yet a bit slow on the din-in service; but usually pretty fast with togo orders.
author: Yilin Y.

description:
Not bad. I've been craving a really classic Taiwanese dish -- pork chop rice -- for awhile, and was on a hunt to find somewhere in the city that I could get it at. Taste of Formosa definitely came up as one of the most popular dining options, so I dragged the SO over one Friday night. The place was pretty empty when we went, and service came out pretty quickly. I got the pork chop rice and the SO got a braised pork belly rice. 

The pork chop rice was okay... but nowhere near the best that I've ever had. I'm a really big fan of Ocha for those of you in the Valley. The pork chop at Taste of Formosa was super oily, bony, and just not delicious. The rare pieces that I was able to have were pretty good, but overall, it was fairly underwhelming and most of it was really bony. SO really liked his pork belly rice though, that did look good.

I do appreciate that they take credit card here because I find that most Asian restaurants never take credit card, so that's at least some thing good. 

tldr; okay Taiwanese food, but nothing special
author: Jasmine X.

description: Update: Food is good as usual BUT the amount is getting ridiculously smaller if you get togo. I usually get togo so I would know where the amount uses to be. For the oyster noodle soup it went from 9/10th filled to 5/10 filled. I asked them and they said the ingredients are getting more expensive, but I'm paying a higher price! Unfair right? Two star because food is good. But the boss is also very rude and self centered. Her attitude towards me when I asked why I only got 2 small oysters out of the whole noodle soup is ridiculous. Two oysters! Really?! It use to be 5-6!
author: Potatoe Q.

description:
ATTN TAIWANESE PEOPLE: Not very Taiwanese. 

Stinky tofu: stinky, but not fried enough. The side sauce was typical Chinese chilli and soy sauce. The kimchi was also subpar 

Beef noodle soup: savory, but noodles over cooked. Plus side, beef tendon was very soft and milky

Green onion pancake: Awesome, this was awesome. Fluffy, flakey, and rolled in a traditional fashion
author: Jocelyn C.

description:
I don't know too many taiwanese places in the city but I usually come here when craving for some. I normally order a ground pork over rice with pickled veggies with some dumplings and a honey green tea drink to refreshen. Theyre closed on tuesdays so dont come here tuesdays lol. Parking is always difficult around here especially for dinner. I try to come for lunch only to avoid the horrid parking in that area. Just remember to bring quarters because the meters are still the old ones where it only takes coins. 

Food wise is pretty good. I've been spoiled by taiwanese food in SoCal so I wouldnt say this is the best but it is definitely good for San Francisco given that there arent too many places around that sell this type of food. My rice dish I get is a small portion but its a good thing if you want to order a bunch of other dishes to eat along with the rice dish. But sucks if thats all you want given its such a small portion. (Think we are too spoiled with large portions in America haha). All the dumplings I've ordered here are pretty good and fresh as well. No complaints so far. They have an upstairs seating area as well but if downstairs isnt crowded and you're not in a big group, they will only seat downstairs since they are low staffed. Upstairs is mainly for at night when theres more people or for bigger groups just fyi.
author: Linda L.

description: I think it's a good place to have Taiwanese food, but still not really similar to the Taiwan.
author: Yi-chen S.

description:
I'm only interested in 3 kinds of food: sicknasty, grossout, and barfpuke.
Lucky me, because this place has all 3.
** NO chicken feet. It has vanished from the menu. **
But pretty much everything that IS available tops out the nattometer.

We're talking pig ears, stuffed chitlins, watermelon, duck tongue, tendonsintestinesoystersbloodsquidsmelltofufishheadskillbillshogunassassinlikeeveryoldjackiechanmovieevereyjukixdbzcgfoqejugckfigrxdcbhsrpwmly111111

Service was speedy like "did they make it or did they microwave #americanhustle #whydelilah it?". I don't care either way.

I didn't bother google mapping or siri-ing, but apparently Formosa is located at a crossroads of my black grandma's house, China, Korea, Philippines, and Noah's Ark. Heart it. But still bummed about no chicken feet.

Rounding up to 4 stars.
author: Dan B.

description:
Delicious, balanced flavors. Thoroughly enjoyed the perfectly fried stinky tofu w/ it's tasty yet not over salted sauce. Not super oily. The veggies were wonderfully pickled. Extra side of eggs is a must for me. Also ordered the pork chop rice but that's for the hubs so can't rate that yet.

Phone orders are quick to be fulfilled but the lady speaks very low so it's a wee but hard to understand.

Definitely better than Spices.
author: Julie L.

description:
I wanted to like this place so bad.  However everything tasted close but slightly off.  We ordered the following:
* fan tuan- not bad, probably the best thing we ordered.  Just wished it was more tightly  packed since it was falling apart to easily
* braised beef noodle soup - The noodles were not bad, and the broth was almost there.  However the broth very clearly has chinese XO sauce added in.  I've never had this in any beef noodle soup anywhere.  XO sauce has a very strong taste and distracts from the usual beef noodle soup flavor.
* Chinese doughnut- Good but somewhat small portion
* Sweet, hot soy milk- Really how can you get this wrong?  I have no idea what happened here, but for some reason it has a fermented aftertaste.  It's almost like it's spoiled or something.  
* scallion pancake with egg added - Okay but not a huge fan.

Overall this prices are a bit high for what you get.  Sadly I have yet to find a great Taiwanese restaurant in the city.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Extensive menu, but nothing really stands out. Server didn't look too happy while taking orders, and didn't make any recommendations. We ordered the House noodles, green beans and the beef tendons. Everything was on the oily side. Beans were old and overcooked. I love taiwanese food, too bad this isn't the right thing.
author: Em T.

description:
Meh. For a restaurant that specializes in Taiwanese food, it sure as hell was bad Taiwanese food. Everything is over-priced, not good, and even their soy milk tastes like stinky tofu.

If anyone knows of a place with great Taiwanese breakfasts, please let me know!
author: Kazu O.

description: The food was great but service was terrible he women name chi was the worst server ever it took her 45 min to realized I forgot my order and when she came to my table and laughed and giggled about it "sorry she forgot you order." .also I asked my water has been empty since 15 mins being here and u past my table and looked at me 6 times yet u never filled my empty glass. Also for got my Togo order. If you're looking for great tasting food and bad service this the place.
author: Christopher M.

description: Today i am so angry. I ordered pork chop over rice for my child. They added spicy on the pork chop. I called the waiter he can't do any thing. He just said I am sorry then I reordered pork chop only. When I got the bill   They charge me 2 times pork chop over rice $8.99 . I asked the waiter again how come I only ordered pork chop why charge the same price...., I won't go there anymore...I will tell my friends not go there too.
author: Vinny L.

description:
Came here on another whim. After the Breton fare, last night. 

We tried the 蚵仔煎，滷肉飯，臭豆腐，台南碗課，大腸蚵仔麵.  They were all pretty good! We had to roll out the place. 

Added an extra point for being the only Taiwanese place worthy within access of public transport. The Geary 38 bus drops you off on 25 Ave., and you're within 2 blocks from the restaurant.
author: Jeannie H.

description:
Ordered:
Pork chop rice
Stinky tofu
Fried chicken tenders
Green onion scallion

The pork chops and fried chicken tenders evoked my time spent in Taiwan, eating basically everything there was to eat in Shihlin's night market.  Weirdly enough the place didn't have the aroma of that place, but it certainly has the taste.  The pork chop and chicken tenders, especially, were fried to perfection.  The stinky tofu wasn't stinky enough for my taste, but it does the trick, especially considering how rare the, uh, delicacy is.

The service is both very good and could use improvement.  On the one hand, they refilled my cup of tea with ridiculous dedication, never letting me dip below the halfway mark.  On the other, I had to ask for a check multiple times, which could be a problem if your car is running low on the meter.

The prices are kinda all over the place.  I'm not sure why the scallion pancake was $7, since there was only one.  It was good, as it is incredibly difficult to get that wrong, but it was strange to me.  Yet at the same time, the bowls are a ludicrously good deal, and the rest of the entrees (that I saw) were very fairly priced.

All in all, would definitely go here again the next time I'm in the Richmond.
author: Norman S.

description: Tasty! Braised beef noodles had tender, flavorful beef and yummy noodle soup. Oyster pancake indeed had amazing sauce.
author: Kathryn C.

description: It's comforting to have authentic Taiwanese food in San Francisco. They have all the favorite go to snacks from back in Taiwan!
author: Maggie C.

description: I ordered to go. The sausage fried rice is off the hook. The pork belly over rice is pretty good, too. The  pieces of pork belly were so creamy and smooth. Just wish there were more of it, but worth $5.65. I can order two if I want more. The chicken hearts were disappointing; nothing special. The eggplant was average. The oyster pancake with special sauce was a bit of a let down. I kept trying to find the oysters but found this clear, gooey paste, instead. I will try them one more time because  many people rave about them.  Like many other restaurants, it's hit or miss at this place. However, I will keep ordering the fried rice and everything pork related until I find the perfect dishes for me. One thing does seriously concern me and keeps this place off my "Frequently Called List", the low Health Dept score. If only their homemade sausage fried rice and pork belly over rice weren't so good!
author: Robert L.

description:
Overall rating 3/5, but 4/5 for the beef noodle soup and scallion pancake!

Service is very decent. Most of the dishes were very home-style, not particularly unique but very tasty nonetheless. Pork and sticky rice was great, braised napa cabbage tasted just like at home, and there was a chicken dish that was decent. 

Order the beef noodle soup and the scallion pancake for sure.
author: Kathy Z.

description:
Sucks how there's nooooo Taiwanese food in SF.. barely any. But this place is pretty authentic, it has all of my childhood favorites..like TAIWANESE MEATBALL! But it's honestly not that good here. The skin of the taiwanese meatball was too.. uhh... dry? no doughy at all. That's the only bad thing about this place (besides parking.. but hey, it is Richmond so parking you are screwed).

We ordered the oyster crepe, dan dan noodles, and popcorn chicken! Everything was delicious. The dan dan noodles didn't taste as peanutty/sesame like as I would have imagined, but it wasn't bad at all. It had a smokey taste to it.. and a numbing feeling.. cuz it's kinda spicy.

Popcorn chicken was slightly better than your average quickly's but with a higher price point. It was delicious. and the oyster crepe is another one of my favorite taiwanese food too. It was on point here. 

My breath smelled so bad and garlicky, but it was so good. And they understood my taiwanese...! Hahaha so that is a plus.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I came here for the taiwanese breakfast but was disappointed. The breakfast itself isn't very good and too pricey. The noodles and rice plates might be the best things to order here. Attentive service though. 

Beef noodle soup (niu ro mian) - This was good but nothing WOW special, the noodles I don't think they are handmade and they were okay chewy, a bit on the soft side. Good soup. 

Chives pancake with egg - too hard and dry, and greasy

Oyster omelette - Big oysters which is good, I haven't had this a lot so I don't know what to compare it too. I think it was good

Salty soy milk - $5 overpriced!!! I didn't get it. Who charges $5 for salty soy milk for a taiwanese breakfast??! $3 sweet soy milk is okay. 

Salty fan tuan - too much rice, kinda hard, almost undercooked

Stinky tofu - This was good, not the stinkiest though
author: Emily M.

description:
A good ba wan in the city?? 5 stars!  It's labeled as #12 Taiwan style dumpling.  Imagine a large round dumpling the size of a small bowl with a translucent skin, like mochi but more chewy than soft.  Now stuff it with a chopped mixture of shiitake mushroom, bamboo shoots and meat.  Drizzle on some rich sauce and garnish with cilantro.

The beef noodle soup is good, especially if you like your broth with just a little spice and noodles not especially thick or thin.  It tastes more like satay sauce than most nieu ro mien broth I've had.  Meat was nice and tender and had plenty of bok choy veggies

The pickled veg and pork soup was alright, clear garlic pork broth not as pickly veg flavored as expected.

Service was great especially considering the poor girl had to run up and down the stairs and was always checking on us.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
This place is literally just A-OK. I love Taiwanese food and i was hoping to find a Taiwanese place in SF that would become my new favorite go-to Taiwanese food spot in SF..but this won't be it.

The menu is extensively long with a multitude of different taiwanese things to eat, but nothing my parents and I ordered was superb. Mediocre for every dish we tried, I can't really give it more than 3 stars for the food.

The interior of the restaurant is also a bit drabby, and even the walls look unhappy and could use a fresh coat of paint.

Also, yelp just notified me that this place has a poor food score..yikes..
author: Zoe H.

description:
I ordered take-out from here a couple of times when I was too lazy to cook.  I've tried their lemon chicken and the sesame chicken..

The lemon chicken was fried katsu style with not enough lemon sauce to cover the dryness of the chicken.  The sesame chicken lacked flavor, but it tasted a little better the next day.  I also ordered the gyoza, which was not good.  The wrapper was thick and chewy, and I didn't like the overall taste.

After reading the reviews, a lot of people say that Taste of Formosa is authentic Taiwanese food.  I'm not familiar with Taiwanese cuisine so I guess I'm not accustomed to the flavor palate.  Or I'm just really used to Cantonese food.

The menu is extensive, though, that I'm sure I'll be back to try something else.
author: Vira P.

description:
Taste of Formosa is one of the most authentic Taiwanese restaurants in the city. Please enlighten me if there are other comparable Taiwanese restaurants around. I'm always on the search! It would be a different story if we were comparing it to the places in Fremont, Milpitas, and South Bay.

What I like to order: 
- Taiwanese Style Dumpling: Yum. More meat inside please! 
- Oyster egg omelette: It's not as chewy as I'd like. 
- Clear noodles with spicy pork: This isn't exactly Taiwanese but still good! 
- Beef Noodle Soup: Noodles are good! Broth is ok. 
- Minced Pork Rice: Typical Taiwanese food, on point, the go-to.  

This will do when I'm missing Taiwanese food in the city! The food is cheap; I'm happy with it and there's nowhere else better so I'll be coming back. Parking sucks, so maybe just do pick-up and eat at home.

*Card Minimum: $20
author: Ingrid C.

description: Awesome food. Authentic. Good service. Soy milk, fried vegi with beacon, stew pork instance, pork instance with noodle, oyster with egg, slide pork with garlic, and fried fish ball were all good. I visited twice in three weeks.
author: Anya C.

description:
Taiwanese restaurants are a rare find, even in San Francisco. I always crave the street food from Taiwan, so to be able to get green onion pancakes and braised pork over rice is a wonderful thing!

We ordered the beef noodle soup, which came with a relatively thin noodle that was surprisingly chewy. The broth itself did not taste as much like traditional beef noodle soup as I would have liked. The flavor was good, but I definitely wouldn't have called it beef noodle soup. My favorite dish was the braised pork over rice, which came with a well-marinated tea egg. The meat was seasoned perfectly, and it came with a generous portion of rice. 

The more disappointing dishes were the green onion pancake and the spicy wontons. Although the wontons themselves were decent, there was too much hot chili  oil and not enough of the traditional seasoning in the sauce. The green onion pancake was twice as thick as it should be, and three times over-fried. Instead of getting a thin layer of dough and a big punch of green onion flavor, my mouth was filled with a greasy aftertaste.

I think it's hit or miss here in terms of getting traditional Taiwanese food, however it's always great to know that it's getting a foothold in the US!
author: Ashley T.

description:
Great food. Super friendly staff. Nice bathroom. Toddler-proofed eating-ware:) (paper plate, a fork, pink plastic cup with a straw). Loved all the chubby chunks of garlic cloves throughout many of my dishes. 

I enjoyed the following there:
-scallion pancake with egg - yum! And hearty
-Chinese doughnuts - crunchy through and through (more crunchy than I usually have it, but still good!)
-sweet soy milk - super sweet (satisfied my toddler's craving for chocolate milk)
-homemade sausage - enjoyed! More meaty than the mass produced version. 
-stinky tofu - ooooweee. Stinky. 
-Chinese tamale - really liked! (Bonus points for the egg yolk inside)
-stir-fried squid - yum!
-stir fried pea sprouts - good. 
-corn and chicken soup - toddler-approved

They even nicely packaged my leftovers afterward. I'd definitely go back!
author: Diana N.

description:
Came here on a Thursday night and it wasn't too busy so we got seated right away. The interior of the restaurant was very nice and neat and apparently there's an upstairs as well. The service was very good; the waitresses were very approachable and patient! The food didn't take very long to come out and was just okay for me, nothing really stood out. We did family style:

Oyster Crepe with Special Sauce - i didn't particularly like this very much because it had a weird slimy texture but the sauce was pretty good.
Green Onion Pancake - this was pretty good; very crispy and savory. This was less doughy and more crispy than the Chinese green onion pancake I'm used to
Braised Ground Pork over Rice - this was probably one of my favorites of the night; portion size is not very big if it's for one hungry person
Bacon with Taiwanese cabbage - this was a refreshing dish; I would've loved if they used crispy bacon instead of regular bacon that was still chewy and you can still see all the fat
Pork with Vegetable Soup (added noodles for 50 cents) - this was a good dish; the dish had chunks of pork, shitake mushrooms, napa cabbage, carrots in a very thick soup - reminded me of chinese hot and sour soup.
author: Anna L.

description:
Everything was delicious and the service was nice.

The only reason it didn't get 5 stars is that on some things the portions were large (congee) but then they were stingy on the meat compared to similar places. Note I was eating alone and thought I'd need a to-go box, but I was mistaken.
author: Ellie M.

description:
This review is for the Beef Noodle Soup ONLY.  

A little background.  I come from the South Bay so I'm very used to a full-bodied broth, beef that just falls apart in your mouth, and a beef/bok choy ratio that shows one is only there for color.

That being said, Taste of Formosa is.....not bad.  It wouldn't rate among my favorites but it's definitely not the worst I've had.  The broth was decent.  It could have had more flavor and I felt like there was maybe a little too much anise but not too shabby.  The noodles were the weakest link.  You need hand-pulled noodles to make it to the big leagues.  The noodles here sort of fell apart and were very thin.  The beef was something I could only describe as inconsistent.  The first couple pieces were chewy as hell.  The third was a little better, and the fourth hit that sweet spot of just falling apart in your mouth.

All in all it's as my rating suggests.  It's A-OK.  It wouldn't be my first choice but in a pinch, it'll do....
author: Chris C.

description:
When I start dreaming for Taiwanese food, I gotta come here. I like this place because it's not dingy, the food's not too oily and done well. It is on Clement though, so parking's the luck of the draw. There's two floors. I enjoy eating upstairs because it's not as dark as it is downstairs and they usually have a concert music video playing on the TV to watch/listen to while you eat.

Each time we come here, they haven't disappointed. We always order a few dishes from the following:

Oyster Crepe: doesn't look appealing as it's covered in sauce, but extremely tasty (one of our favorite dishes)
Deep Fried Pork Intestine: they drain it so it's not sitting on a bed of oil and it's nice and crunchy on the outside
Dan Dan Mien:  a cold minced pork noodle dish
Stinky Tofu: not really stinky and great w/the sauce they provide
Preserved Egg and Tofu: love the sauce
Ma Po Tofu: spicy minced pork and tofu (fairly spicy if you can't handle Sriracha)
Preserved Egg and Tofu: slices of preserved egg over a block of tofu surrounded by a pool of their sauce (another of our favorites)
Eggplant in Basil Garlic Sauce
Sweet Soybean Milk and Chinese Fried Donut: something I grew up eating, so I love to drink/eat it for nostalgia
Sticky Rice in Pork Chitterling: slightly crispy skin w/flavorful sticky rice
Sticky Rice Cake w/Pork: lots of flavor in the pork that infuses into the sticky rice

Haven't ordered anything we didn't like. They always have me coming back.
author: Kitty K.

description: Food here was pretty good. Always get the braised pork over rice with egg. some times I get the combination braised items or the fermented tofu. Prices are good and service is prompt.
author: Jerry Z.

description: There's so few options for Taiwanese food in San Francisco that this is literally one of our go to places because there is nothing else. Used to order delivery but they jacked up their minimum from $35 to $50 to go to our area. Ugh. Sadly because of the extra gouging I'll just wistfully go get Taiwanese at another time or place.
author: Shay F.

description: I love Taiwanese food especially its fried chicken steak 雞排 rice dish. So I ordered the dish at the restaurant. For $8.95, I got one small piece of fried boneless thigh and some preserved vegetables and rice. The chicken steak was not flattened, and there was not even enough meat to make up the steak at all. The quality of the food and the price they charge for the dish were just outrageous. Very disappointing. I wonder when this restaurant would go out of business. There are a lot of competitions in the neighborhood. Please check in with your chef and ask him or her whether or not Taiwanese fried chicken steak should be cooked that way.
author: GR Z.

description:
I enjoy the hometown taste of Taiwan -- although not exactly authentic but it satisfy my thirst.
I like the rice noodles, cold noodles, bacon stir fried with cabbage, sticky rice in bamboo cup. The food was good.

However, when I ordered two more dishes to go, and asked for an additional box for my leftovers, I was told I had to pay for the third box-- hello, I paid for the takeouts, and my dinner, now you are charging me for a box for the leftovers? Finally, she gave me a very tiny cup (sauce cup)to put my leftovers in so she won't have to charge me.  That's ridiculous.
author: SJ L.

description: This is kind of the only deal in town when it comes to Taiwanese food in SF. Does it compare to Taiwanese food down in south bay? No, absolutely not, but it's a decent choice if you live in SF and you are craving some Taiwanese food. The dishes are on the smaller side which is great for trying a few dishes and for sharing. They have plenty of space upstairs for seating large groups and I've never had to deal with any lines. The only downside is parking in the area is not great so plan ahead.
author: Alice H.

description:
I'm here for the stanky tofu. It was my first time trying it ever and I'm really into it. I have such a love for food, I can almost eat anything and everything. It has a very distinctive smell. The flavor is not too intense but you can definitely taste the fermentation. The service is Chinese, what I mean by that is that it's quick and they won't bother you. You order, you get your food, you get your check. Straight forward.  A variety of tasty dishes for cheap! I tried the oyster omelette, a well known dish of Taiwan, and was disappointed. I'm not sure how it should be properly prepared but I wasn't expecting a glutinous rice, chewy texture.. very saucy as well. Not my cup of tea. I've also tried the wontons in chili sauce, pot stickers, braised pork w/rice, and savory soy milk. All were pretty tasty.

However, I'm still craving my stank tofu...yummmma.
author: Emily M.

description:
Try:

Beef noodle soup - the noodles are just so good
Pork Belly over rice- little blend
Tofu with preserved egg- a lot of garlic but a lot of flavor
Passion fruit tea- always love a little sugar on the side

I always come here :)
author: Moto B.

description: More like 3.5 stars. Came here for some snacks with friends. I had the crispy chicken nuggets and the wonton in hot chili oil. Crispy chicken nuggets were typical of what you would get at a milk tea place. The wonton in chili oil was pretty good! I'd come back to try more items.
author: Christine B.

description: super good. i suggest their beef noodle soup, 3 cup chicken and so much more i cant even type!!
author: Katty H.

description:
Pretty extensive menu, so I'm looking forward to trying a lot of other dishes. 

Braised ground pork over rice: Good balance of fatty/lean pork, good rice texture with sauce that really reminded me of other taiwanese meals I've had back home. Egg could have had better flavor. 

Taiwanese-style potstickers: Surprisingly impressed with the crispy skin and flavors (even though I had take out). The garlic-y sauce is authentically Taiwanese. Will order this again when I crave potstickers. 

Marinated seaweed: Not the best I've had, but they certainly give you a lot of seaweed for one portion. I personally enjoy thinner seaweed ribbons but these were great also.

Salty soy bean milk: Quite authentic with all the ingredients like dried shrimp, pickled vegetables, even the soggy Chinese doughnut-y stuff. That said, I couldn't taste a lot of the "soy bean" flavor I was looking for. Happy that they make this themselves, but I would expect to taste a lot more soy milk.
author: Jackie C.

description: I don't remember the exact names of the items were on the menu since I didn't order but I think it was beef noodle soup, oyster soup, egg flour scallion pancake and this other pancake thing with meat in it.  Everything was tasty and good portions.  Service was ok.  The upstairs is really nice and modern.
author: Chris L.

description:
It is pretty hard to come across Taiwanese restaurants in the city. Taste of Formosa, fulfills that craving. 
I came here on a cold night with my boyfriend. For appetizers, we ordered Salty Sticky Rice Roll and the Pork and Chives Dumplings. They were both delicious and pretty standard. I was feeling adventurous and ordered the Squid with Vegetable Soup and Rice Noodles. I felt pretty indifferent about my dish. The soup was very favorable and you can taste the XO sauce; not to mention, it was very thick. My boyfriend ordered the Braise Beef with Noodle Soup and that was the winning dish for the evening. It was not as spicy as I thought it would be; the beef was cooked perfectly and the flavors of the soup complimented the whole dish.

Overall, this place definitely has a lot of potential. The only con is that parking around this neighborhood is a challenge. However, they do validate parking! :)
author: Emily L.

description:
The braised beef noodles - so yummy! A little hint of spiciness and the noodles were a perfect consistency

Scallion pancake - I heard mixed news that this may turn out super oily but luckily, my pancakes is not!! It was fluffy crispy scallion goodness!

& lastly, I got the wonton in spicy sauce, which is actually beef wonton swimming in spicy chili oil. IT WAS DELICIOUS! It wasn't actually that spicy (just don't dunk the wontons in anymore of the oil) and the beef had a nice peppery kick to it. TRY IT

So what if my arteries are working extra hard the next few hours, my belly was happy! 

I was also surprised at the upstairs, it's a nice space! Huge windows and an abundance of nature lighting! I will be back ;)
author: Tiffany N.

description:
So I'm fresh off the boat from Asia. Seriously. 
Just arrived back from 4 years abroad and skeptical that SF's food can compete. 

... And honestly, it can't. (Nothing beats the motherland)
But... compared to the other city eateries, Taste of Formosa holds it own. 

Let's be clear, Cupertino, or even East Bay, have this place beat... but for helping me get my oyster pancake and chive pancake fix in the city, this place gets an extra star. 

Don't expect anything mindblowing, but if you need to feed your inner Taiwanese FOB with fried pork chops, marinated cucumbers, and ba wan and don't want to leave the city limits, then this is your place.
author: Vic C.

description: Got the chicken poridge delivered and it was good. At least it was good up until I found a bug.
author: Nancy H.

description: Fantastic food, but even better service!! When I walked in for a Postmates delivery the hostess sat me down and offered complimentary tea. When I returned to try the food, it was amazing! Definitely recommend this place!!!
author: Austin N.

description:
We come to the Taste of Formosa quite often, especially when we were craving for some Taiwanese foods. 
In general the service was nice and the foods are good too. And it opens until quite late and still open during holiday season, so we come here during after hours.
author: Michelle H.

description:
I have been in search for good Taiwanese food in SF; Formosa turns out to serve home-made Cantonese style food instead. 

The dried fried noodles were just mi fun noodles chop suey style. 

The beef noodle soup was disappointing, they let me switch to clear noodles for 15 cents. I was really surprised they asked me for permission to charge 15 cents extra.

I think the best part of the meal was the $4 pork over rice bowl but it was so fatty and I've had better. Next time, I'm getting my Taiwanese food fix from South Bay.
author: Jess C.

description:
I first came here as just a casual dinner with a large group of friends.

Staff could be friendlier, and the food wasn't all that great.

I came back a second time for lunch with my friend and it was worse.

The food seemed luke warm and lacked in flavor. Definitely not authentic Taiwanese food. Not planning on coming back here.
author: Mabel Y.

description: The preserved egg with pork congee and Chinese donut came out very hot, which assured me that, despite the hair I had the misfortune to find in not one, but both dishes, I would unlikely get sick over them. The hairs were about 1 cm in length and black; I'm guessing beard, nose, or black rodent being possible sources. Flavorful dishes, but off-putting enough for me to add this review to the existing three reviews of this establishment with the search term "hair" found in food.
author: Debbie Y.

description:
YUM!

green onion pancake
- crispy and perfectly fried

sautee beef noodle soup
- thick noodles perfectly cooked
- yummy spices (surpising because i expected a chinese style beef soup)
- rich broth

mango beef
- sweet mango
- tender beef
- plenty of onions
- in a deep fried bowl that soaked up all the juices

shrimp and chive dumplings
- good but tiny and tiny portions for the price

pork belly over rice 
- meh, this is the only item we got that i dont recommend

service is on point as well
author: Tina A.

description: I FOUND A PUBIC HAIR IN MY MINCED PORK BOWL. It was gray and black. One of the older cooks must hate their job. I love this place and the minced pork but  deliberately messing w the food for no apparent reason is disgusting.
author: Theresa H.

description: Well it's close to me, so I eat there quite a lot. Excellent food. Recently had been addicted to pork rice, Lu roufan. But all is pretty good, I haven't found any dish that too off. Perfect homely restaurant.
author: madeline m.

description:
I come here because of the limited choices in Taiwanese restaurant in San Francisco. A few highlights:

Pros:
- Huge selection of Taiwanese snacks and dishes
- delicious cold tofu dish

Cons:
- pricey for asian food
- service can be slow at times
author: Fu D.

description:
Their food can be a hit or miss and the portions aren't very big for what it costs. There are certainly other places that are more filling for the same price you pay here, but Taste of Formosa is one of the few Taiwanese restaurants around the city. They often only have one person running both the register and waiting the tables, so service can sometimes be spotty, though the food (usually) makes up for it.

I almost always spring for the potstickers (a bit overpriced IMO, but still delicious) and fried pork chop rice (batter for the pork chop could be better but the crisp goes well with the rice). They also validate parking, which is a nice gesture, and the food comes out pretty quickly and their menu options are pretty unique since you don't come across very many Taiwanese restaurants in the city.
author: Felix C.

description:
After an all afternoon at Angel Island, I wanted to bring my friends to some different ethnic food restaurant....and this was the place.....

The tofu with preserved eggs, the best as usual.....we ordered tons of dishes, but I had to drop one star, my friends mom found a piece of hair amongst the veggies in the loaded oyster egg pancake......nasty.....they did apologize and asked if we wanted a new one, but we declined, mentally it kind of throws you off.....so they deducted it off the bill.....

One specialty ordered was stinky tofu, it was a first time for me and loved every bite of it......it is an acquired taste for sure.....

We arrived quite early, about 5, they were just opening, so we were the first ones there.......

I definitely will still return but not for hair in the food, hope they take care of that issue....
author: Leslie Y.

description:
The staff here is incredibly rude. I came here on a Sunday night with my family and it wasn't busy at all, so I don't see why the waitresses needed to be so rude and give us an attitude that conveyed impatience. On top of that, we found a hair in our chicken. 
After the rudeness of the staff, I already had a bitter taste in my mouth, so I can't say anything good about the food here.
author: Samantha W.

description:
The taste is pretty good....but i would say the price is not.
For a chicken porridge they are charging for $7 for a small size. Its pricey for porridge in my opinion. The good thing is that hey gave us Taiwanese style rice ball as complimentary treat.
author: T P.

description: Great simple eats. Good prices. One of the few taiwanese restaurants in SF.  So I can't complain :)
author: Kate S.

description:
An okay Taiwanese restaurant.

Venue: Pretty big 2 story place. Semi trendy decorations.

Service: Okay.

Food:
- Three cup chicken (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hYH3XfUXFc09TjiuGfLiow?select=XnLB4XVKlRcQSyvI4KgLuA) - $10.50 Tasted okay. Evenly coated sauce. Chicken was cooked well.

- Mustard green shredded pork fried rice cake (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hYH3XfUXFc09TjiuGfLiow?select=M3k4bsdz7GsxL_GiwmmCyw) - $8.95 Tasted okay. Like any other fried rice cake dishes you have anywhere else.

- Stinky tofu (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hYH3XfUXFc09TjiuGfLiow?select=phJ7TGUviqal-llV45Oi8A) - $6.95 Tasted decent. Not too stinky.

- Oyster pancake (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hYH3XfUXFc09TjiuGfLiow?select=EXOpztp9gi4Ip3KTyH9bdQ) - $6.95 This was good. oyster in chewy batter with the usual oyster pancake sauce.

- Stir fried Chinese squash with clam (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hYH3XfUXFc09TjiuGfLiow?select=m-BLyRjpvJO5TNMsexnYEQ) - $10.95 Very refreshing dish. Loved the clams.

- Beef noodle soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hYH3XfUXFc09TjiuGfLiow?select=Nm09UAcxQ5J5p0qk0RT6EA) - $7.95 Tasted okay but not great. Didnt exactly like their noodles and soup wasnt beefy enough.

- Red bean paste cake (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hYH3XfUXFc09TjiuGfLiow?select=mkka8L4rrPGLVWhly5bm8g) - $3.50 Not bad. 

Price: Slight over priced for okay food.

Overall: This place was all over an okay restaurant. This is probably the only decent Taiwanese place in the city so far. If you want good Taiwanese food, go to the south bay.
author: Jannifer H.

description: A twist on the usual flavors. Taiwanese food distinct from Chinese. Clean and modern inside was a surprise. Great noodles and great service. Some items such as pigs feet or tripe might be challenging for some, but there is something there for the less adventurous.
author: Matt A.

description: One of the only authentic taiwanese restaurant left in the city. Great service and great food. Will be back again.
author: William C.

description: I really love this place, albeit I have never had any other Taiwanese food. Their spicy wontons and the braised pork bowl are my faves. Their beef noodle soup is oily as hell but tasty.  I wasn't crazy about the salty soy bean milk with doughnuts or the tofu with thousand year egg, but I'm also not too used to those flavors. I do not recommend the jjajangmyun!! It had a very bizarre taste to it, almost soapy or citrusy and I had to send it back. Otherwise, for the price and the taste, this place is great!
author: Terry K.

description:
There's a sign on the door that reads "yes, we have stinky tofu" in Chinese, and that pretty much sums up this place.

If you've ever been to Taipei and had the priviliege of sampling/getting sick from their numerous street food treats/night market offerings, this place is exactly that sans the 1300 dollar round-trip flight and the initial confusion at Taiyuan Intl' wondering why the Taiwanese use "New" Taiwanese "Dollars."

If you have no idea what I'm talking about and are new to Taiwanese cuisine, the following are a MUST:

Fried Intestines
Oyster Pancakes
Taiwan Beer (honey lager... ish)
Century Egg Tofu
Beef Noodles

Much to my delight, they also cook mapo tofu Taiwanese style (basically the tofu isn't drowning in a soup of oil) ; their stinky tofu isn't quite as great as the one I tried at the HK Plaza in Hacienda Heights, but it definitely qualifies as stinky.
author: Scott S.

description: Consistently delicious!  We have been ordering our Asian take out and dine in from this place alone.  The food is so flavorful, fresh and yummy.   We've had take out and done in at other places in a pinch and they simply do not compare.  The staff is always polite and friendly.  Highly recommend this neighborhood gem.
author: Melissa O.

description:
My 1st time actually trying Taiwanese food that my Taiwanese friend brought me to, and I wasn't disappointed.  The dishes were simple but full of flavor, and kind of reminds me of homemade food, which I like.  
I got the pork chop with rice along with other dishes such as the tofu, and oyster pancake, which were all delicious.  The tofu was super creamy.  The boss and the staff were nice and attentive to make sure everything was alright. 
I'd go back again to try all the other dishes!
author: Raymond C.

description:
The hunt of decent Taiwanese places in the City led us here. (There are fewer of them than one would expect.  I guess they're all down in San Jose)  First impressions - it's very nice inside, but the downstairs eating area is small.  If you are wondering where everyone is, they're probably upstairs.

Friendly and fast service.  Both the marinated beef tendon and the scallion pancake arrived quickly.  The beef tendon was wonderfully seasoned and spicy - thin shaved and excellent.  The scallion pancake, on the other hand, was not.  It turned out doughy.  Most places tend to do pancakes dense and crisp, so if the goal at Taste of Formosa is for a fluffier pancake, it would be a great differentiator but in our case, didn't work.  The pancake ended up just being greasy and unpleasant to eat.

Onto the main course, I had to go with the Braised Beef Noodle Soup.  The broth was a richer broth and the cuts of beef were more simply prepared - very clearly not cooked down with the stock - so they held up their own flavor and texture more than most others.  A serving of baby bok choy and napa cabbage.  Noodles were fresh, cooked al dente, but otherwise not that impressive.  Portion size was decided average.  Prices are a very fair.

Don't take the three star review as a huge negative - Taste of Formosa is the best Taiwanese restaurant I've found in the City.  But somewhat surprisingly, compared to what's available elsewhere in the area, best for San Francisco is only decidedly average for the rest of the Bay.
author: Jason H.

description:
I just have to add that I literally killed an entire order of fried pork intestine to myself. BOMB.COM. Stinky tofu is killer here, but you can also order non-stink too. 
Beef noodle soup was on point as well. I've had my share of really good taiwanese food in LA, and I feel like this can compete with the best of them. 
Damn good comfort food.
author: Brian C.

description: Always looking for authentic Taiwanese restaurants this is definitely a great find. They have all the small snacks from stinky tofu to 5spice sausage to full meal items like three cup chicken etc. A must go for Taiwanese and Taiwan lovers a like.
author: Andrew W.

description:
I honestly think this is probably one of the only authentic Taiwanese restaurants in the city...if not one of the most tasteful.  

I love their cold thousand year old egg tofu dish and their oyster egg pancake.  Their soup noodles are tasty and you also must try their fresh soy milk.

This place also delivers within the Richmond area for dinner.
author: Patrick C.

description:
The Rundown:  Acceptable Taiwanese food for Bay Area standards, but the price of street eats may make you shy away.

Oyster Cake (Oh Ah Jian):  B
Tasted okay.  A bit heavy on the corn starch and a bit light on the oysters.  Compared to the real deal, this was definitely a smaller portion.

Sticky Rice in Banana Leaf (Zong Ze):  A+
Definitely reminiscent of the night markets in Taiwan.  Everything from the taste to the consistency to even the fatty pork used was on point with my mom's cooking.

Beef Noodle Stew:  A-
Broth was tasty.  Noodles were cooked well; not overdone or underdone.  The portion again was a bit small.

Crispy Fried Chicken:  B
Reminiscent of the street vendors in Taiwan.  Taste was on point, but it was seven dollars for a small portion (you can get comparable dishes from Tapioca Express or Quickly for 3 dollars).

Pork Belly with Garlic Sauce:  A
Thin slices of grilled pork belly with green onion and garlic sauce.  Definitely a killer dish.  The pork belly was tender and was not overdone.

Schezuan Style Fish:  A
No idea why this was on the menu as it really isn't Taiwanese, but still cooked pretty well.  Only drawback was that it was incredibly oily; not for the faint of heart.

If you need your quick fix of Taiwanese food, this isn't a bad choice.  If you're a food snob, this will probably only leave you half satisfied.
author: David C.

description:
Pretty much the only Taiwanese spot to sit down and eat at comfortably. They even use the kind of take out boxes used in Taiwan! Makes me think of all the stinky tofu I ate there. 

This place is clean and the decor is contemporary. You also get plenty of space between tables. For that, you pay a bit more. Worth it.  There seems to be a decent amount of Cantonese being thrown around by the staff... with Mandarin.  So not sure how authentic this place is.  But I can tell you, food still tastes good.

Order:

Oyster pancake
Stinky tofu
Green onion pancake
Meat rice 
Beef noodle soup
Fried chitlins (aka intestines)

And probably some vegetables because you're not getting any of that from the above order.

Five stars because there is no other decent Taiwanese place to eat at comfortably and in groups. And for those take out boxes.
author: Erika C.

description:
It's hard to find Taiwanese restaurants back home so I decided to go exploring in the world of food. That's why I decided to try this place out while in the BA. 

Luckily, I wasn't too hungry when I entered this contemporary and clean restaurant and was able to skip the lunch rush. When seated, the waitress quickly brought out a plate of roasted peanuts and hot tea which was the perfect snacking food. Sorry to hear other reviewers didn't have great service but maybe they stepped it up because my waitress was very attentive and prompt. 

Since eating Taiwanese food is somewhat new to me, I went with the basics and ordered warm soy bean milk ($2.25), scallion pancakes ($6) and wonton with hot sauce ($7). The soy bean milk was awesome to match the cool weather outside and the pancakes were nice and crispy. Sad to say, the wontons were drowning in the chili oil with a lack of flavor. 

Overall, it was just okay and I will continue for my Taiwanese adventure somewhere else before I come back here. Zai jian!
author: Santi T.

description:
Yay to Taiwanese food in SF! We came here with my in-laws who were Taiwanese and they have a lot of Taiwanese snacks-green onion pancake, pickled cucumbers, fried chicken pieces, spicy wontons etc.. 

Parking can be a bit tricky in this part of town and the portions are kind of small for the price but we liked our food here and could see us visiting again.
author: Betty C.

description:
It was ok. Nothing so great for me to come back and say "OMG I have to try it again!"
I came here with 2 other peeps, they ordered ground pork with rice and beef noodle soup. I ordered the pork chop over rice. The fried pork chop tasted like the popcorn chicken you get from quicklys, thought that was funny, but prefer it not tasting like it.

I also ordered a thai ice tea...can't go wrong with that, but their ice were the shape of lil mushrooms, very cute, until they melt and im sad.

All in all, it was ok, nothing bad and nothing great.
author: Jade L.

description:
Great tasting food. Reminded me of the street food you'd get in Taiwan. Staff was constantly refilling our tea. BUT I went home with some major explosive diarrhea so BEWARE if you have a sensitive stomach!! I'm giving 2 stars to be fair because it was good tasting food, the staff was nice, and it could have just been my stomach (but probably not).

Our group ordered the following:
Scallion pancake
Oyster pancake
Wonton in spicy sauce
Stinky tofu (which was way stinkier than what I remember from HK, it was like eating a stinky gym sock)
Beef satay noodles (best tasting dish of the night)
Taiwanese dumplings
Marinated cucumbers
Total: $53

Not bad if you don't mind risking spending the night on your toilet in pain.
author: Dorothy W.

description: I live near Inner Sunset so I rarely come out this way.  One weekend we had plans to eat in Inner Richmond but couldn't find parking, so we ended up in this area and decided we were in the mood for Taiwanese food.  The restaurant is small but cute, reminds of of little eateries in Taiwan.  It was late afternoon so the restaurant was almost empty, and the service was good.  We ordered some authentic Taiwanese tapas (oyster pancake, etc.) and the dishes were fine, but I didn't think they were great or authentic. They put bean sprouts in the oyster pancake, I thought that was strange but maybe that's a new trend? I didn't like the flavor.  They did have Taiwanese beer, which was a nice surprise!
author: Sarah W.

description: My friend recommended me to come here so I had very high expectations. Unfortunately, they didn't quite meet my standards. I think the food was just okay. Not bad... But nothing to die for. We went there at around 4:30 pm and it wasn't busy at all. I ordered the minced pork dish with a tea egg, ba wan, and dan dan noodles. The dan dan noodles were super greasy. I will go back and give them another chance.
author: Jennie C.

description:
The service is good. The dish is okay but a bit pricy. The portion is small. The rice ball is a meh. Rice noodle with starched broth is fine. We do love the loofah broth with clams, though.

Heard that people said their beef noodle soup is yummy. It did smell great and authentic on our next table. Too bad we didn't try it out.
author: Elaine L.

description:
My new favorite place to eat! I have passed by this place many many times, but never actually tried this place. But ever since I went to Taiwan, I started to crave for Taiwanese food... and within one week, I came here twice.

For my first visit, I had the braise beef noodle soup , the minced pork over rice , and mapo tofu. I loved the beef noodle soup, the soup was flavorful and a bit peppery which was exactly what I wanted. The minced pork over rice was average, it was definitely nowhere near the one that I had in Taiwan, but it wasn't bad. The mapo tofu was cooked perfectly, but was not spicy at all... even though we asked them to make it as spicy as possible. Still, I was very very happy with my beef noodle soup, so I don't care about anything else.

Now for my second visit. I ordered the salted sticky rice roll, and fried sauce noodle  (similar to the korean black noodle), and my boyfriend ordered oyster vermicelli soup and satay beef. I did not really like the oyster vermicelli, but that is because I don't really like cooked oysters. My boyfriend enjoyed it a lot and said he likes how it has the consistency of shark fin soup. My fried sauce noodle was okay, not as good as the korean black noodle though. The satay beef was pretty good, a bit pricey for the few pieces of meat though... but anyways... I LOVED the salted sticky rice roll!!! It is soooo hard to find a place that makes sticky rice rolls and that actually have fresh crunchy oil sticks  in it. So happy I finally found yummy salted sticky rice roll!
author: Alicia W.

description: I heart this place. I grew up in Taipei, Taiwan and has been living in the states for 10 years. This restaurant cooks food that reminds me of home. My favorite food is braised pork over rice and oyster noodles. I was so happy to find this place after many disappointing dining experience I had based on my search of high yelp reviews in San Fran. Maybe I just don't like Chinese food anymore when everything dish is covered with some kind of sauce, thick breading, and starch. Taiwanese food has a good balance, deep fried food is never with thick breading and everything is just more flavorful with the cover up of thick sauce coding like Chinese food. I wish there is a Taiwanese restaurant like Taste of Formosa in San Diego...
author: C B.

description:
If you can bear the stinky tofu smell, you can enjoy some Taiwanese dishes.  Although they aren't the best in terms of execution, it's one of the few places that serves authentic specialties, such as oyster crepes and stinky tofu.  It even has some hakka dishes.  The meat, poultry and fish are tender for the most part, but they lack flavor at times.  

Service is friendly, but slow especially if you order from separate staff.  The ambiance is simple and open with tables that either have chairs or booth seating.  However, parking is tough on the street.
author: Jenny L.

description:
We went here for the first time on Friday. The feedback about parking is true...it's terrible. We spent 30 mins looking for a spot. TIP: Go to Geary and park there between 24th to 27th Ave...if you don't mind walking to Clement. 

We had the stinky tofu (did not finish it), the oyster crepe (it's bland), and the shrimp & pineapple (we finished it!). The server kept serving a supposedly hot tea....but, it's COLD tea in a pot! *SMH*

I don't think we are going to come back.
author: Emil J.

description:
Ordinarily my rating for Taste of Formosa would be 4 out of 5, only because they're a bit pricey and keep raising their prices. Having been lucky enough to have lived in Taiwan for a short spell a couple of years ago, it's hard finding good Taiwanese food here, and this is normally our go-to for Taiwanese food. 

However, tonight I had the salt and pepper chicken tender appetizer, which came with a bee fried and breaded in one of the bits. Oddly enough, fried bees are in fact something you can get in a little village called Wulai in Taiwan (check out http://www.travelchannel.com/TV_Shows/Bizarre_Foods/Episodes_Travel_Guides/ci.Taiwan_Episode.map), and they're actually pretty good once you get over what you're eating. But I really like to know when I'm going to be eating a bee or a bug or any kind of animal that I didn't order. 

As an aside, we eat out regularly, so maybe statistically speaking it's about time I found something in my food that wasn't supposed to be there. A bee's definitely the oddest thing to find and still better than a cockroach or anything like that. 

Dear Taste of Formosa, pleeeease take more care next time. Your food is usually amazing!
author: monica d.

description:
Not bad not bad! I'm always overjoyed when I go to any Taiwanese restaurant since they seem harder to find than some other cuisines, but I will try to evaluate this place without the bias of being a total Taiwanophile. 

The first thing I noticed is that the prices are really steep. Granted, all the stuff I ordered here is stuff I miss from Taiwan, and as such, the last time I had any of these food items, they each cost me less than a dollar off the street. But even without that, I don't think the portion sizes nor the quality merit the average of 7 or 8 dollars a dish. Taiwanese food is snack-y and tapas-style mostly  so this turns into a bit of splurge if you want to order multiple things. 

The beef noodle soup is so-so, the flavor is overwhelming of Taiwanese bbq sauce (sha cha sauce) and doesn't have the rich spicy aroma of properly braised beef. The noodles aren't as chewy as I would have liked either and the soup was on the salty side. We also ordered the duck tongues, which were pretty good, the Taiwanese rou yuan (glutinous meat dumpling thing), which was somewhat decent (not chewy enough, not enough filling, but the sauce was good), chilled cucumbers (a little too sweet), and the Taiwanese chicken pork sausage (probably the highlight of the meal). I really wanted to get the oyster omelette, cause that's my go-to at Taiwanese places but the Yelp reviews said to skip it. Another bummer.

All in all, not the best Taiwanese food I've had but definitely will be a go-to place to sate those T-food cravings now and then. Yes, I guess I would call it a Taste of Formosa, but there are better places to get the full flava experience!
author: Carol C.

description:
Sautéed pork with kimchee, stanky tofu, oyster or green onion pancake, all so delicious...

Love this place!
author: Arlene R.

description: YUM- thank goodness this exists in SF, now I do not have to drive to the peninsula or S bay for this food.  It was nice and tasty.  The service was nice.  It is no frills.  You will not be in Taiwan when you go here, so lower your expectations.  It is good for what it is, and again, it is tasty.
author: Lisa M.

description: My wife is from Taiwan so i came here with her. I loved all the food we had here. I had fried pork rib lunch. It was great, light and not greasy. My noodles tasted good and fresh. My wife had braised pork over rice and oyster noodles and she said it tasted like home. We went to SanTung Chinese restaurant before we came here and was shocked how bad the food was there with over 4000 4 stars Yelp reviews. It was awesome we found Taste of Formosa in San Fran before the end of our road trip. It made my wife very happy so it made me very happy!
author: Mac P.

description: Food is just okay, and the waiting time is too long, we been waiting for 50 mins and still not get the last item, and when we asked for the check, and asked about the item, then they gave it to us in 2 mins .... The 2 tables next to us had finished and we only got half of our orders (we ordered before them)
author: Kevin W.

description:
Places with stinky tofu are better and Taste of Formosa delivers.
