They started us off with some complimentary roasted peanuts, which made me think of being in a Chinese teahouse (if you watch Chinese soaps set in ancient times, they receive a dish of peanuts at teahouses). It looks like a teahouse too.  The downstairs area is small but there is an upstairs area that we didn't see.

* Scallion pancake ($5.95): excellent, features crispy thin layers of golden pan-fried dough, plenty of scallions, crispier and more layered than usual
* Dry fried sauteed green beans ($7.95): oily but good, liked the texture, slightly crispy but still soft, doused with many sesame seeds, a little salty
* Lion's head casserole: good but not great, didn't have bean threads, probably the weakest dish 
* Spicy fish filet ($11.95?): delicious, mild, tender white fish, bathed in hot chili oil, topped with chiles, green onions
* Stinky tofu: fried crispy cubes with a mildly spicy dipping sauce.  I liked the crispy refreshing cucumber salad on the side - a nice contrast.  It wasn't that stinky.

The menu is filled with Taiwanese street snacks.  You'll also find noodles, porridge, soups, rice plates, sautéed dishes, etc...and red bean desserts.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Great beef noodle soup. 
Delicious tea, fill me up buttercup!
author: Sydney L.

description:
A little pricey for the food you get here. I usually only get the beef noodle soup and a green onion pancake. I think that the pancake goes well with the beef noodle soup because I like to dip it into the soup (which probably has MSG because it taste so good) For some reason every time I try something new here I just regret it. So now all I get is beef noodle soup and green onion pancake.

What I recommend:

Beef noodle soup + Green onion pancake
author: Andrew W.

description:
Came here because a friend said they had a nice stinky tofu in the city so had to come and try. Sat down for awhile and finally decided on a few plates. Right after we ordered was when they started eating, opening at 11:30pm. They were more focused on lunch than us. 

We had the Mao Po Tofu. The amount that was in that big bowl was equal to 2 rice bowls. The flavor was nothing special. No spices but salt and chili pepper oil.    

Our Sticky Rice Roll was next. The rice was fully cooked, a challenge for this stuff so that was good. Had a crispy piece of Chinese donut in the center, but the lack of dried pork made the dish almost flavorless. 

Our Deep Fried Intestines was the best. It is very hard to screw this up other than them not cleaning it properly. Since we didn't get sick, I guess they did.

The last plate to come was the Stinky Tofu. The proper way of eating is with the pickled cabbage, but there wasn't enough of it. The tofu had a lite hint of smell and so was the taste.
author: M C.

description:
It's tough to find these dishes in the Bay Area since most "Chinese" food is predominantly Cantonese style.  Whenever I eat at Taste of Formosa I am not disappointed.  The only drawback is the portions are rather small and expensive.  However if you are in the craving for some decent Taiwanese dishes and snacks, this place does the job well.

By the way, this is not a "buffet", not sure why it is categorized as such.
author: Lizzie L.

description: Okay Taiwanese cafe in the Outer Richmond. It's alright, nothing spectacular. Their beef noodle soup satisfied a craving but leaves you yearning for that something extra.  I live 2 blocks away but will only come here if there's nothing else open in the area.
author: Jing D.

description:
STINKY TOFU!!!!!!!!! Oh my lord, STINKY TOFU!!!
So rare to find here.. But yes, STINKY TOFU!!!
It is not made nearly as stinky as the place in Chinatown used to. I grew up on this crap. Yes, it stinks. Yes, it makes your house stink. Yes, it makes your breath stink.
I LOVE IT.

TOO STINKIN BAD FOR YOU.

Oh, the cold tofu with 1000 year old duck egg is freaking good too.
author: Susy C.

description:
Their Taiwanese-style fried rice noodle was somewhat pricey (over $8) but it was very good.  It's been a long time since I had that, and now this is the one place that I know of (at least in SF) where I can go get it.  I also ordered their hot and sour soup.  It was $6.75 for a small size but to me the portion seemed small for the price, mainly due to the type of bowl that they used (one with the sloping angled sides).

Otherwise, I find this is now the place in SF I can go to for getting goodies associated with Taiwan, such as fried stinky tofu and oyster omelette.  Also, I'd say the service was fairly good by the staff, particular the young ladies working this past Saturday evening when I went.
author: H K.

description: It is a bit small place, and the environment is overall not bad. The foods are generally okay, and the service is not bad. Notice that the waitresses speak Cantonese.
author: Aaron S.

description:
This place puts a lot of love in its food, too bad it's in the form of salt and MSG.   

The braised beef with noodle soup is ok, I was pretty thirsty afterwards and finished a pot of tea and a glass OJ to help quench my thirst.  The beef and noodle, i would give 4 stars, the broth 2-

The onion pancake isn't that great, but worth a try.... I think the Korean version is better ( and I don't say that too often!)

My chick friend also thought it was ok, not worth raving about. I will give this place one more chance though.
author: B H.

description: always order the braised pork over rice here to go. the fermented tofu is also pretty good
author: Joanna S.

description:
Came here because I was in SF and my friends and I passed by the restaurant. Although I ordered Taiwanese-specific fare because I hadn't seen these dishes in a while, I was disappointed because of the portioning and taste. 

The best part of the meal was the sauce for the fried chitterlings: absolutely delicious and perfect in terms of sweetness, spiciness, and flavor. The chitterlings themselves were a bit disappointing; no Taiwanese sausage inside the rice part, the outer skin was not crispy enough and just stuck to my teeth.

The oyster pancake also had pretty bomb sauce, but the pancake itself was not crispy enough on the outside and basically, was a small limp mess of pancake and a limited amount of oyster. It was also unexpectedly tiny for its $6.95 price-tag ( about 6 inches in diameter).

My friend and boyfriend both ordered the pork chop dish, which basically had pork chops that tasted like popcorn chicken with limp breading. The soy sauce eggs were so overboiled that they became small, hard, salty eggs.

The pork and preserved egg congee was also lacking; the pork just tasted like chicken strips, and the preserved eggs were difficult to spot.

Overall, the sauces here were great; the other food not so much. Also, although the waitress diligently refilled our tea, she was also the quietest person I've ever met. She basically whispered to us when she took our order and whenever we asked her about anything.

I've definitely experienced better, especially if I pay $20+ for a small meal.
author: Crystal W.

description:
Came by on the weekend around 2 in the afternoon, and they're still fairly busy.  Service was good though.

We ordered - 
1. Salty sticky rice roll: only available on weekend; tastes okay, but a real lousy job at wrapping the roll, everything was just hanging out...
2. cold noodles: meh
3. Taiwanese rice noodles: not exactly authentic, but not bad
4. salt & pepper chicken: never again
5. stinky tofu: best dish of the bunch

Without any competition in the city for Taiwanese food, we'll stop by if a craving for stinky tofu strikes, in spite of their prices.
author: daphne w.

description: This is my go-to place when I crave Taiwanese food. I usually order the minced pork rice, with an egg. I wish the portion could be larger, but the taste makes up for it. The restaurant also has that small, family-run feel. It makes me nostalgic for the time I spent in Asia.
author: Emily S.

description: I used to travel to Taiwan frequently and started enjoying their food (yes, even stinky tofu!)  I like this place for the nostalgia and the food.  It's easy to get a table and the staff is reasonably friendly.
author: V S.

description:
It's good to know that there is a place that serves pretty good intestine noodles in the city that I can go to if I ever get the craving! Been wanting to try out this place forever and finally had the chance to come today for lunch. 

We had the following:
- Oyster pancakes - pretty good. still not as good as my aunt's BUT you can actually see the oysters and taste it. yums!
- Fried onion cake - everyone seems to rave about this but it wasn't that impressive. The skin was crispy and the inside was soft... BUT it seemed too doughy... you can add an egg on it though. I love eggs.
- Intestine & oyster noodles - tastes pretty good. the intestines were really good. needs more vinegar and hot sauce.
- Beef noodle soup - the broth of this tastes of sa cha which I'm not big on. The noodles are like the hand pulled korean noodles that you get with za jian mien. Good if you like the sa cha sauce flavor.
- Seafood porridge - not big on this... didn't have much flavor.
- Soy bean milk with fried chinese doughnuts - they serve the soy bean milk in a cup and they serve the chinese doughnuts in a dim sum size. 

Overall, everything was great. Would definitely come back here for more!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
We liked the food; until today.
We found a long long hair in the dish: fish fillet with hot special sauce.
I claimed for refund right after we found the hair.
I ask to refund just for that dish, not for the entire bill.
The owner came out, stared at me, and said:
"You ate all of the fish and ask for a refund?"
Since they already took the dish into the kitchen,
I could not check how many pieces of fish I ate. 
However, who would expect hairs in their food and inspect the dish before they start eating?
The owner never apologized until I left the restaurant.

Me and my wife like the food and dined here at least once every other week, but I guess we won't eat here anymore.
author: In-Sung L.

description:
Had it twice. I think that's about 2 times more than I should have came. 

Over-priced undercooked Taiwanese food at its finest. They do good job keeping your cup of tea filled though. 

The ba wan is definitely a solid choice. Don't bother getting anything else.
author: Jason K.

description:
My parents took me here for my birthday.  I've actually been waiting to come here for months.  We were seated upstairs which was a lot nicer than the downstairs area.  The decor was simple and modern.  The staff wasn't very friendly though.  Not much was going on with recommending dishes.

There were 6 of us and even though the waitress suggested we order more, we were full by the end of our meal.  Here's the list of what we ate for lunch.  
-salt and pepper chicken: delicious!  I love the pieces of basil; I ate those too!
-green onion pancake:  I love how is was a little doughy and yet still flaky
-stinky tofu: need I say more?  Half the table didn't care for it but I ate about 4 pieces.
-Mongolian beef:  very good but waaay too many green onion and regular onion pieces (I ate those too though).
-Oyster egg pancake thing: yuck!  My mom and dad liked it.  It reminded them of what they used to eat in Taiwan.  The texture of the dish was just unappetizing to me and everyone else expect my parents.  Mushy oysters!
-Combo chow mein: Yum
-honey walnut prawns: nice presentation and big pieces of prawns

Although we found parking right away I think parking is usually a problem in this part of the Richmond district.  If it were easier I may consider coming back here sooner than later.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
I came here with a friend for lunch and had quite an experience. We ordered:

Curry Chicken with rice
"Water cooked Beef" ~ some sort of spicy beef dish. (forgot actual name)
Some vegetable dish.

The food was alright.... I've definitely had better.....

Half way through our meal the place started to smell like feet. I thought that someone took off their shoes or something but we were pretty much alone on their top floor. Soon my friend asks me if I smelt something funny. After telling him I smelt it, he informs me that they sold STINKY TOFU there!!!!! 

(~ ~") If I ever have to smell that stench again.... I will die.
author: Mai W.

description:
My friends surprised me here for my birthday lunch the other day. I immediately liked the place when I walked in because they were playing Jay Chou music.

The Good:
+Passion-fruit Green Tea = very good
+Shaved Ice with red bean = very good
+Scallion pancake = one of the best appetizers I have ever had

The Bad:
-Braised Beef over rice = the 'beef' was mostly just fat and barely had any meat. I should have tried other things but my friend said yelp reviews recommended to get this dish. I regret ordering it. Better to order one of the entrees and a separate bowl of rice.

I will come again to try the other dishes that I should have gotten, such as Mango Beef and such. But, until then, 3 stars. 

I still don't know what 'Formosa' is though. I should have asked the workers lol.
author: Benson T.

description:
I was craving the rice cakes w/ pork & veggies all of a sudden, so looked up some Taiwanese restaurants in the area. I've been to Taiwan Restaurant between 5th and 6th ave on Clement before, and opted for some place new.

We ordered the rice cakes w/ pork & veggies, along with this pork over rice, w/ veggies & an egg. It was a moist type of rice, which tasted pretty delicious. The rice cakes had a nice flavor to them as well, and I would definitely recommend both dishes.

However, the down side would be that both dishes were freakin' TINY! They were like small plates; barely enough to feed one person per dish. I believe the dishes were $9 and $11. The portions are definitely about twice as much over at Taiwan Restaurant.

Overall, taste was declicious. Place looked a lot cleaner and newer than the other restaurant, but portions were way off! 

Parking is not the most fun as usual, but a few circles should do the trick.
author: Elaine H.

description:
I've only ordered delivery from here so can't speak to the service in the restaurant. This is definitely my favorite Taiwanese place, and one of my favorite Chinese places from which to order (OK, I know that Taiwan is not China). The delivery is usually pretty quick, the prices are OK, and the food is delish!

I love the basil garlic eggplant dish. It's not greasy or salty; it's perfectly sauteed. And I also always get the homemade Chinese sausage rice, which is really, really good. We did try one of the soups and wasn't too impressed, but everything else we've tried has been really good.
author: Amy B.

description: We really like that restaurant, the food was perfect and the price is very fair.  Our 3 1/2 year son also liked the food particullary the Tofu.  The waitress was very fine and was always looking to help with our son, they got all the toys before they fall on the ground.  The service was fast, the tea was very appreciated and they fill your cup as soon as it miss one sip into it.
author: Daniel G.

description:
a close T-DUb, gem of a place..

Nicely decorated place 2-story place. You can find parking on the metered streets if your lucky..

They have a good variety of traditional street market vendor eats. This is probably the closest as it comes to the real thing, but I must point out they do have some flaws...

soy bean milk ($1.95) & chinese donut ($2.5) - pretty good, not too sweet with the soy bean milk. Crispy and not stale from earlier in the day..
 
Oyster pancakes ($5.95) - Decent, not too gooey on the starch or not to clumpy. Oyster tasted fresh and good amount of green veggies. The sweet and spicy sauce need a little work...

Fried Onion w/egg pancake ($6.96) - This was a weird one.. Never tried or seen this before. It was fried a little too brown for my taste. Crispy pancake with egg on it. I'll pass next time. 

Intestine & oyster noodle soup - Good flavor reminiscing T-dub, and intestines was actually pretty clean compared to most places. 

Beef noodle soup -  if you like sa cha sauce flavor to your beef noodle soup then this place is for you. Pretty good beef with a strong sa cha blend for the broth. Good texture with the noodles..

I would recommend and come back for my T-Dub fix. =)
author: kent c.

description:
Oyster pancake! They have oyster pancakes!!! And stinky tofu!

I haven't had oyster pancakes and stinky tofu in awhile, and this place serves a pretty good one. Like others have mentioned, this place is a little more expensive, but it's served in a clean place and the food's good.

They also serve beef noodle soup, which is wonderful when you're trying to get through a cold day.

If you're having a craving or simply just miss Taiwanese food, this is the place to go if you're in the Richmond district!
author: Steven W.

description: The Taiwanese food here is pretty good and relatively authentic. I was not super impressed, but still I enjoyed the food at Taste of Formosa. We got chinese squash with clam, basil with clam, stinky tofu, braised ground pork over rice, and a few others I can't remember now. The two most popular were the two clam dishes. For dessert we tried all the options - the bean curd, the rice balls, and the shaved ice. The shaved ice was good, but I wasn't a big fan of the bean curd. The peanut with the bean curd wasn't cooked enough.
author: James K.

description:
Its rare to find a "Taiwanese" restaurant thats clean and good.  Dont be mistaken from a chinese/szechaun/hunan one.  Taiwanese food is like asian tapas.  Dishes are small and one dish doesnt feed a family of ten.  Not to mention its SPICY! LOVE!

I drool over the sauteed bamboo shoots (spicy), spicy cod, marinated pig ears, and their basil clams!!!  OMG....those clams!  Food is excellent I have to say and the place is very clean.  ok...minus the weird smell when you walk in cuz they serve "stinky tofu" which is a fermented fried tofu.  Not a like to everyone's taste buds, but if you have a SUPER sensitive nose to scents you might not want to come here.  Its bearable though once you start having a few Taiwanese beers to wash down the spices that are burning your tongue!
author: Gina S.

description: I minus a star because the last dish I had was pretty gross, Don't get the Spicy Minced Pork noodles, too spicy and oily! The chinese donut is very crispy but i literally felt drips of oil going down my throat, gross! Pig ears, ok Beef Tripe, chewy and tasty sauce.
author: Karen T.

description:
Authentic Taiwanese (street) food! Probably one of the best in SF. I'm still looking around in the bay area though...

My favorite thing to get here is the Oyster Vermicelli Noodles, my favorite dish in Taiwanese street food.  

The price is on the higher side for what you get...
author: Sway M.

description:
Food: Not bad... but then again, if restaurant food were bad I'd just cook at home.

Service: Um, WHAT service?  The waitress was utterly confused.  We asked her to recommend a couple of dishes, which sent her into a frenzy... and she spent quite some time explaining to us the difference between appetizer and main course.  Huh?
author: Kristen S.

description: This place is amazing for Asian people who love authentic Asian food(not the Americanized Asian fusion kind). It is run by native Taiwanese people(I can tell from their accents). The food here is pretty hard-core Taiwanese food and pretty comparable to the food I ate in Taiwan. If you are a native Chinese person who is a fan of Taiwanese food you will definitely love this place. If your not used to authentic hard-core Taiwanese food, you need to reconsider your choice.
author: Angelina L.

description:
Formosa What.

If you get the song reference we should be friends.

If you don't you'll still want to know there are almost 100 items on the menu. Pork, chicken, tofu and seafood in a variety of dishes ranging from salads to soups to entrees. You'll need a few minutes to decide.

Squid sauteed in white wine was a solid choice. Lots of seafood and lots of veggies. Someone expected given the twelve dollar price tag. Good if unmemorable.

Service was about the same. Friendly if not all that interested. 

They might be more interested in this:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-ALdTMnuUpE
author: Jason B.

description:
It's nice to know that Taste of Formosa remains at the top of my list for Taiwanese places in the Bay Area and somewhere I can take out-of-towners who are craving good Taiwanese food.

Service was even more lackluster than usual today, with multiple promptings for water and tea refills, yet only one request for the check required. Hence the minus 1 star, though I still really love the food.

The scallion pancake (in reality a cong zhua bing, not cong you bing) was excellent as always, tasting very much like what you can get from street vendors in Taipei. The fried tofu snack (su zha dou fu) was fantastic - a crispy shell encasing tender tofu - and came with a great dipping sauce (garlic, black vinegar, sugar plus some chili sauce). Other winners included the pork chop rice (the pork chop was true Taiwanese style, like what you can get on the Alishan railroad at Fengcihu) and the cold noodles (liang mian), which was done more in a Sichuan style (sesame paste as the base for the sauce instead of peanut butter/paste) but without the spice.

The Hakka pork belly was pretty good, with a garlic/white vinegar based dipping sauce, though very fatty (if you like that kind of thing). The "Taiwanese-style" potstickers were ok... but compared to the other dishes fell a little flat; same sauce as the tofu. Maybe if they had been true Shanghainese/Zhonghua Rd open-ended potstickers they would've been better.

I almost forgot... the cold sweet soymilk was a definite plus, especially with yesterdays temps and sun. Not quite the burnt taste that I favor, but still mighty refreshing.
author: Albert C.

description:
While in SF with my mom and sister a few months ago, we were all a bit hungry and wanted a snack. Since we were in the Richmond area, I suggested to drive over to Clement and that we would be bound to find something. After parking and looking down the block, we saw Taste of Formosa and my mom practically made up her mind. Anytime we encounter places with Taiwanese food, my mom is sold. (She grew up there) 

The restaurant is pretty small, but a cute little spot. Service was friendly as my mom and the lady kept chatting and chatting. The menu here is pretty big and varied, and they definitely have all the yummy, traditional Taiwanese snacks/food. We ordered Oyster Omelet, Oyster Vermicelli w/Intestines and Oysters, Minced Pork w/Rice. 

All three dishes were good and my mom completely enjoyed it since it's all nostalgic for her. Taiwanese food can definitely be tougher to try/appreciate since there's a lot more unique/odd sounding ingredients to it. However, I have loved all Taiwanese food that I've tried, whether here in the states or Taiwan, which always surprises my mother. (I think she forgets that I'm a foodie, and practically love everything)

Overall, great little Taiwanese spot. We appreciated/enjoyed this place a lot especially since Taiwanese food isn't necessarily abundant in the Bay Area. Prices are also decent - I'll have to come back when I get the chance.
author: Tiffany K.

description: Taste of Formasa is one of the best taste and authentic Taiwanese food that i had so far in the San Francisco Bay Area. Must try their braised pork over rice with egg.  It is phenomenal. The owner is very friendly!
author: Alen H.

description:
One of my friends told me after the fact that if you speak Chinese when you enter, you are immediately whisked away upstairs to the much less ghetto portion of the restaurant. B and his friend went and spoke english and sat downstairs, and then when we went a couple months later I spoke chinese and got seated upstairs, so maybe there is a kernel of truth to this? 

ANYWAY. I miss Taiwanese food ALL the time. And A Taste of Formosa (although lacking a little in imagination in restaurant naming) delivers with Taiwanese small eats.

Stinky Tofu is a must - we ordered two plates of this. 
Beef Noodle Soup
Congee with thousand year old egg and lean pork
Oyster pancake - HOW I'VE MISSED YOU SO
Hong You Cao Sou.. er... Wontons in spicy oil? bad translation, delicious food. Just get it. 
Pig ear

Our table of four ate very happily, and our waitress was actually pretty attentive and friendly.
author: Julia C.

description:
A taiwanese friend referred me to this restaurant, was not disappointed.

I'm not familiar with the Taiwanese cuisine, but the waitress gave a lot of suggestions. 

Dishes my 2 friends and I decided upon:
-oyster crepe? snack. I never had something like this before. Quite interesting, i'm not sure if i like it or if i think its just okay. 

-bowl of rice with pork and pickled veges. It was really good, a simple dish but tasty because of the salty balanced with sweet and sour. (these are like individual portioned, maybe 2 ppl can share 1 but yeah)

-eggplant with basil and garlic. much more complicated than just what it states. It is cooked with pork and some bell peppers and nested in a big fried wonton skin bowl.

-bbq ribs(idk the name of it on the menu) but its 3 pork ribs with sauce all over it. VERY Tender! did not need to pick up the rib, just used a fork very easily. 

I would come back to this place and try other items. But i refuse to try stinky tofu unless i am in asia. Last time I had it in the US, it tastes like how it smells....
author: Erica L.

description:
Was craving TW food and being in WC, my options were fairly limited, so I trekked out here to satisfy the craving.  Overall it was decent, but certainly not amazing. 

-- NRM: decent but I've def had better
-- jang jang mien: okay, def have had better
-- steamed clams w basil: yum! prob my favorite dish
-- oya-gen (oyster pancake): ew, too mushy and gooey
-- stinky tofu: pretty good, prob one of the better places I've had it (aside from TW, street-side!)

Given the limited options for truly Taiwanese cuisine in the city, this serves as a decent alternative, so will I be back?  Quite possibly. However, nothing beats the SGV (other than the motherland, of course!)
author: Cynthia G.

description: A dangerous place for using ur credit card. Has ur card info and swiped with a Radom peoples order.... Bad staff attitude....:(((
author: Wendy H.

description:
02.27.11

ToF has become a hot debate topic amongst my core group of baggie friends.  Fred is in love with this place.  The rest of the baggies were fine with it, until we started having to hear about this every week.

I mean, their dishes are OK.  I like the beef noodle soup.  And the stinky tofu.  But they use quite a lot of MSG on their food.  Enough that I can drink almost a whole pot of tea during a meal there.

They play Chinese concerts on the flat screen, so it's a pretty consistent form of entertainment.  My people sure know how to look ridiculous on stage.  Seriously, sometimes Lady Gaga has nothing on them.

Parking in the area is horrendous.  A paid parking lot on a Sunday night two blocks away charges $3.50 for every 30 minutes.

I know I'll inevitably be back, so I can't bash it.  See you soon...
author: Jenny L.

description:
The service was horrible. The waitress named "Emily" apparently doesn't know how to manage the tables and customer's orders.

- She walked away in the middle of taking my order, when she saw new customers walked in to the door. 

- She could have sat the customers down with menu and quickly return to my table, but then she continued to set out their plates, utensils, tea cups, ran back to the back to fill up the pot, and returned to that table to fill up their cups. After all that was done, unfortunately some dishes came out from the kitchen, so guess what? She had to deliver the food to different tables and we just sat there and watch her running back and force.......

- When she finally returned and took my order, she did not give my order to the kitchen immediately!! She turned around and took order for the people that just made me waited. 

- She submitted both orders to the kitchen without specifying which table came first.

- While the table behind us got all their food and 5 minutes into their eating, we got nothing on our table!



The food was mediocre.

- Oyster Egg Pan Fried: Below standard. The taste was not quite right, and the texture was horrible. This kind of stuff will not sell in Taiwan.

- Minced Pork Over Rice: The pork was slightly stinky.

- Scallion Pan Cake with Egg - $6.99 for something like this? Come on!

- The Salt and Pepper chicken was actually not bad.  But then again, it does not justify the price. For the same price, you can get twice as much food and better tasting chicken from Tapioca Express. 

Oh, and did it mention that Tapioca Express probably has much better service than this place?
author: Shin H.

description:
It's really hard to find an authentic Taiwanese food in SF because basically Chinese food here is Cantonese food. So when we found Taste of Formosa, we went there immediately. 

They have a good menu with lots of authentic dishes. My happiness just by reading this menu was so high. Everything we ordered was authentic Taiwanese food, by name. When we tasted the food, my happiness decreased less by less. They were not bad, but not good either. I wouldn't blame them. They want to include too much in one restaurant. Every of these dishes missed something, yes, I'm saying they're not authentic enough. In Taiwan these authentic dishes each had its unique flavor. Many even is the only food sold  by the owner. So I can understand it's too difficult to make every dish taste as good as they're in Taiwan. 

But I would say the flavors taste good if I don't consider the 'not authentic enough' part. 

I read some review talk about the portion are small and price kinda expensive. Well, the small portion is collect. Many of them are sold in night markets where you eat many authentic small dishes from different venders. But the price in Taste of Formosa is indeed expensive, you cannot eat these small dishes the way you do in Taiwan or you'll have a small hole in your wallet.
author: V L.

description:
This place was a decent meal, but I'm not sure if I'd come back here anytime soon. Its far out in the avenues and is a bit of a trek if you don't live in the area.

I walked in planning to eat with a party of about 20+ people, and couldn't figure out how they could fit so many people. It looks like about 5 tables when you walk in.  Interestingly, there's a 2nd floor that makes it pretty huge.

Food-wise, it was OK. The prices and they were a little steep for Taiwanese food, but the overall quality was pretty good.  Service was ok, but the food came out in very wide intervals. There was a lot of people, so dishes came out maybe one at a time for the first 15-20 minutes, then suddenly came en masse.
author: Lily W.

description:
This place is sooo authentic


Fried intestines are awesome 5/5
taiwanese pork chop over rice 5/5
Scallion Pancake 3/5
Cold Noodle With Shredded Chicken 3/5
Sliced Pork With Garlic Sauce 5/5
Braised Ground Pork Over Rice 5/5
Fried Chicken Over Rice 5/5
Braised Pork Feet Over Noodle 3.5/5
Clams With Fresh Basil 5/5
Marinated Cucumbers 5/5
Braised Marinated Pig Ears 5/5
Spicy wontons 3/5
Combination Braised Items 5/5
House Special Cold Noodle 2/5


everytime i go, i pay like around 25 per person.. kind of expensive, we also overorder tho....
author: Cindy L.

description:
Taste of Formosa is a small joint with two levels located in one of the busier sections of the Outer Richmond district, replete with several other dining options on all sides that range from Indian to Thai restaurants.  I felt the need to write a review only because I come here so often for takeout since I have a few friends that reside within walking distance.

The space itself is quite narrow and compact, but as previously mentioned, a second floor provides a little more breathing room but be warned, on hotter days it may get a little stuffy as the proprietor doesn't seem to believe in air conditioning.

The service is decent as well as the decor; everything seems simple and clean.

The menu consists of traditional Taiwanese fare, although most of the food here does not remind me of my childhood, probably because my mom was never into super traditional Taiwanese cuisine, but rather, a much more simplified approach to cooking.

Interestingly, there is a full bar that serves beer, wine, and cocktails.  Right, just in case you wanted to down a couple of shots of Grey Goose with your stinky tofu (it would probably take me to do that just to go near that stuff).

The oyster pancake and various rice dishes are the most common items on my order and are usually satisfying.  For takeout, I almost always get either some type of fried rice or chow mein dish.

I would come here for a quick fix, but if anyone knows of any other noteworthy Taiwanese restaurants worth checking out, let me know!
author: Tony L.

description:
Hallelujah...I found an authentic Taiwanese restaurant!! (Ok, not completely authentic but close enough!!!) I have been craving Oa Mi Sua for years and years and am always so sad that it always takes a trip to Taiwan to fulfill the yearning desire. NOT ANYMORE! I came to Taste of Formosa with high high high expectations and it has been filled!! We ordered the green onion pancake, oa mi sua, beef and green onion and fish congee. Only thing - skip out on the congee, not worth it to order here when there are so many other goodies!!!

The pancake was perfectly cooked, crispy outside, sweet inside and not too oily. The oa mi sua... no words. They had the pork intestine's inside and everything!! Which I thought an American version of Taiwanese food would decide to skip out on - thank goodness they didn't!! And the beef and green onion...AMAZING! The meat was so tender and the entire dish had so much home-cooked-miss-my-mama flavor!!

AAAAND...they have delivery here!! Needless to say I will be back again and again and again,..and when I do not have the means to get there. I will order delivery.
author: Christina L.

description:
Straight up Taiwanese cuisine as the name suggests.
Decent sized facility for lunch. Came on a Sunday and was seated upstairs and ordered the beef noodle soup and green onion pancakes. The noodle soup was flavorful and delicious but I wasn't too sold on the pancakes. 

Warning! This place serves stinky tofu which was obvious that someone had ordered it as soon as you walked in. Unfortunately I couldn't try it since I had gutless wonders in my group that day and couldn't see myself eating the whole plate by myself. Awww. Maybe next time...

Did order a cold plate: pig ears, dried beancurd, seaweed, forgot the last item. All with a bit of chili sauce which was pretty good as well.

Ok, I got feedback on the pig ears. PIG EARS you say? Man, that's like the asian version of potato chips. They're crunchy and delicious. Just move on if you don't have an iron stomach and can't deal with variety.
author: Michael C.

description: I've been here a number of times and this is the best Taiwanese food in SF, in my opinion.  Not as good as the places in the South Bay, but with the gas I save from not driving down there, I can save up for my next trip to Taiwan.  The dishes are pretty authentic and good.  Particular props to the pork chop rice.  The beef noodle soup and Tainan style bowl cake (ba wan) are not bad either.  The oyster omelette was a little disappointing though.
author: Neill T.

description:
We walk into Taste of Formosa late on a Wednesday night to the heedy smell of food. Ben turns to me and asks, "Smells like home?" with a smile. True, true, it smelled like home -- if not my home, the homes of Taiwanese families everywhere.

The food was authentic Taiwanese. The green onion pancake was sweet with margarine because in Taiwanese fashion, you have to make your breads very saccharine. The beef noodle soup had the familiar taste of the satay sauce you get at 99 Ranch, with spaghetti-like noodles because in Taiwanese fashion, spaghetti noodles are *cool*. The marinated jellyfish salad was tasty -- tossed in vinegar and sesame oil. I will definitely come back to try more things on the menu. 

Great atmosphere, nice people, very clean, late hours.
author: Angie C.

description:
I ordered 5 appetizers and 5 entrees.  Here is my critique:

Food - 3 stars
Service - 2 stars
Ambience - 4 stars

Appetizers:

1. Scallion pancakes - I would recommend this appetizer.  It was very good.
2. Stinky Tofu - soooooo disappointed.  First of all, it wasn't stinky.  I was expecting to smell it as they were bringing it up the stairs.  The weird part is that it was hard to smell the stinkiness, then the tofu tasted like *ss.  I heard it is supposed to smell like *ss, but taste delicious.  Either different chef than the other reviewers, or they are making it wrong.  I heard it is supposed to be really stinky.
3. Fried oysters - delicious, but where did they get the oysters?  Where I'm from, oysters are 3-4 inches long.  These were the size of razor clams.
4. Combo Appetizer - pickled pig ears, tea eggs, black fungus, and marinated cold tofu cake.  Pig ears were good, but didn't care for the rest.  The tofu was like eating a wet sponge.  The fungus had the consistency of kelp.  Tea eggs were like normal chicken eggs.
5. Fried pork intestines - weird taste where it was not prepared right. It crunchy on the outside, but super chewy on the inside.  I have had better.

Entrees:
1. Pineapple shrimp - not bad flavor, but wished they used a lighter batter.
2. Braised eggplant with garlic sauce - it was pretty good.  Nothing too special.  They cooked the eggplant OK.
3. Mango Beef - beef, mango, and pineapple with some sauce.  It was OK.
4. Bacon with napa cabbage "salad" - let's sprinkle bacon bits on a couple of leaves of cabbage.  What an insult!
5. Watermelon drink - OK....people said I have to get this.  It literally was blended watermelon.  I was expecting something mindblowing.
6. Rice - since the meal didn't come with rice, then we had to pay for rice by the bowl.  I think they should have a big side order of rice instead.

Dessert:

All their desserts contained red beans.  Nothing seemed appetizing.  I guess desserts wasn't meant to be the highlight of the menu.

Service:

Our server wasn't as attentive as I hope she would be.  Also, I'm surprised we didn't get any water.  We just got hot tea.  The biggest disappointment was that we ordered a fish fillet dish, but never got it.  I'm not sure if she didn't enter it, or the cooks overlooked it in our order.

Ambience:

We were upstairs, which was a larger and more pleasant experience than downstairs.  It was an open area.  We were next to the bar, which had a large TV playing Chinese music.   The lighting was adequate.

Summary:

Overall, I'm not sure what the hype is about this place.  Either I'm ordering the wrong dishes, went at the wrong time when they changed chefs, or my palette is so different than everyone elses.  I just wasn't sold on this place.  If you go, set  your expectations low, so you won't be disappointed.
author: Ryan Y.

description:
3 cup chicken------does authentic but it's edible
stinky tofu---------doesn't stink but it's very crispy
chicken roll--------decent

I will not be back to this restaurant again..........if it's in LA.
since SF doesn't have many Taiwanese restaurant so I will definitely be back again.
author: Rina C.

description: This place is so Taiwanese, from its cute sign to attentive service to yummy food. The smell of stinky tofu hit me straightaway when I walked in. It smelled delicious. I got a hankering for their preserved egg and tofu (cold) and ordered it with a pork chop. So much flavor my stomach hurt afterward, but it was worth it! Next time I'm giving the stinky tofu a try.
author: Carol C.

description:
Passed by this place the other day and decided to give it a try. I like Taiwanese food, but didn't know any when I lived in the city, now I found it, here we go.

This place looks so small from outside, but it has a second floor which is pretty spacious!

Two of us order some snack dishes: 
- Oyster pancake is good. Better than most of the other places I tried, but I still prefer Mama Chen for that
- Tofu and preserved egg is one of the favourite out of all the places I went
- Ground pork rice is cute and decent
- Ordered a rick stick to try, since I saw some review online that highly recommended it. The rice is very well cooked, but the chinese donut inside is a little too hard, I like it softer.

Overall, it's pretty good with good price. I would go there again if i go to San Francisco and want Taiwanese food.
author: Chloé N.

description:
Went with some old friends and just had them order their usual since I've never really been to a Taiwanese restaurant before. 

Hot and sour soup had a good amount of stuff in it and just the right amount of spicy. Really enjoyed it. Flavorful.
Scallion pancake with fried egg: my first time having a fried egg on a scallion pancake but this pancake is what I'm talking about. All the other scallion pancakes have not measured up like this one has.
Ma Po Tofu: was good but only had one helping of it. In hindsight, I wish I had more of it. Went so well with my rice.
I had this chewy (rice) dumpling with beef(?) filling in it that was really good. The chewiness of the outer was so good and the beef filling was just the right amount (not too much and not too skimpy.)
Oyster Vermicelli Noodle Soup: I enjoyed it all except the oysters (but I don't care for cooked oysters, so that is not the restaurant's fault)
Oyster Crepe: again, not an oyster fan, but the one accidental oyster that I ate seemed like it wasn't dry and had "good" oyster flavor. I enjoyed the ketchup sauce on top of this crepe, so I think next time I'm going to get the Shrimp Crepe.

Got another dish that was beef and veggies in a bowl of spicy sauce. Don't know what it was called but it was too salty for me. But my friends really liked it, but I thought the salt load was a bit more than I could tolerate. 

Will definitely come back here and bring friends. Oh, on the way downstairs and out, something smelled really bad and I just realized it might have been their stinky tofu...

Lastly, attentive waitresses. Loved how they were playing a Cantonese Kareoke DVD upstairs in a Taiwanese restaurant. Muahahaha.
author: Vicki T.

description:
OK, it was date night with the wife.  After the movie, we head for a quick dinner before picking up the kids.  All the other restaurants in the area was full, except for this place...should have been a clue.

The menu had hand written changes to the prices, but when you walk into the dining room you are hit with a interesting scent...sort of sourish smell to best describe it.

Appetizer:
Chives Shrimp Dumpling $7.25.  There were about a dozen of these little flavorful pillows.  This is really good with or without the white vinegar they served on the side for dipping.

Main Courses:
Braised Beef Noodle Soup $8.25.  A bowl of udon style noodles in a spicy soup.  The beef is pretty tender considering its braised.  You can take the noodles out and eat it away from the soup for a not so hot meal.

Braised Beef over Rice $8.25.  Looks more like a beef stew with carrots & turnips.  The sauce has just a bit of heat.  The rice is more on the side then under the beef.  The beef could use a bit more braising...like another hour or so...it was bit chewy.  The turnip is very bland, did not pick up any flavor from the sauce.

Bathroom:
There are 2 single unisex rooms.  Both rooms only had 1 light.  The one closest to the wall had the light over the toilet...the other room had the light over the sink.  There is also a motion sensor that turns on the light...must be cutting cost on utilities.
author: Jerry W.

description:
Feels a bit Americanized and also pricier than what Taiwanese food should be sold at, but the food is still delicious, and it really is hard to find Taiwanese food in San Francisco.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for a late lunch, ordered eight dishes and my boyfriend left nostalgic after our meal. It was so cute how everything we ordered brought him back to his childhood days. Now we have to venture to his parent's place to satisfy our authentic Taiwanese food cravings!

-oyster pancakes: YOU MUST ORDER THIS! I've only tried green onion pancakes but geeeez, these oyster pancakes along with the sauce, is like crack in pancake. 

-stinky tofu: I guess this is what everyone comes to Taste of Formosa for. Not as stinky as I anticipated but it was very good. It was like fried tofu. I can't wait to go to Taiwan to actually have the real thing! This dish came with a sauce you dip your tofu in and also pickled cabbage. It went very well with stinky tofu. 

-intestine and oyster noodle soup: this dish was perfect because of the weather. I can't really explain how it tastes like but it is also very delicious. The intestines look like bean curds so that's what my boyfriend kept telling himself it was.. but in reality... it was intestines.. hahaa.

-preserved egg and tofu: basically, this dish is a block of tofu (precut) and a thousand year old egg cut into slices and it's bedded with sauce. I hate how I can't explain how good Taiwanese food is because I am not Taiwanese. It's good, trust me. 

-spicy wonton: the name of the dish says it all. incredible!

there were many other dishes we ordered. I don't know what it's called in English nor do I know how to explain how the dishes are prepared. :(

The waitress was super sweet and very helpful with helping us order. Although she doesn't speak perfect English, she speaks enough for us, non-Taiwanese people, to understand.  

I will definitely make sure to come back here when I'm back in SF!
author: Tiffany K.

description:
some good dishes - green onion pancake, beef noodle soup, freshly made dumplings. deep fried yellowtail fish
some dishes that did not work that well - drunken chicken, House special ribs
and service that did not seem to click this evening. i was charged corkage and ended up opening the bottle myself because our server did not know how to work the corkscrew.
go figure!
plus parking in this part of town sucks!
wasn't worth the trip.
author: Jeff W.

description: Foods were quite authentic. The restaurant owner and its waiters are all very kind and helpful. It made you feel like home. I highly recommend it.
author: Lo Y.

description: The price is a lil high but Good food !! Not too far from where I live Will come again :)
author: Tsz Chung W.

description:
This place has a variety of authentic taiwanese dishes. I came here a few times knowing their cooking is not consistent. 

My boyfriend and I usually order a oyster pancake (o wah jin), fried intestine, intestine stuffed with sticky rice, stinky tofu, and braised beef and soy suace egg with rice. 

The oyster pancake is  a wet pancake with a chewy mochi like substance. The veggies they use are quite fresh. 

The fried intestine and intestine stuffed with sticky rice are the two dishes that are not consistent. Sometimes, the fried intestines are over cooked making it hard to chew. This dish normally comes with a red vinergarette sauce. 

Often, the stuffing does not carry enough taste making the whole dish quite bland. Even the sauce accompanying the meal does not help, as the taste of the sauce will only dominate the original taste. 

My favorite is the braised beef and soy sauce egg with rice. The meat is nice and tender filling your mouth with joy in every bite. Many places have a problem with over cooking the braised beef, but this place is the exception. You could add a soy sauce egg to your meal, but there is nothing special about the egg. Just an extra.  

Stinky Tofu! This place is not comparable to the star lunch cafe on Jackson street that is closed, but they are one of the few places that serve stinky tofu. The tofu is cripsy on the outside and carries a small stink, but the inside is not flavorful.
author: Sylvia C.

description:
Great place, very good Taiwanese food!

The flavors reminded me of the food I had in Taiwan.
The pork chop was amazing and the Hakka Pork Belly appetiser was excellent (with a lemony like sauce).
So much to choose from (excellent variety) and many cool new things to try!
The service was great: very attentive, polite and friendly and not in the least bit invasive.

I'll definitely be coming back :)
author: Matt C.

description:
Trying to find good Taiwanese food in San Francisco can be a frustrating and dejecting.

That said, when my friend introduced me to Taste of Formosa, I knew I had finally found my fix.

The day they introduced stinky tofu, I fell in love all over again.

Some of the food is a little unique in style, like the green onion pancake and beef noodle soup, but it's kind of nice to see them trying to give standard and basic dishes a little bit of a different spin.

Lately they also got friendly and more helpful staff, and also better music (last time I went they were playing a Fish Leong DVD). I feel like they are perpetually improving and adding items.

I'm always happy to bring my friends and family here, and it probably saves me countless dollars in bridge tolls or long drives South for Taiwanese food.

...I just wish Yelp didn't erase all the Chinese characters I typed...
author: Ken R.

description:
Ok, this place is as authentic as it gets. 

1. Asian people who seemingly have bad service because they're only comfortable speaking Chinese

2. Amazing food (even my friend who is Taiwanese said this gave him a "ratatouille" flashback of when he was back in Taiwan) 

I only discovered this place two months ago and i can already say, "i'm a regular". The price is good (i almost always order the small dishes) and every dish so far has been a hit. 

Some of my favorites:

1. Braised ground pork over rice - always a winner; flavorful and full of ingredients

2. Preserved egg and tofu - cold dish - so good; the sauce makes the dish

3. Bacon salad with taiwanese sauce - sounds weird, right? but trust me, the sauce is really tasty and light 

4. Spicy dumplings - its literally just dumplings dunked in a soup of hot sauce -  so delicious - i am usually very picky about my dumplings. i usually don't like dumplings with skin that's too doughy and the meat inside has to be flavorful and not too compact (like it's been in the freezer for a decade). These fit the bill of being perfect plus the added bonus of extreme spiciness. 

5. Braised pork belly over rice - get with an tea flavored egg - the belly is kinda fatty but i just eat everything except the fat. 

The oyster pancakes are also fresh and tasty, if you're into that kinda stuff. 

Hope you guys enjoy this place as much as i do!
author: Lily S.

description:
We ordered 
Taiwanese pot stickers-very good.
Salt &pepper chicken tender-very good.
Stinky tofu-the best I have tried so far around bay area but I wish they'd give more      pickled cabbage.
Braise beef with noodle soup-very good
Taiwanese fried rice noodle-Very good 
Oyster crepe with special sauce-sauce taste good but too much powder in my opinion.
Overall,their food is great and worth the drive.
author: Ru L.

description: We came here with a large group and ordered family style. The food was very good and we tried several things that I've not seen at any Chinese restaurant in my area. Service was good. The girls were very nice. They missed a couple of things here and there but overall they were very accommodating. I typically am not a fan of green beans, but they have a dish that converted me. Also, the red bean desserts are delicious.
author: Allyson P.

description:
Went back again and got the marinated cucumbers and the on choy (cong xing cai).  Both great.

I miss this place.
author: Ken L.

description:
This place has authentic Taiwanese pretty much down - it's that good !!!  

Sliced pork with garlic sauce - to die for 
Homemade sausage - pretty good
Oyster with special sauce - pretty good but I don't like oysters (wife likes)
Stinky tofu - decent 
Pork with veg soup - damn good
Oyster vermicelli noodle soup - damn good


You can't go wrong coming here - we will be back for sure.
author: D W.

description: It's not that the food isn't good, it's just that I go home frequently enough so when I'm craving for a taste of Taiwan, my expectations are really high. I was born in Taiwan and the majority of my family is still out there. I was so excited to find a place that served classic, Taiwanese street food, but it didn't hit the spot. Not even close.
author: Helen L.

description:
The food there is really really good.
My friend is from taiwan and he said that the fried intestine tastes just like what he had in taiwan.
And i have vegetable and pork rice noodle, it is really good too.
The only thin I dont like about this place is they kinda over price the food.

Since their food is really good, I think I will go back again
author: Kk N.

description:
- Green onion pancakes with egg
- Homemade Taiwanese red sausage with raw garlic and pickled ginger
- Oyster omelette 
- Za Jang Mian
- Pickled cucumbers
- Shrimp and chive dumplings
- Taiwanese fried chicken nuggets with Thai basil
- 3 bottles of Tsingtao Beer
______________

$62 and some change

Very, very good rendition of Taiwanese night market/street foods.
author: May T.

description:
I love their Pork Fried Rice, Chicken Chow Mien, Generals Chicken and Won Ton Soup. The chive pancake is a great starter as well. Overall, everything I've eaten here is great.  It's a pretty casual spot for a late night dinner on those nights that you just don't feel like cooking.  

My one complaint, the staff is very friendly, but they will disappear for a while and you're left searching for them.
author: ERICA G.

description:
Not good.  Not memorable.

If you really like stinky tofu, go to Spices 1, which is a lot better than this place.

Will not go back.
author: Bob S.

description:
Never had Taiwanese food prior to this, so I didn't really have any expectations.  I let my Taiwanese friend order.

I personally enjoyed almost all the dishes we got, although they weren't extremely good.  To me, still tasty though, although it might've been the novelty of trying new foods.  My Taiwanese friend on the other hand, really wasn't a fan at all and felt many of the dishes to be sub-par.

Anyway, combined with cheap prices...  I wouldn't mind returning in the future, although I'm not sure it'd be my first choice in the Richmond.
author: Thuan N.

description:
Came here a couple weeks ago for a friend's birthday party and honestly I was surprised at how good the food was. It was a set menu that she ordered. We sat upstairs in a private room taking up pretty much the whole space. One cold cut dish with pig ear deliciousness, a spicy seafood clay pot with super yummy fish, a scallion pancake, a spicy beef stew, some vege I'm now forgetting and a ton of beer.

Everything was really good here. We even stayed so long that they were shutting the place down. Man I wish it were closer to home, I'd probably eat there more often. Then again I might end up 200 lbs of that were to happen. :P
author: Jessica C.

description:
I think I have to come back again and have it with someone who enjoys Taiwanese cuisine as much as I do.

I came with my boyfriend on a Saturday night and it was pretty empty. I didn't know there was an upstairs, so maybe everyone is gathered up there. He wasn't too fond of the selections of foods and didn't know what to get. Ended up ordering a salt&pepper chicken appetizer and a bowl of braised pork over rice.

I on the other hand was thoroughly excited. I love stinky tofu and this place was pretty much the only place listed on Yelp search for it. I've had it bookmarked for ages and so yes... I was excited.

I saw something that said "Chinese Donut" on the menu and asked the waitress if it was "Saa young". She gave me a dumb look and said "NO. It's yow tiew". .......uhh. SORRY FOR NOT READING CHINESE AND BEING FOBBY. Jeez. 

Anyways, moving on.

I quickly placed an order for stinky tofu and a bowl of minced pork over rice. The bowls of rice came out really quick to my surprise. They were small, almost snack size but enough for me as I was to devour a plate of stinky tofu on my own. Oh, and the egg with the rice is $1 more and dry. DRYDRYDRY.

Onto the tofu. Mmmm, fried crisp to the taste, but sadly it lacked the stinkyness. I mean, it's still stinky for sure but it wasn't stinky enough. Not sure how to explain. Definitely had better in San Gabriel and so-cal, but I can't complain. This city isn't overpopulated with Taiwanese people like it is 400 miles away.


I will definitely come back and eat more of their appetizer dishes!
author: Rosanne L.

description: This is the only Taiwanese place I could find in the city, so there is really no competition, which makes their price unbelievably high, Taiwanese street food are known for its affordable price, that was a shame that this restaurant undermined the core culture of street food. Their food taste pretty authentic,  pretty good but real Taiwanese food could be even better.
author: Diana C.

description: Came here with my kids and I remember the famous item on their menu was the Green Onion Pancake.  It used to be fluffy and airy, not too greasy.  This time, it was deep fried and crunchy, the way they make it at every other restaurant.  The sausages were really greasy too.  I'm not sure I would come back here, unless someone else invited me.
author: Kevin L.

description: The beef noodles here are spicy and savory.  The stinky tofu really does stink. The passion fruit green tea is quite refreshing.  The food is a bit heavy but will hit the spot when you feel like having Taiwanese food.
author: Jennie W.

description:
I have been searching for a good Taiwanese beef noodle soup in SF after having experienced it in Flushing, NYC.  I was so hoping this place would meet the challenge on the name alone.

Unfortunately, the beef noodle soup was tained with sa cha BBQ sauce. Who would put that in in a beef noodle soup? The result was an oily and gritty tasting broth. The beef also was not very tender with the exception of 1 piece out of the bunch.

I also tried the scallion pancake ... very doughy and thick. I like mine light and crispy.

Definitely not repeating even to try the other dishes. I may have to start heading south in search of decent beef noodle ...
author: Daniel L.

description: It's been a while since I was last here, but I seem to remember them having a good beef noodle soup -- good tasty broth; beef is not melt in your mouth but OK, and the noodles were of a super-springy spaghetti-like variety -- not your typical beef noodle stew noodles, but OK. They also do traditional Taiwanese night market dishes like oyster omelette and meat dumplings.
author: Chris L.

description:
I've been to the Taste of Formosa once before and distinctly remembered being underwhelmed by its food. A year or so later, I revisited at the request of a friend and found this place much improved.

We sampled a bunch of dishes. The oyster rice noodles were decent, but the broth was thin and not the right thick, viscous consistency. The beef noodle soup was flavorful, but the beef was tough and not quite melt-in-your-mouth tender. Oyster pancake and scallion pancake were both just okay. The stir-fired kidneys were bland and under seasoned.

The stand-out dishes were sour mustard greens soup with intestines, pork belly with garlic sauce, and fried pork chitterlings. If you can't make it to Spices I or Grand Harbor in Fremont, Taste of Formosa is a decent substitution. Just don't expect it to satisfy all your Taiwanese food cravings.

By the way, parking in this area is a pain in the behind. This place validates parking for up to an hour, but the sign for it was so small that I think very few would've noticed until after parking on the street. Now you know.
author: Teresa K.

description:
I go to this place whenever I have cravings for Taiwanese food.  There aren't that many Taiwanese restaurants in SF.  I used to have to drive to Cupertino, Santa Clara, or LA to find good Taiwanese food.  The food in this place is decent but pricier than other places I'd been to outside of SF.  This is probably due to lack of competition in Taiwanese food in SF.  

I order the following dish and here are my thoughts about the food:

5 stars:  Braised pork over rice (Ru Rou Fan). It's very authentic and tastes great.  It's my favorite dish when I was growing up in Taiwan.  This is the dish that got me hooked to this place.  I love this dish so much that I look for recipes online and make it at home.  

5 stars: Green onion pancake.  It's so crispy and slightly buttery.  It's on the oily and greasy side, so it's not a good dish to order if you are trying to loose weight.

3 stars: Smelly tofu.  I had better ones from Taiwan.  

3.5 stars: Taiwanese fried rice noodles.  It tastes good except they put too much MSG.

5 stars: ice cold soy milk.  It's tastes very refreshing and similar to the hand made soy milk.  It's not too sweet either. 

2 stars: Taiwanese sausage fried rice.  Don't bother with this dish at all!  The sausage was good, but they added only peas, carrot cubes, soy sauce and MSG over rice.  The rice tastes kind of plain and generic.

Overall, I think this place is a good place to go if I only order dishes that have good reviews on Yelp.  I do save time and money on gas, so I can go on a real trip to Taiwan to have all the good food out there.  

FYI:  They provide free deliveries to Richmond District SF (minimum $20 or more) and to Sunset District SF (minimum $30 or more).  They also provide free parking on 23rd Avenue if your dining bill is more than $35.
author: YH B.

description:
Taste of Formosa is a yummy taste especially if Taiwanese street food is your thing.

The downstairs is tiny but upstairs is far bigger. This place is always full of people of local as well as more recent immigrants. The menu is huge with something for everyone and every appetite but what I like best are all the small street food.

we got a variety of dishes based on the fact that one is a vegetarian, one eats anything and one person is just picky. We order duck tongue, pork belly, fish ball soup, veggie dumplings, tofu and one other dishes.

while there are vegetarian dishes here most notably the stinky tofu, this is a place that that's about animal parts, pig's ear, duck tongue, blood soups etc. If you realize that it's stupid to eat one part of an animal but then turn your nose up at other parts this is a great place to try all the parts you have ignored. Of course if you are Taiwanese you'll be familiar with most of the dishes.

the duck tongue is served cold are many of the small snack dishes and a good portion but the best thing was the pork belly. It is so flavourful and melt in your mouth and is far cheaper than the pork belly served in the fancy expensive restaurants right now. All the dishes are large portions so plan on sharing and the prices are good.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: Have been bringing friends so I can eat more dishes and they don't disappoint! Love the omelet with preserved veggies, mee sua with oysters, beef noodles, cold marinated cucumbers, bean curd in soya sauce, glutinous rice with ground pork and mushrooms, taiwanese sausages, and much more!!
author: Sheue L.

description: Honestly, bland Taiwanese food, besides the stinky tofu.  I remember it tasting better than that, when my mom would make it at home or when you get it at the night market in Taiwan.  Not worth the trip, plus they can't even speak Taiwanese in there!
author: Joy-Lu B.

description: Ok Taiwanese food, not completely authentic, but good enough when you want some Taiwanese. I liked the intestine/sauerkraut soup very much, it's perfect for a cold day. And of course fan tuan is always amazing and hard to mess up. Their dan bing is strange though...nothing like what I thought it would be. Didn't care for it much. The sausages were pretty good though and so were the deep fried fish balls...basically the appetizers were decent. Better than some other places in SF claiming to be Taiwanese, that's for sure.
author: Eugi H.

description: i've been here several times, but most of the time it's with my cantonese friends. I finally came here with my taiwanese friend... and i have to admit.. it helps! usually prefer sitting at the top floor because it's more bright and comfortable.  we ordered the spicy wonton, stinky tofu (it's not on the menu, but it's written in chinese on the walls), oyster pancakes, and mince pork over rice. my favorite is the spicy wonton!!! it maybe oily, but you can drain the oil.  it's has the right amount of spiciness ... the stinky tofu looks dry but it's not.. when you bite into it it's fine. i like the sauce it comes with, it was some mince garlic in it and a little spicy as well.  the oyster pancakes had a lot of flavor in it but i didn't know there were spouts inside.. i'm not a fan of spouts.. but i'll still order this dish again. the mince pork over rice was ok.. it just needed more sauce.. other than that, it would've been fine.
author: Belinda C.

description:
This is one of the better places for Taiwanese food. The traditional Taiwanese dishes reminds me of home. One of my favorite dishes would have to be green onion wrapped with deep-fried pig instines. The Sweet and slightly spicy sauce that comes with it offsets the onion taste. It's quite delightful. Their ground pork over rice is also fairly good. The portions are decent and Taiwanese specialties is definitely the way to go. 

The service can be spotty since it's a family business. I usually go on off peak times to decrease the wait time.
author: Eva Y.

description:
After a nice vacation in Taiwan, I found myself back in SF craving the street food and cheap eats Taiwan had to offer. We so happened decided to have dinner here on a Friday night and it was just what the doctor ordered and no I did not get a can of Dr. Pepper. We got all the dishes that we reminisced about from Taiwan like crispy fried chicken, onion pancake, ba-wan (giant ground meat dumpling surrounded by a thick broth almost like a savory, gelatinous mochi), noodle soups, fatty pork, etc. All were pretty good but nothing beats what you get in Taiwan.

Given it was all snack food, portions were pretty small so order tons. Service can disappear on you if you sit up top. I had to get and bring back the bill on my own since they seemed to forget about us. If you want a taste of Formosa, this place will give you a great preview but got to take a flight to the island for the whole entree.
author: Ed L.

description: Bro brought back some Taiwanese fried noodles from here yesterday, they were pretty good. It had some pork, mushrooms, carrots, various veggies...yummm. I can definitely see myself coming here next time.
author: Kylie L.

description:
My gfs recommended this restaurant for our get-together dinner a month ago, as they had a craving for Taiwanese.  We ordered a few share plates: stinky tofu, pig ears, onion pancake, intestine w/ blood cube soup ....yes they went all out on the exotics .  

My favorite is their fried tofu.  I was craving it soo much that I came back this past Fri.  This time around I also had the spicy string beans and a watermelon juice. I recommend the upstairs seating area rather than the lower level as it's a bit small. Also, parking is tough.
author: Stacey L.

description: Talked with the owner Katie who is very nice.  I am not sure if she is really Taiwanese since she didn't have the accent or speak the dialect.  The beef noodle soup I ordered was pretty good, the noodles tasted fresh and not overcooked and it had 5 pieces of beef with some vegetables.  The table next to me ordered up a storm.  I think they had the pork kidney, beef with scallion and sauteed spinach.  Four dishes for 2 people, although they did bag the leftovers.
author: Jim J.

description:
My boyfriend and I are regulars here.  The main complaint (hardly one) I have about this place is that it's closed on Tuesdays.  And for whatever reason, Tuesdays are days I often crave their food.

My favorite dishes in no order:
- turnip and rib soup
- xian fan tuan / salty rice roll
- beef noodle soup
- pork chop over rice

And they have the paper covered yogurt drink. And fresh watermelon juice. :d

Getting the check/checking out can be slow, hence minus a star. But the food is always out in a timely manner.
author: Diana C.

description:
What exactly is Taiwanese food?  Cantonese = dim sum, cha siu, etc.  Shanghai = xiao long bao.  Taiwanese = stinky tofu??  My bf & I were on Clement looking for a place to eat at, and just decided on coming here.  

What to get??  I felt like I should of stuck with going to a Cantonese restaurant or Shanghai.  The menu looked very mixed; I even saw kimchee & udon noodles on the menu!  I was tempted to get the braised beef noodle that people have been raving about; but was worried if I wouldn't like it; it sounds almost beef stew like & I usually don't order stew or big thick pieces of beef.  We ordered an order of the Chinese donut, fried minced pork noodles (me), and fried chicken bento (him).  Chinese donut...can't really mess it up; it was fine..greasy fried goodness!  The noodles were reminsicent of the minced pork and cucumber noodles that I get at Shanghai restaurants like Shanghai Dumpling in Millbrae, but it's better there.  At Formosa there was some unidentifiable object that looked like tofu..or..kinda like pig's blood that I would see at Dim Sum restaurants...eww yeah I hope it was tofu.  My bf didn't really like his fried chicken, as it wasn't very crispy, the portion was kind of small, and some pieces were tough.  He also didn't care for the bento tea egg or veggies.  I know that we probably didn't go with authentic Taiwanese cuisine, but for shame!!

On the plus side, on the way out...I managed to grab a Watermelon Jolly Rancher & one of those hard circular strawberry candies with the gooey center; I haven't had both of those in a hot minute!  No...I don't go to Chinese restaurants for the candy, but I definitely grab me a couple on the way out in the candy basket!  --Two stars for that and the nice decor, that's all.
author: Cat C.

description:
Wow! So much fun, the menu is so different and a ton of fun if you're looking for something different. I went there for lunch and my eyes crossed trying to figure what was going to be lunch for the day. So yes the onion pancake was out of this world... Ahhh but the pig ears were so much fun! And the pork belly was very nice. I would have gone Andrew Zimmerman style and had the pork intestines, but it was a matter of physics at that point, big eyes and limited stomach space :) 

Besides that, I saw so so reviews on the wait staff, but let me tell you the girl that served us was adorable and very attentive I would totally give the place a go for something different... And now back to sushi ;)
author: patti k.

description: One of the few places in SF i can find authentic taiwanese dishes like stinky tofu, green scallion pancake and minced pork over rice! Love it here!
author: J D.

description:
I went there Saturday with a friend and we had such yummy noodles I had to make sure I went back again Sunday.

Saturday I had the preserved vegetables with pork noodle soup.  My friend had the beef in satay sauce over noodles.  We shared the jelly fish.   All very delicious.   It was a little expensive for 2 noodles and an appetizer, plus tip it was about $33.

Sunday, my adventurous sister and I went and we had the following: 

*oyster crepe- very tasty and oyster was very fresh!
*deep fried pork intestine- DELICIOUS!!!!
*braised beef noodle soup- broth in the beef noodle soup was delicious!!!!   there was just 4 slices of dollar size 1/2" thick medallions of what appeared to be beef shank - I think they can be a little more generous with their beef.   
*marinated duck tongue- soso.  not particularly tasty but I just do like the duck tongue.
*the shredded chicken with cold bean noodles-the chicken shreds were very tough, tasteless, and chewy.  The noodles were a little too al dente... also chewy.    sauce was tasty and I liked the cucumbers.
*sweet soy milk- yummy. 

For the most part, everything tasted very good.  The service started with who i think is the unfriendly, unsmiley owner.  But ended with the same friendly waitress as Saturday.
author: Regi K.

description:
This place is very large, though you won't notice walking through the doors.  There's only about 5 tables on the first floor, but tons of space on the second floor.  My friend and I sat on the first floor.

The waitresses were very attentive and our tea cups were filled so many times that I never went thirsty.  We tried one soup, one appetizer, and two snacks and they tasted so unique to me (never tasted Taiwanese food before).  The sticky rice packed like a sausage in a sausage casing was interesting and not too different tasting from those sticky rice wrapped in bamboo leaves, but without the chinese sausage in it.  We also had a oyster omelet dish which was very odd in that it had a very gooey film on the top which puzzled me, and there wasn't much oyster in it.  If it weren't for the red sauce on top of it, the gooey film might have been too much of a turn off for me.  

The portions were small since we did not order real entrees, but we intended not to overeat since we wanted asian desserts the next few blocks down afterwards.  Overall, the bill came out to be about $26.  I would love to come back here to try more of the unique goodies.
author: Mel L.

description:
Came in here with my boy after a day of Man Work on our bikes.  Two guys sharing noodles and dumplings.  I guess at first its hard for me to take this place seriously since I've been here when it was 2 other restaurants, including a shanghai spot that I once loved and had to see it shut down.  Now this Taiwanese joint comes in and just doesn't show me what it's all about.  The flavors were ok, and the food decent.  I admit I'm no Taiwanese cuisine expert at all, but I had a feeling it would be better.  If other mediocre Chinese restaurants taste better than this, something is just not right.  It just seems to me this might be a place that serves authentic Taiwanese people and just offer a homey meal for those away from home.  But I'm not one of those and so this is just another mediocre spot for me.

-Scallion Pancakes - Kind of thick and tasteless
-Taiwanese Fried Rice Noodle - Perhaps the favorite of the dishes, but not a big win
-Braised Beef Noodles - seemed very similar to the tossed noodles at the regular chinese places.....hint: give more beef
-Taiwanese Dumplings - These were ridiculously huge, but I guess it was worth it after seeing the size of that thing come out.
author: Vincent K.

description:
The food is OK. The reason to give two starts is because of the terrible services. 
The waitress was icy cold....
No greeting except: "Hello, how many?" or "Pick wherever you want to sit." or "Are you ready?" No smile at all! She looked like she was forever mad!! But I wanted yelp:" Please tied your hair! That's not professional!" 
When she served, she simply put the dishes on the table w/o asking whose order it was or telling what the dishes were. When we tried to ask, she already turned her back. It took less than one second. So if you are new for Taiwanese foods like me, be aware of it.
Also, she disappeared for a long time. After we finished, we had to wait for a long time to get a waitress (But that was a good one, a nice girl with brown hair. I wished I had her at the beginning).
author: Lala B.

description:
Excellent beef noodle soup (niu rou mian)!  The noodles had the same texture as the kind my grandma used to make and the broth had wonderful flavor.  I also had the sliced beef tendon but it was cut a little on the thick side.  (I prefer the version at Spices 2).   The scallion pancake and the chinese donuts are yummy, too.  

The service is good and the staff works really hard, especially since they have to carry the food up to the 2nd floor dining room!
author: Eddie L.

description:
definitely acceptable for taiwanese food as it is sooo difficult to find authentic taiwanese food in the bay area (who knew?!)  it appeals more to the young crowd with minimalist decor...service was not bad, though they kind of left us alone after the food came out...food tasted like taiwanese food, but obviously not the best taiwanese food you would find in taiwan, but good enough for me...as much as i LOVE stinky tofu though, i don't think i'll order it here 'cuz it just didn't taste right, like it was fermented too long and tasted sour...i was also disappointed that they didn't serve boba, but can't have everything...

our group of 4 girls definitely ordered too much food 'cuz we were so excited to have taiwanese food:
stinky tofu (not good enough)
beef noodle soup (pretty good)
oyster pancakes (large oysters)
meatball (good, generic)
mah-po tofu (delicious)
popcorn chicken (ok, small serving)
~something else i can't remember

anyway, i would recommend this place for anyone, whether you've never had taiwanese food, or if you grew up and lived in taiwan all your life (just don't expect the 100% awesomeness of street food)
author: Irene R.

description: 3 cups chicken & green onion pancakes are good !! The reason why I like this place is because they have good service & traditional Taiwanese food !! Parking is a big problem and it's hard to find a parking !!
author: Anita J.

description:
Good place to fulfill your taiwanese food cravings 

Nothing special or absolutely great though

Still prefer brunch at China Bee in San Mateo
author: Charles C.

description:
Why there is so limited Taiwanese place in Bay Area?  Anyway, enough complaining, let's focus on my review.

This place is like a 3.5 stars for me. These are the dishes that I have:
Fried "chicken nuggets" - Good, love the fried basil what comes with the dish. It is a bit pricey for the portion, but at long as it tastes good, I am willing to pay =)
Braised Ground Pork over rice - very flavorful and rich rice dishes and great bargain too. One of the must have.
Oyster fried egg... hmmm..... not so much. First of all, the oyster wasn't that fresh tasting. And also, it wasn't mixed properly. Oyster was all on one side, while egg misture on other. Maybe I should fold it over like an omelet.  Just a thought  :p

Parking of course on clement street can be a pain, but they have an hour validation on the nearby parking lot. Guess I might come back to try out more dishes next time.
author: Prascilla L.

description:
My friend and I were determined to find the best beef stew noodles in the bay area. Our quest has been... extremely disappointing so far. 

Granted, I really don't expect to find very great Taiwanese food in SF, but throw us a bone here! I think the chefs and the owner were speaking in Cantonese, first off. Hmm... good sign.

Anyway, we decided to go with the green onion pancake (the best part of our meal), the zha cai shredded pork noodle soup and the beef stew noodles.
