The green onion pancake was good. Really good, extra fried and crispy on the outside and really doughy on the inside. $6 seems a bit unreasonable to me for green onion pancake, but whatever. 

Other reviewers were right; the beef stew noodles has the taste of satay in. I'm not trying to eat hot pot here, I just want beef stew noodles! On top of that, they only forked over 2 pieces of tendon meat.. definitely not getting the bang for your buck.

My zha cai shredded pork noodles were okay. Really spicy, which was kind of weird, I've never had them spicy before. The soup was a bit watery, but other than that they were okay. 

The total came out to ~27-28?
Probably wouldn't come back.
author: stacy c.

description:
Pretty good Taiwanese food, considering there aren't that many options in the city.

Stinky tofu, braised beef, beef noodle soup, string beans, pancakes, black sauce noodles. Everything laced was with fat, oil and MSG, but what isn't, it's Asian food.

We had a feast for only two people, but the size of the dishes for the prices and "quality" of food were a little on the high side. Bring your $$ to $ and I will definitely be here more often.
author: Jimmy N.

description: some of the dishes here are ok.  some of these taiwanese dishes arent all that great.  one really good one i always get is the one with the cold tofu with duck egg.  their pork rice cake is pretty good, one of the best i've tried.
author: Karen L.

description:
Very authentic Taiwanese food. The stinky tofu was about as legitimate as I've ever found in the States, about as good as the best Taiwanese restaurants in Southern California. The Taiwanese pan-fried rice noodles, marinated meat over rice, and beef noodle soup are all very homey and tasty. I've only tried the more traditional, home-style Taiwanese dishes, but they're all highly recommended!

The only problem we encountered with the food was when we asked for the classic oyster omelette -- they didn't have any oysters and instead suggested a shrimp omelette. Um, WHAT? What kind of Taiwanese oyster omelette doesn't have oyster in it?! 

Also, I do wish the staff was less awkward about all the staring they do. Whenever I go, it's not very crowded, so the restaurant staff kind of sits around the dining area and stares at us. Totally weird.
author: An L.

description:
Food:  We had the "Water cooked Beef", "Five intestine" and the "Egg with Turnip". I enjoyed the dishes, but felt that the egg dish was lacking quite a bit of the turnip. It felt as it was more of a egg with green onions.  2 Stars (lost an extra star for egg with turnip dish).

Service: The service was reasonable. They weren't proactive but were responsive when asked for water, tea or extra rice.   4 Stars

Overall: 3 stars. The food overall isnt bad, but I guess it really depends on what you order. The staff were responsive. Although interestingly, it is suppose to be a Taiwanese restaurants but all the staff speak Cantonese.
author: Jason H.

description:
All the dishes I tried were good. The price is about the same as similar places in the Bay Area. Bathroom was decently clean and stocked.

The waiter was not pushy and did not try to make us leave.
author: Thomas S.

description: Very QQ! Someone in my party claimed that stinky tofu is made from horse poop, but I think she might have been drunk. Anyway, all the authentic Taiwanese dishes were on point and hit the spot :P
author: Calvin W.

description:
I have come here twice and have been disappointed both times.  Are all of the good Taiwanese restaurants in the south bay?

I can't remember everything I've ordered here, but I know that I was pretty sad about the beef noodle soup.  Sad enough to give up my search for niu rou mian in SF and just learn to make a good bowl at home!

I would give it two stars, but I'll give it three just in case I ordered all the wrong things.
author: Carol L.

description:
I eat here about twice a month but always forget to write a review.  I guess its like the mother or wife you take for granted.  They offer great Taiwanese food and fast delivery.  

My usual items are the egg jook with pork, and fried onion cake with a fried egg on top.  Best in the city BY FAR!  Other good items include, Chow lein gow (sorry, dont know how to translate), pickles and pork noodle soup, and the egg plant.  

Best delivered chinese food by far.
author: dion c.

description:
I happened to be up in SF for the Taiwanese-American Cultural Festival on this fine spring afternoon, where it was actually warm in San Francisco!  Can you believe that?

So I got to the festival about an hour before it ended, and all of the concession stands were pretty much out of food.  Luckily, I had my friend Queena H. with me, so aside from being local to San Francisco, she is also a foodie, and wanted to try out a Taiwanese restaurant that she knew about in the Richmond district.

Reading through the reviews on Yelp, we both thought it would be pretty decent, and ventured forth.  Maybe it was a lot better because I still had the awful taste of Sunrise Restaurant in Sunnyvale in mind from the day before... 

So some of the reviews in Yelp said that they had tiny dishes, so we decided to order 5 dishes.  Maybe they listen to the complaints on Yelp because these dishes were definitely not small, and ordering 5 dishes for 2 people was way too much.  Our first indication of this was when they moved another small table next to ours in order to accommodate all the dishes.

So upon reading the reviews, I went in with the mindset that the food would be pretty similar to what I would expect from Taiwan, and they did not fail to disappoint.

The Taiwan Mi-fen (thin rice noodles) was definitely flavorful and very similar to what I remember having when I was in Taipei.  It was flavorful enough that I didn't have to add any white pepper into it.

The Tsong You Bing (onion pancake) was a bit different from what I am used to, but still pretty good.  It was sweeter than what I am accustomed to (it's usually salty, and more reminiscent of the Korean pajun) since it was a golden-brown crust versus the whitish color I am used to. 

We also got a dish with green beans and ground beef in it (sorry, forgot the name), that was really good.  The string beans were definitely crunchy, and the ground beef and tiny shrimp in it definitely added to the flavor.

The mapo tofu was just like any other mabo tofu I have had.  It wasn't bad, but it wasn't anything special to me either.

Finally, there was the Yen Su Ji (fried chicken nuggets).  This was really good too.  Of course, you can also get some pretty good ones at places like Tapioca Express or other Pearl tea establishments, and it is more of a snack item than it is a dish for dinner, we just had to try it, and it was definitely a very good choice.

We washed everything down with some Taiwan Beer, and it still has this fruity aftertaste that I am used to now.  

-1 star for service.  Our waitress didn't seem to like us being there, and didn't seem to be comfortable speaking in English, so we had to switch to Chinese.  She was not very friendly, and everything seemed to be thrown onto the table, and then she left.  Well... at least that part was an authentic Taiwanese experience.

As for the ambiance of the place, it was well decorated, and very pleasant.  It had more of a modern flair to it, and was nicely done.  It did feel a bit like Q-cup or Tapioca Express with the LCD TV playing Chinese karaoke videos, but it was still very nicely done.

So were there any funny or interesting stories while there? Nothing really, but I did find it odd that my friend, who is a "wai shen ren" (Taiwanese, but came from China after the KMT), didn't realize that Tsingtao is a Chinese beer, and NOT a Taiwanese beer, and also didn't realize that Tsingtao beer refers to Tsingtao, China, of where it is brewed.
author: Michael C.

description:
Went back for beef noodles, stinky tofu, and rice with pork sauce for two people.  Total was around $21 and this time, the food tasted better.  I suppose the items we ordered this time were their better dishes.  

The noodles were chewy.  The soup was heavier on the satay sauce, but not overwhelmingly so.  The tofu was nice!  Not stinky enough, I think.  The rice, I was told, was very oily, like it should be.  

Much better!
author: Mrs F.

description:
Better than average Chinese place.  Not a hole-in-the-wall.  
The upstairs dining area is clean and well lit with a cool high ceiling.
The menu has all the items you'd expect and then a whole list of snacks and appetizers that I guess are common with Taiwanese food.
Fried pancake looking things, one called beef pie and other fried egg and dough pancakes.
Super good shrimp and chive dumplings.
And my Ma Po Tofu was very good.  Spicy and large.
One weird thing is it seemed that most of the dishes on our table were chipped on their edges.  Just an odd observation, not a negative.
And they play a DVDs of some Asian singer in front of an enormous crowd of glow stick waving fans.
author: Kev M.

description:
If there's one thing I'm good at, it is being a third wheel. I went to the Yelp Prom (http://www.yelp.com/events/oakland-enchantment-by-the-sea-prom-to-benefit-hands-on-bay-area) with Kerrie and her 1HMF and I was being a complete darling by taking lots of pictures of them together, urging them to dance, and most importantly, leaving them alone when they wanted to make out. I'm good at picking out cues they gave out when they're trying to tell me to get lost.

I'm kidding. They're nice people. 1HMF was so nice that when we went to Taste of Formosa for dinner before the prom, he paid for everything.

Taste of Formosa is a Taiwanese restaurant that's apparently a rarity in SF. I don't know if it's authentic or not because I've only been to Taiwan once and the last Taiwanese restaurant I went to was in Singapore.

So we just picked some snack items that sounded good. 1HMF recommended the green onion pancake because according to him, Ed to the M swears by it. And who am I to question the great Ed to the M, the ultimate chink? So we got that, chive pocket, sticky rice with pork, crepe with oyster, and deep fried squid.

The green onion pancake was pretty good. Not something I'd swear by though *ducks rocks thrown by Ed's fans*. The crepe was a little weird. It looked like egg foo yung and tasted like gluten. I think I like the sticky rice and the calamari the best. The chive pocket was okay. I think it gave me bad breath for the rest of the night. Those of you who talked to me at the prom, I'm sorry if my breath offended you.

Five snack plates were actually pretty fulfilling. No need to get full plates, and you get to taste a variety of dishes for reasonable price. I think the bill came to about $30 for everything. Service was fine, a little slow in the beginning, but nothing majorly irritating. 

Overall, that dinner was a nice opening for the prom night. Thanks, Kerrie and 1HMF, you guys are awesome. Next time just tell me directly if you guys want some room to make out and I'll go away.
author: Ari C.

description:
i love it here!!
good food, good service!! i love the green onion pancakes and dumplings here. i also loved the seafood kimchi noodle soup, spicy and tasty. ithe broth was just right, if i had to say...probably the best kimchi noodle soup i have ever had. =)
author: Stella J.

description:
This is great, because what I really needed in my life was more fried foods. 

Damn you and your "green onion pancake"!!
author: Megan W.

description:
I dragged my boyfriend here because we only live a few blocks away and I badgered him into picking a restaurant that neither of us had been to. He was originally in the mood for Thai food, but I guess the power of persuasion (or just him not wanting to hear me whine) led us to this little place.

The waitresses were super friendly and nice. We were the only people sitting downstairs, and the service was great. I ordered the won ton soup, which wasn't as good as my grandma's (but hey, no one can beat my grandma's won tons), he ordered the chicken curry (and made the special request to have it extra spicy) and we split the potstickers.

I'm excited to go back and try more of the things on their menu, which is really freaking huge (not like, a big sheet of paper ..whatever).
author: Tori S.

description:
I am very proud to have a restaurant like this on my street.  I got italian, meditterenean, indian, japanese, chinese, soul food, mexican, vietnamese.........I got it all.  Damn.............I am lucky!!!   

I've been here before a couple of times and I really didn't like it that much.   I like neigborhood businesses.........so I am willing to give it another chance. Came here again tonight because a friend told me this was a great place for hot pot.  He was telling the truth.   They actually do have an awesome spicy broth at this restaurant and they aren't afraid to spice it up.  Taiwanese people like it spicy and I do too.   I think we ordered everything.

tripe is very fresh

fish ball......just like the taiwanese like it.........fresh

beef .......was a little frozen.......but it tasted like butter

vegetables.........a little bitter but good

tofu is very good

there fried pancake is by far the best in the city.

They actually have Taiwanese beer here!!!  i never knew there was a Taiwan beer..............but they had it here.  The owner was very nice and welcoming.  Sometimes...........that's all it takes.  Pretend to want my business and I am sold.  They gave us a free dessert............red bean pancakes.  It was very good.........maybe it was free..........or did it tasted that good???  It was good!  Will come back again!!!!
author: jason g.

description:
I wish I could give 3.5 stars, but I can't.

Being Taiwanese in the city, it's difficult to find authentic .tw food. This place is probably the best in the city (someone prove me wrong), but that's not saying it's very good. 

The prices are expensive (ever been to LA for .tw cuisine? You'll know what I mean), and while the food is tasty, the portions aren't enormous like they should be.

The pork chop rice needs a little more work (pork chop was too salty), the green onion pancake could use an egg, but all in all, if I need .tw food, I'll come here.
author: Jason C.

description:
Yelpers did not disappoint.  The green onion pancakes here are unlike any other I've ever had.  They're hearty enough to be its own meal: crisped to perfection on the outside, chewy on the inside with visible scallions.  But the wait for food forced me to dock a star.  

Rarely am I given something to drink while I wait for take-out, much less eat.  I thought it was such a warm, hospitable gesture to be given hot tea and salted peanuts.  I later realized that they do it to stave off your hunger while they take their sweet little time to cook your food.  I was told it would take five minutes.   Twenty minutes later, and fully aware of my antsiness, the lady gave another ETA of three minutes.  

Three minutes came and went.  

When I finally got my order, I was tempted to forget the amount of time of my life I just wasted away from waiting; it was that good.  Too bad I was already full off the nuts and tea that I couldn't bare finishing it.

To their credit, the staff was apologetic, the interior was well-kept, and their To Go box was cute enough that I wanted to wrap it up as a present.

EDIT 12/19/06:  I've been back several times since (dining in), and though the service was a lot better, my current rating still stands.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
We ate at Taste of Formosa. My parents are from Tainan, and they found the food to be very authentic, with most of the typical Taiwanese dishes from their childhood. The service was excellent, and the mongolian beef was very good, the oyster pancake was good (but ask for the sauce on the side). the steamed rice in a tube was very authentic. We also loved the fresh soybean and the fresh watermelon drink. The desserts were very good too. We are going back!

Taste of Formosa also offers free 1 hour parking 1 block away. Highly recommended!
author: Margaret L.

description:
There is a lack of good, authentic Taiwanese food north of LA.  Taste of Formosa is one of the better ones, and more authentic in taste compare to some in the Bay Area.  I'd give it 3.5 stars but they deliver and the restaurant is very clean so I decide to round up the stars.

Dishes that always bring us back:
Scallion pancake is definitely outstanding, here they make it close to the style of hand-grab pancake (soh-juah bin).  As is Taiwanese Style Dumpling (ba-wan), very yummy.  Not sure why it's translated as dumpling, it is more of a giant meat pocket.  
We always get Pork with Vegetable soup with added rice noodle, not too greasy and it tastes better than the Southland Taste in Cupertino.
Clams with basils reminds me of little seafood restaurants along the coast of Taiwan and it is tasty.  Braised brown pork over rice, boy do I feel like I was back in Taiwan eating those tasty boxed lunch they serve on the train or in fast food restaurant.  Quite authentic.

Dishes that are not too bad, but you could definitely find at other restaurants that do it much better within 50 miles radius are:
Taste of Formosa's Spicy Wonton is good but I like the sauce from Joy in Foster City.
I also love pork kidney and am grateful they actually have it on the menu, but the slices are few and it should be considered an appetizer rather than charging the price of a main dish.  So far, only Happy Cafe, Little Shanghai in San Mateo and Hong Fu in Cupertino have better and more delectable pork kidneys.
Braised Beef noodle soup is good with a solid soup base and the noodles are ok.  I like the one at Grace Garden in Burlingame.
The cold dishes overall not bad, but nothing too unique.

I love the taste of these dishes but unfortunately these were the lower ranked dishes:
The oyster pancake and the oyster vermicelli are very tasty, especially the pancake where they use Taiwanese bak-choy and they are not too heavy on the sauce.  Unfortunately the key ingredient (oysters) didn't taste fresh.  I think they use frozen oyster which is too bad as we live in the bay area, and have access to fresh oysters.

Wish list: stinking tofu, savory stuffed rice ball soup, grilled corn.

Overall, it's a delight to find this place that can somewhat satisfy a craving for Taiwanese night market food, and obviously we've been back several times.
author: MooMoo L.

description:
This place is really terrific.  It could replace Spices as my Clement St. destination for Chinese dishes with hot chili oil.  

We did not get the green onion pancakes, despite the hype.  And I still think this place rocks.  

First of all, there were absolutely zero white people in the place, other than Maya G.  All Chinese, all in groups of four or more, all looking like they were really enjoying the food.  The place was really clean and airy, and the service was very good -- we had a cute & friendly multi-lingual waitress who could speak Cantonese to me, Mandarin to my friend, and English to Maya.  Charming in all three languages, and very able to navigate the menu for us.  Best of all, she didn't dumb it down just because we were new to the place.

From the snacks menu, we ordered the fried tofu, the sliced pork in hot chili oil, and the shrimp and chive dumplings.  We topped it off with turnip & ribs soup, a big pot of fried rice, and shredded pork and tofu.  The dishes were all very strong.  The only weak link was the dumpling, which was not bad so much as uninspired.  They also brought us the pork dumplings, but we didn't get twisted up about it because we would have been just as willing to order that.  

The soup as especially good -- just the right amount of white pepper, and the broth was not at all oily.  The soup even had some fish balls thrown in as a bonus.  

By far the best dish was the pork in hot oil.  It got even better when wrapped the pork around the fried tofu for a particularly genius blend of textures.   We were also really fond of the texture of the tofu in the pork dish.  

We will definitely come here again, even though it's really far (coming from Oakland).  Yet another reason why the Richmond has the best eating in San Francisco.
author: Ben A.

description:
I am told by some that this is an excellent restaurant.  However, I did not enjoy my experience here.   I was not pleased with the waitress when she asked my girlfriend if she could read the menu.  This same waitress who questioned my girlfriend's literacy then screwed up our order and did not bring the one dish I wanted to eat.  I'm sorry but can you HEAR??????

The oyster pancake thingy was slimey and not very tasty.  The Chinese Donut tasted like the coating from a serving of fish and chips minus the fish.  It was so fried that I looked for a defibralator because I thought my arteries were immediately going to clog and my heart was going to stop.  The broccoli was cold and slightly undercooked.  The seafood congee has the consistency of phelgm and tasted like it as well.  

The one menu item I enjoyed was the scallion pancake.  One menu item is not enough to warrant a return trip.
author: Chris I.

description:
OK.  I wasn't that impressed.

Eveyone raved about the green onion pancakes so we just had to order one to try.  However, it wasn't that authentic to be honest.  It's what we usually call the "grab cake" (literal translation).  It's good but nothing to die for.

I was starving so I ordered the pickeled spicy cucumber which is usually served immediately because it's already prepared.  However, in this case, it wasn't even served until 25 minutes after we arrived.  It was quite nice however.

We also ordered the "3 cup chicken" which was flavorful but half of the chicken chunks in there had bones.  And because of the dark color of the dish, it was impossible to see the bones.  Very strange.  I had the squid porridge which was all right.  

Service was poor.  We stood at the door way for at least five minutes and no one greeted us.  I had to walk upstairs (additional seating area)  to find someone who seemed pissed off that I walked in on my own.  We had to flag someone down to take our order.  And after ordering, we waited 25 minutes before the first item showed up.

Parking was a nightmare even on a Wednesday night.

Will not go back again...
author: Yuan W.

description:
When I took my first bite of food here, I instantly had this thought: "I must bring my mother here because this is what she used to cook for us when we were younger." And then  I realized that if I were to ever bring my mother here, I would be subjecting myself to a 30 minute rant about how much money we wasted by paying other people for food that she (my mother) could have just cooked up at home.

Which goes to show you how much of a, um, "thrifty" person my mother is because a bowl of ground pork over rice costs something like $4. Four m-fing dollars!!!!
author: Sylvia C.

description:
First time hitting up Taiwanese food, and absolutely loved it.

For starters, we went won ton soup and I'd have to rank it as the best I've ever had.  Broth was not too heavy, dumplings were full of flavor, and a good amount of lettuce and crispy noodle gave it  a unique personality.  

Entree-wise, I figured the Taiwanese fried rice noodles would be a solid choice and indeed they were.  It was basically a bowl of glass noodles with chicken, onion, cilantro, and mint.  My homegirl, the meat freak, went with spareribs and they were done to perfection.  We both did watermelon juice as the drink and felt it was worth it.  

The restaurant is cleaner and more modern than any of the Chinese or Hong Kong places on Geary, so the only downside I can think of here is parking.  For that, head blocks North on 25th.   You'll find a spot between Lake and El Camino del Mar, I guarantee.
author: John H.

description:
Yay! Delicious Taiwanese food!

We've been looking for a place like this for while.

There are lots of these down in LA but not so much in SF.
author: Gregg T.

description:
I ordered delivery for two at 10:30pm on a lazy sunday night. I got the house 'spicy' sausages (which weren't spicy at all) and the house special cold noodle (which had strips of chicken, a slightly boring dish). 

And yet, it's hard to beat their 30 minute delivery service, and I'm left satisfied with terrible garlic breath and a large bottle of Taiwanese lager (named aptly, 'Tawian Beer') left over. 

BTW, they say they stop delivering at 10:00pm, but they'll take deliveries until later if you live close by. 

I'm definitely ordering again. Next time I might venture some of their stranger dishes that involve pork intestines.
author: Jae K.

description:
Go here if you want quick seating, slow service and oily food.  Nice decor.  Maybe they need some time to get up to speed.  

English needs to be spoken here as well.  Gan!!!
author: D. T.

description:
3.5 STARS

Honestly, a little biased opinion here.  I'm Taiwanese, so tasting flavors that remind of home is always nice...that's the reason for the 1/2 star.
So here's my opinion of this place:

Authentic:  Growing up in Taiwan, I find it hard to find something that's even close. But this place is actually not too bad.  It's either a hit or miss.  The beef noodle soup is pretty good.  So is the chow mi fen.  The appetizers are pretty good too.  The thin sliced pork with garlic and soy sauce paste.

The service is pretty good.  Oh, the best part...THERE IS TAIWAN BEER HERE.  How awesome is that.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
I've always wondered what happen to taiwan point on Irving street. I used to go there all the time with my friend Zenas. We went there so much they knew what we wanted and it was basically a silent order hahaha. But then one day, taiwan point disappeared...I guess just me n Zenas alone couldnt help Taiwan Point survive...but moving along..

Anyways..I've never seen this place or heard about it until recently. But then again I dont really go down to richmond that often. So going inside I was thinking "bubble lounge" restaurant, but to my surprise the menu was filled with almost everything I've had in taiwan. hahaha I thought I had just hit jackpot, I was so happy eating there. 

Maybe its just me and my desire to go to the homeland to dine over and over again..hmmm i'm not sure. Anyways, the cousins and I ordered all sorts of different dishes..not sure how to explain to you um we had the spicy wontons? and tbe chinese donut wrapped in rice, there were the small dishes. I just ordered a porkchop with rice, cause thats waht I always order when i go to these places. 

I really cant wait to go back...not sure why but I think I would be much happier dining here then even Boulevard..and I really like Boulevard too..O yea one more thing...this place isnt pricey...at all!!!!
author: phillip w.

description:
Nice, cheap place in the Richmond that serves authentic Taiwanese food.  Lot's of variety and pretty cheap.  
I tried the Scallion pancakes, oyster sauce pancake, both of which were great.  The noodle soup is really tasty.  Pork is a little chewy.  
Would definitely go back when the hunger strikes.
author: Ilya L.

description:
A Taiwanese friend suggested this place for lunch during my recent SF visit. I'm always down for food from the homeland. As I told him, this place really confused me, but I could see why he in particular wanted to eat there. You go in and there's a second floor, where we were seated. The decor is contemporary and they use real chopsticks and utensils. Kind of like what you might find at a Crate & Barrel or possibly on sale at Ross. We ordered mei fun, won ton soup, tsong yo bing, gwoh tieh and ja jang mien. Hope you can figure out what that was. I thought all the food was good and was surprised. Usually, only good food comes from places where you sit on stools, the chopsticks are bleached, and the tables are plastic. This place provided a nice atmosphere. Nice, but confusing if you're Taiwanese and from Taiwan like me, and are used to the night markets or cockroaches crawling around on the walls. I'm still trying to figure out if it's a good thing or not. Also, the waitresses spoke Mandarin, but really need to learn more English. I'm ashamed I don't know more Mandarin, but when a waitress comes to you asking you how to translate something into English, you know something's wrong. And if this place is Taiwanese and has "Formosa" in their name, they should speak the language of the motherland. 

Would definitely go back, for decent service, good food, confusing atmosphere, but a little pricey for Taiwanese food. OG food should come with OG prices. 

Different friends wanted to go to there for dinner the same night (of all places) and I had to pass.
author: Ming-Jou C.

description:
this taste of formosa place was alright.  and even if i weren't cranky going in, i would have still given it three stars.  we initially hesitated walking in since there was no one inside.  but i quickly checked my mobile yelp and saw 3.5 stars based on 21 reviews.  so i said, it can't be that bad.  so we walked right in.  they said we could sit upstairs instead if we wanted.  so we walked up, and whew, there were actually several other tables full of people up there.

we ordered a bunch of stuff that didn't really leave any kind of impression on me.  neither good nor bad.  well, except for the scallion pancakes.  i requested them since i saw at least a few mentions of them as i scrolled through my mobile yelp.  and it was actually pretty good.  it was basically naan with some scallions mixed into the dough.  but it was good.

and as a note though, when you order the soy milk, just know that each order comes in a coffee mug as opposed to a huge soup bowl.  just so you know what to expect, because we all made "huh??" faces when they put the mugs on our table.

and oh, can't really give them any more than 3 stars since their service was painfully slow.
author: spiff e.

description:
YO, Taiwanese joints are hard to come by in the city. 

The food here is comfort food for Asians.

I dig, I dig.
author: Stanley L.

description:
I came here with my friend last night.  The first thing we ran into was finding parking.  I think we drove around for 20 minutes trying to find a place.  I literally wanted to cry, I mean, I was starving and I couldn't find a spot to park.  This perhaps tainted my impression of the place, but it was part of the experience.  

The staff here is very friendly, and I was happy that we didn't have to wait for a table.  I thought the place was small, but after walking in, I realized they had a 2nd story which I did not go up.

The food is reasonably priced for SF.  For the 4 dishes we ended up ordering, it was about $33.  The Tainam bowl cake was good, although a little fatty in taste for me.  The mapo tofu was the best I've personally had, and had the right amount of spice.  The stir-fried udon was good, but nothing too special.  The garlic basil eggplant was good, and had a nice presentation as it came out in a large wonton bowl of sorts.  

All-in-all, the food was good, but not the best I've had.  If I were to drive to the city for Taiwanese, I think I'd still go over to Spices! a few blocks up the street from here.

The staff was also very friendly about constantly refilling my tea cup, as I apparently was dehydrated.  The one major upside for this establishment is that they accept credit cards (including AMEX).  

Also, the bathroom here is nice; a lot nicer than I was expecting.  :-)

If you're in the area, I would check this place out.  The food is good, and I think I would probably give them 3.5 stars, but I need a little something extra (perhaps during my next visit) that will prompt me to update this to a 4-star rating.
author: Brent A.

description:
Foods- I would say they are pretty consistent EXCEPT the herbal wine chicken soup. Sometimes it has wine, chicken WITHOUT any herbs that said on the menu....sometimes is hella greasy...is kinda unpredictable...

Services - SUCKS!!! I threw a gathering for a big crowd (more than 20+++)...no discount and their waitress didn't even come to greet us. And then the waitress said to me that "you don't even spend enough money for each person!!"..WTF?????? Forget about it. I am so done with this place. 

I mean DONE!
author: Skylar G.

description:
No good in my hood.  I returned to this place again after not being too pleased with the pork chops like two months ago.  This time around i asked a server what she thought was yummy and agreed to try the braised beef and mixed vegetables.

Mazuiii dayou!  I mean i had to force myself to handle more than three bites of the beef over rice and i was fucking starving.  Perhaps it is my bad for never going there with friends, dining upstairs...you know those places where you gotta eat in and never to go.

Well the saving grace was the veggies- especially the asparagus that were cooked just right--not too crunchy, or mushy..tho a bit too much butter.

I do enjoy taiwanese food but i would rather go to Quickly than here again.
author: omar b.

description:
When I evaluate my experience with restaurants, I always consider the following:
1. Service;
2. Quality of Food;
3. Ambiance, which attributes to dining pleasure

For Taste of Formosa, my every visit has always been:
1. Service: 5
2. Quality of Food: 5
Ambiance: 4 After all, unless this is my own home/business, there's going to be style difference on the decor, right.

I've also had them deliver food, and I noticed they use the high-end, quality paper container (not the cheapy paper painted red, nor plastic containers - when hot food gets in plastic, any kind of plastic regardless of the "safety" claim, it always produces chemical toxins released from the plastic), and the chopsticks they included run smooth on the fingers & are substantial - again says QUALITY & their WILLINGNESS to INVEST in food safety for customers & business presentation.

Most of their dishes are Taiwanese, which has island flares. When you go the next time, try the Mushroom Soup w/ Pork Dumpling (hsiang gu rou geng), or the Taiwanese Bamboo Wrap (rou tsong), or the udong noodle, or the soymilk, which is absolutely delicious & housemade/homemade. The owner, Katie is Taiwanese, mother of 2 cute little ones. One conversation with her about her passion for Formosan food & quality of food will win you over. She speaks quality. If she's ever going to open more restaurants, I'll for sure be a loyal customers.

I could go on & on. To sum up, if you're interested in SERVICE AND QUALITY of FOOD, not the superficial long line on the sidewalk/crowd scene, and you need a restaurant with clean, food safety conscious, trusted kitchen, Taste of Formosa is worth a visit, two visits & more.
I've been going since 2005. They never failed me.
author: M L.

description:
tastewise, this place deserves 3-4 stars. service? not so much. 
imma start with the positives. came with 2 friends, we ordered: bawan, soup, duck tongue, oyster pancake, sticky rice sausage, and stinky tofu. everything was good, the portions were small tho. 
now to knock them on the service: 1. after our first two dishes came out, they moved us to a different table to make room for a bigger group. no biggie, but kind of lame that we had already started to eat and then they came to move us. 2. they gave us the wrong dish (chitterlings) we ate it thinking it was the sticky rice sausge. confused we asked the waiter what it was. realizing their mistake the other waitress came over to ask us if we ate it. we said yes. she told us that since we ate it we have to pay for it. she perfusely apologized, but i felt a bit miffed that their mistake resulted an extra dish on our bill. 3. we ordered stinky tofu, but the waiter forgot to put it on our bill and when we questioned him he told us that we hadn't ordered it. "forgavingly" he added the dish onto our bill. 
although the food was good, i have to say it was very overpriced and the portions were small. not worth it for crappy service (even for an asian restaurant smh).
author: Carol C.

description:
been wanting to try this place for months!
the beef with satay noodle my friends enjoyed, the pancake was average-no mouth orgasm there, the eggplant dish was good (came in a tortilla bowl thingy and the eggplants were cooked well)
author: Miss J.

description:
A nice spot that opens late on a Sunday!  We peeked into the window and there was no one inside, but we did see a glowing "OPEN" sign and a Yelp sticker on the door.  We walked in and there were 4-5 tables downstairs, so they told us to go upstairs.  The building design literally felt like a house converted into a restaurant.   They had a plasma screen tv playing a concert and nice wooden floor.

The food here was greasy.  The onion pancake tasted like grease (mmm).  I ordered the beef noodle soup and it was a bit spicey!!! The Taiwanese wonton was ok, but with a little sauce next to it, made it taste better.  We also ordered a spicey beef appetizer, not bad at all.

Minus a couple stars for the pricey food $6.95+ for each dish there. FYI a minimum of $15 on credit card.  Parking on Clement St. is usually a pain. 

And what does Formosa mean??
author: Elliot Y.

description:
Always passed this place, but never bothered to go in b/c it looked dead, but ohhhhh, what a fun surprise of a place it was!!! 
YUMMY and chill.  Will definitely come back!
author: Mellie P.

description: This review is for their braised pork with rice, or Ru Rou Fan. They really shouldn't c it ru rou fan at all because it's so bad. It was missing the flavor in the rice and the meat. There was also not enough preserved/ pickled veggies in it. The egg they added in was very bland too...
author: Meiling L.

description:
Really tasty taiwanese snacks, but I do have to disagree with some of the other yelpers on certain items.  

Green onion pancake was just OK -- needed more flavor and green onions.  Also, wasn't exactly the authentic version, but I digress.  The beef pies were also not as tasty as I would have liked -- the texture of the meat was a little too loose and tasted like butter, which was really odd.

I really enjoyed the "tainam style bowl cake" (ba wan), the "sticky rice in pork chitterling" (luo mi da tsang), the "braised pork over rice" (lu rou fan), and the "oyster crepe with special sauce" (o wa jian) -- really made me miss the food in taiwan.  And the items were wayyyyy less greasy than what you'd normally find in your taiwanese night market.  This is definitely a place I'd take my very very picky parents when they come visit -- and I think they'd actually enjoy it instead of ranting about how expensive and bad the chinese food in the bay area is...but again, I digress.

I also came to the realization that "Taiwan Beer" is actually pretty good -- who knew?  That deserves an extra star in itself.
author: Mitzi C.

description:
We need more Taiwanese restaurants in SF.  Taiwan restaurant is NOT Taiwanese food and when Taiwan Point closed up shop, I thought I'd have to make trips down to the South Bay for some food from the motherland.  Luckily, some friends told me about Taste of Formosa and we're back in business.  Their braised ground pork over rice (ru ro fan) is just like how my Dad would make it and the o-a mi sua (oyster vermicelli) is just yummy.  I also like the xian fan tuan (salty rice ball/roll).  Their noodle and sauteed dishes are delish too.  The o-a zen (oyster pancake) is a little off for me, which is a shame because that's my favorite dish, but I'm just happy to get some authentic Taiwanese food.

C and I have always have a hard time remembering that they are closed on Tuesdays.  Twice we planned to go, saving up our appetites, and thinking about what we'd order all day, only to be sorely disappointed that the doors were shut and the lights were out.  We almost cried both times.  Waah!
author: Pelle Y.

description:
Authentic Taiwanese food is hard to find in San Francisco.  Besides Spices I&II, there isn't a whole lot going on.  Taste of Formosa makes a good effort.

The food is very good and authentic!  The staff is very nice!  Everything was great, EXCEPT...they have by far the strangest sign outside.  Some waiter guy and the lettering is so hard to read I am not surprised anybody misses this place.  Place is also cold

But it;s worth the trek to outter Richmond!
author: Sir Paul L.

description: I honestly don't know what formosa is, but it tasted pretty decent to me.  I got chicken and vegetables and my sis got some soup recommended by the server.  It had a tiny bit of a spicy kick to it.  Both were really decent.  The prices weren't too bad either.  I think I paid just under twenty bucks for two dishes.  Pretty good if you ask me.
author: Amy J.

description:
The best.. hmmm..
The scallion pancakes - slightly above average..
Beef Noodle soup - decent but the beef was not soft and moist and tasty. Queens house is way better in Mountain View.. although the oil will kill you.
The service so so .. very comparable to the service you get in Taiwan. 
So in general nice place to eat at..  but not  the best. 
If you are around the area.. i would see its good enough to eat at!
author: Kaio T.

description:
The owners are taiwanese from the eastern side of the island.

The food they cook up is fairly authentic with a slight nouveau presentation. I like hot soups and the little dishes above
everything else.

We typically do take out - once per week on the average.
author: Edward T.

description:
Wow, this place is pretty damn good.  I had the spicy wontons (hong you chao shou), beef noodle soup, and eggplants w/ basil.  I was thoroughly impressed with all three dishes.  Rich in flavor, spicy, not too oily, and not too bland.

Apparently the green onion pancakes are pretty good too.  I'll have to try that next time I go (which will be very soon).

It's definitely worth the trip to the outer richmond if you're craving taiwanese style chinese food.
author: Brandon C.

description:
Out of 5 Stars
Taste: ****
Service: ****
Cleanliness: ****
Value: ***

Will I go back? Yes

I am Taiwanese and have been looking for a authentic Taiwanese restaurant in the Bay Area for a while.  There used to be a place called Taiwan Point on Irvine, but that's gone a few years back and I had no place to go.  The two Taiwanese restaurants in the 99 Ranch Plazas in Cupertino and Milpitas are not good.  So I was really happy to find this place a few weeks back.

The Taiwanese cuisine (snack size plates) is quite authentic.  The place is clean.  I was worried about the service since I did read other reviewer mention about bad service, but that was not the case for me.  Maybe I am lucky.

Check it out.  One of the better Taiwnese restaurants in the Bay Area!
author: Peter W.

description:
It's really hard to rate this place because it's not always consistent. I guess it gets a lower rating b/c of that but it wasn't too bad so I won't be too harsh.
If this was the first and only place that I've eaten Taiwanese food, I wouldn't be too sure if I liked it.  The food was just not cutting it for me.  It looked like the waitresses just went back to make the food and brought it out for you.  Maybe the cooks are the waitresses, who knows. 
 I've been there about a handful of times and each time, i come away thinking something different.  First time, "YUCK!" second time, "it was okay." Third time, "EWW!" Fourth time, "meh"...and then i either stopped going or stopped caring...or both
author: Tu L.

description:
This place is okay. Nothing special that stood out. The place/interior/environment is nice though. But the food was, once again, just okay. The portions were on the small side relative to the price, and almost everyone had to grab something to eat afterwards. The waitresses there (when we went there) looked more like models with their fake (but very shiny and plastic-y) nails. I was afraid that one of the nails would drop into our food.

Parking is always a problem around that area around dinner time. I would not come back on my own volition.
author: Sam W.

description:
I have been here multiple times in the past but today was totally different. In the past I would have given 3 stars for the food, -1 for the price, and 4 for the ambiance. After today, it will be a definite one, because nothing is worth eating spoiled food.

I am warning people about their preserved cabbage and pork noodle soup. Today it came out with a funny smell and the preserved cabbage was obviously spoiled. We told the server (who was really rude and already had forgotten our order once and gave it to the next table) completely pretended like it was not. But the other people on my table also felt the same. I asked her to take it and ask the chef, she looked at me like I was crazy and once again said it is fine. So we paid and left, well they definitely lost a customer.
author: Ce Y.

description: "smell tofu" -- yes it permeates here.  came for some dumplings, scallion pancake, got the spicy fish fillet, done fine with soft fillets, lots of spinach, some sichuan peppercorns and lots of red chili and red peppers.  the scallion pancake was very crispy on the outside and thicker than average but not doughy on the inside, lots of scallions, good savory flavor.  dumplings small, wrapper packed tight.
author: Rob C.

description:
Finally, a SF institution that is reasonably priced and authentic!  I was born in Taiwan, so I'm a little familiar with what Taiwanese food should be even though I came to the States at a very young age.  This also makes me quite the adventurous eater.  Let me follow that by saying the Large Intestine Stuffed with Sticky Rice is really good here!  The dipping sauce was nice and garlicky while the large intestine itself had a slight crisp and didn't taste at all like what you would think large intestine should taste.  The Tainan Glutinous Bowl Rice was also pungent with garlic, but still needed a little more depth of flavor.  I would also not recommend the Green Onion Pancake topped with Egg unless you like the thick, doughy sort.  Personally, I like my Green Onion Pancake thin, crisp, and not too oily which this establishment failed to offer.  Also ordered was General Tsao's Chicken, which was just average.  

The menu is diverse with many options, so I'll definitely come back and try other dishes when I'm feeling homesick.
author: Tina F.

description:
If I were rating their green onion pancake, it would have gotten 4 stars.  But since I cam here with my family and spent $40 for lunch, we ordered many other items.  
Potstickers were bad.  Honestly, the ones at Costco are better.
The black bean noodles were ok.
Beef noodle soup was ok as well.
Also had the rice cake.  This dish was a little better than the noodle dishes but like all the dishes, it looked like it was a kid's portion.  

This restaurant is definitely over-priced for their food.  My first and last trip here.
author: Will I A m.

description:
This is my all time favorite restaurant when I'm in the inner Richmond area!  I always order the same two things (and I'm still not sick of it!): 

1.  Braised pork over rice
2.  Dry Sauteed String Beans

Their Scallion pancakes are pretty good too!  Just make sure to ask for the chili soysauce that comes with potstickers because it goes really well with the scallion pancakes.  To top it off, this place deliversss!! Just try to remember that the restaurant is closed on Tuesdays.  I highly recommend this place!
author: Siu L.

description: Very clean place. Dish style is more ordinary home cooking, nothing too fancy to replicate at home, but several dishes are pretty good, like the stinky tofu, and the Kimchi fried tofu.
author: Shirley W.

description:
Tasty Taiwanese style food. The entrees here taste better than the street style foods which are overpriced. Which is too bad as Taiwanese food is very hard to find in San Francisco (and even the Bay Area compared to Monterey Park/San Gabriel Valley in Los Angeles). 

My favorite dishes there are the dry sauteed beef and the Hakka style stir fry. Wish their prices were either cheaper or they gave you full-sized entrees. Also charge steam rice by the bowl. They also play KTV or music videos on the flat screen (which I do not mind since I listen to Chinese music myself). 

Overall, decent place if you are hankering for Taiwanese food. They also have cute to-go containers, reminescent of Taiwan itself. As in all restaurants, some dishes are consistently good while some (like the braised beef over rice) are hit and miss.
author: Empress C.

description:
Good Food! We went there on Sunday.. food is excellent.. very Taiwan like!!!

Will definitely go back again!
author: Michy C.

description:
So came here with my boyfriend yesterday night, and he was really iffy about coming here but I finally forced him to give this place a try. Not bad. We ordered the braised beef noodle soup - which I would love it more if it was SPICIER! I also got the beef tripe - which is spicy enough and it taste good with my noodle soup. I guess I used the beef tripe to make the noodle spicier =). We also ordered the ground pork over rice. Lastly, my boyfriend ordered this mini hot pot with tofu, pork intestines, which also included pork blood and it was quite spicy. 

I like how it is really clean upstairs and felt really comfortable. Parking was a bit hard to find but luckily it was just right after 8PM so we parked at the bus stop. 

I will definitely come back again and try more stuffs!
author: Willa L.

description:
Being a whitey, I must say I wouldn't have any idea how good this place is if it weren't for my best pal from Taiwan.  That being said, I know it is good and I know I am not the only one who feels that way.  

Formosa is solid.  I am hooked on the chive pocket.  Try it and you may be too.  

chives shrimp dumplings - you had me at hello
beef noodle soup - you had me at hello
house special cold noodle - you had me at hello
beef with green onion - you had me at hello
seafood kimchee noodle soup - I've loved you since we first met
pig ears - (norcal vegans look away)
mustard green w/ shredded pork fried rice cake - I cherish the ground you walk upon.

The menu is eclectic and diverse.  I love picking new items randomly- they are never what I expect them to be and usually a nice surprise.  

If you don't speak mandarin and are ordering by phone, have a menu handy and just read the numbers, that's how this dummy does it...
author: chris o.

description:
Their scallion pancake was really soggy this time.  There was so much oil that it felt like I already had on chapstick or lip balm after eating just one bite.  

The sesame chicken soup was FILLED with small, broken pieces of bones from the chicken.  As much as I love food cooked on the bone because it lends more flavor to the dish, I could not take a sip of that soup without pulling out bits of bone out of my mouth.  No thanks.  I can't exactly chit chat with old friends when I'm too busy picking bones from my mouth.  

Chinese Chicken salad.... Why would I order that?  Seriously?  I'm Chinese, and hello?  Chinese people don't eat salad, so there was NO way this was going to be good.  So heavy and over dressed with peanut sauce that was a little too reminiscent of peanut butter.  

All I know is that I had the really bad unsatisfying kind of food coma there.  

Side note: The waitresses all looked the same and strangely like my friend from high school, Flora.  Fobby Asian hair FTW!
author: Anna T.

description:
Okay, here's the thing...

I know NOTHING about Taiwanese food, I have absolutely no reference to what this food is supposed to taste like or if it was prepared properly.  All I know is that everything I shoved in my mouth last night, was delicious.

Seriously, the restaurant was pretty empty, so when we strolled in with our party of eight, and said our reservation, I looked around at the first floor of semi-occupied two and four tops wondering, "How are they going to fit us all in here?".  Then we were taken upstairs, and I was pleasantly surprised. 

We sat down, and having researched the restaurant a little bit, I know some choice dishes I wanted to try, and so we ordered:

1. Scallion pancake with egg *
2. Drunken Chicken
3. Fried Squid Balls 
4. Deep fried pork intestine
5. Beef with hot special sauce 
6. Chicken in rice wine sauce *
7. Shrimp with pineapple *
8. Morning Glory
9. Braised ground pork over rice **** (The whole reason why I went)
10. Whole fish with spicy sauce (not sure what it's called on the menu)
(* are my supa-favorites)

There weren't any hungry people left, and thanks to a combination of the little research I did and an actual Taiwanese person in our party, everyone actually enjoyed every dish.  And including tip it ended up being $16 a person for a whole lotta food.

Our waitress was very helpful, service was great and presentation was beautiful.  Five stars for sure, and will definitely be back.
author: Asha H.

description:
It's OK. That's my overall review of the place. The food is fine, but I feel like it depends on which days you go.

Food-wise, this place is okay. Nothing amazing. I would go back there if I'm craving something. I feel like it's a hit and miss. Some days, they're delicious, other days, not so much. I think I went on an off day. Their sticky rice was good, but the chinese donut was extremely hard. I think I could've chipped a tooth ... being slightly overdramatic, but hey! It's how I felt... The stinky tofu was pretty legit! Most of the good stinky tofu places in SF are closed, so this is a good place to satisfy your craving for those stinky little things. I had the braised pork rice. Nothing too amazing. Granted that I can't compare it to Taiwan, it wasn't anything too good. Just decent. Edible. Their beef noodle soup was okay. There was a hint of sour taste in it, maybe it's just me, but I wasn't too fond of that. Basically, everything was just okay. I'm not crazy for this place, but I will come back.

Last note: always go to the second floor, it is a lot more pleasing than their first floor. The first floor is dark and closed off, whereas their second floor is bright and airy.
author: Bianca W.

description: This place is very good.  Especially for San Francisco.  Also, the fact that they serve Stinky Tofu gives them major cred points in my book.  A big fan of their Numbing-Spicy marinated beef tripe (although my mom's is still the best!).  Zha Zhang Mien is also serviceable.  I go here a lot.  I can't give them 4 stars because I think my standards are too high.  Service is generally good.  Free peanuts with every meal.  You should note there is an upstairs room so if you walk by and the first floor is empty and that seems like a bad sign to you, know that most of the seating isn't viewable from the street.  Great if you go with a big group so you can try more different dishes.  And not too expensive either.
author: Nat L.

description: taiwanese pork chop over rice and clams With Fresh Basil those are pretty aewsome.  the price is knid of expensive, but i sitll go at least twice a month.
author: Jay C.

description:
3.5 stars.

I wandered into this place after the restaurant I was planning on going to turned out to be closed.  I have to admit, I am pretty ignorant when it comes to Taiwanese food, so when it came time to order I picked something pretty much at random.  What I got was a very spicy beef dish with fresh spinach.  It came in a large bowl, with copious amounts of sauce.  For a moment I thought I had ordered a soup, but based on context clues (the patrons who had, in fact, ordered soup had the trademark soup spoons while I did not) I realized that this was not true.  Overall it was a little oily for me and the beef was on the mysterious side.  The sauce had a nice flavor though.  If I end up going back I will keep some of the other reviews in mind in terms of what to order.
author: Richard N.

description: In terms of food, this place is pretty good. Most of the dishes taste pretty authentic and are quite scrumptious. The service is also pretty quick and good, and they're one of the few Taiwanese restaurants in the city that can accommodate a large group on short notice. The only real drawback to this place is the lack of parking in the area. Aside from that, I'd give it a thumbs up!
author: Ty L.

description:
Decent taiwanese food.  I usually get their salty pepper fried chiecken with basil, spicy pig's ear, spicy beef tendon, pork intestine vermicelli.  Stinky tofu is not super, but does the job to warm my stomach since not many places have that in SF.   This is a good place to eat some snacks, drink cold beer, and chill.

Service is just like regular chinese restaurant, not bad, not good.  Parking can be a b***h though because of all the food establishments in the neighborhood.
author: grace C.

description: Came here for a friend's birthday brunch. I forgot what I ordered. I think it was the generic vegetable chow mein. It was generically..good? Nothing too amazing. When you're a vegetarian at a typical Asian restaurant, everything ends up tasting the same to you. Nothing too fancy, good for a quick bite. Very clean restaurant.
author: Tina C.

description:
The best Taiwanese restaurant in a sea of Cantonese eateries (aka Little Hong Kong)

The definition of best- of the highest quality, excellence, or standing

I never thought I would ever find a place that had green onion pancakes that was better than Earthen in LA.  But I was introduced to the BEST green onion pancake and of all places, it was in SF.  It is crispy on the outside and fluffy and airy on the inside.  A piece of deep fried heaven in an anti-carb world.

The rest of the food is decent, price and service is good. Decor is simple and the place is clean.
author: Sun-Kai P.

description:
I've been here twice, and both times I've really enjoyed the food here. The waitress, who has been the same person both times, is really sweet and attentive. Maybe it helps that I can speak Mandarin, but my brother (who doesn't speak that dialect of Chinese) can speak with her just fine in English. This waitress knew Taiwanese, so I don't know what some people are saying about the staff not being true Taiwanese. 

I think my two favorite things here are the niu rou mian (the beef noodle soup) and the cong you bing (scallion pancake). The scallion pancake is quite different from any other one that I've ever had, and I can't really vouch for "authenticity" since I've never been to Taiwan. The beef noodle soup that I had shared twice was super yummy -- a semi-spicy,  beefy broth with al dente noodles and a generous portion of beef. I also liked the pork chop over rice here. 

For things I didn't like so much, the ou ah jian (oyster omelette) was pretty bad, almost scary, so I wouldn't recommend that. My party also had the chicken wings the second time we came here, and they're pretty underwhelming. 

A lot of people complain here that the food is pricier than what Taiwanese food "should be sold at." Frankly, we're not in Taiwan, so you shouldn't expect to find this type of food or any type of food as cheap as it is back there. The cost of living isn't the same. 

 I'm definitely coming back here when I come home. Yum, beef noodle soup and pork chop!
author: Yvonne W.

description: I think the best feature of this restaurant is how clean and modern everything is, from the bathrooms to the 2nd floor.  The food is pretty solid, I had the BBQ Short ribs and stole my friends ma pao, both pretty good.  I can't say I'm a fan of stinky tofu, I still ate it, but let's just say it damn well earned its name and more.  Won't make a trip from campbell or anything, but definitely will be a go-to spot for good taiwanese food when I'm in that area.
author: Hiro K.

description:
Limited exposure, but so far so good.  I'm a sucker for their Basil Eggplant and Braised Pork over rice.

Will update when I inevitably succumb to more items on their menu.

(Psst.  They validate parking.)
author: Teresa K.

description:
My friend had a birthday here. I wasn't expecting too much but i was truly surprised by how well the food was made. Since we had such a big group we had a good chance to sample plenty of the food. Here are some of the dishes that were mouth watering: green onion pancake, beef noodle soup, an eggplant dish, a seafood mix, very fresh fried mackerel, tasty Green tea jello dessert and of course.... the pork ribs...mmmmmmm. The pork ribs were great! It was obviously slow cooked for a long time since the meat just came off the bone.

Service was good and attentive. Parking is a bit of a challenge. I suggest parking 2-3 blocks away from clement- Geary or California

It looks like a small place when you enter BUT they do have a spacious upstairs that's downright fancy.
author: Bert T.

description:
My Taiwanese friend wanted to come here because she was hoping that this place could satisfy her craving for authentic Taiwanese food. When we first got there, we thought the place was packed, but we didn't know there was a larger, more spacious upstairs dining area. 

We ordered a lot of food because my friend was craving everything on the menu. I don't remember everything we ordered, but I enjoyed most of the dishes. I liked the green onion pancake the most. It was light and crispy and tasty -- just the way I like it. The steamed goose meat was a bit tough but still good. The only thing I was disappointed by was the drunken chick (san bei ji). The whole pot was mostly whole cloves of garlic with just a few pieces of chicken. I'm not a big fan of garlic.

My friend was very satisfied with the restaurant. I wasn't as impressed, but it's probably because I'm not a big fan of Taiwanese food in general. (I probably should have told her I wanted to go to the Indian restaurant next door instead... er... next time I guess.)
author: Hue L.

description:
I don't like black napkins.  period.

Other than that, I don't have anything negative to say about this place.  I love their sour cabbage and fish fillet soup.  The description sounds weird at best, but the actual dish is delicious beyond words.  

Everything I have had there has been very good.  And for a Chinese restaurant, it's really clean and spacious.  

I wish we had more Taiwanese restaurants like this in the city.
author: Candice B.

description:
On my quest to find good Taiwanese food, I dragged AK around SF when she visited a year ago. It took me another year to finally review this place. 

This place is small, there are plenty of dishes to order from and it is all the way out in the boones. When we came, we were the only people here so it was a nice leisurely lunch.

I would say this place is so so. Not great, not outstanding and not memorable. I still like Spices better, although nothing beats 66 in Flushing, NY.
author: Sophie C.

description:
I'm from the San Gabriel Valley so moving to San Francisco was like going to rehab and put on a program for Taiwanese food withdrawl. Every encounter with someone with an ounce of Taiwanese background would elicit a violent barrage of me shaking them by their shirt collar, screaming WHERE CAN I GET TAIWANESE FOOD (sometimes wailed in Chinese for effect). A couple people pointed me here as their favorite and while it's expensive for what you get, if you're really craving Taiwanese food in San Francisco, this place is your best bet. 

Very good Green Onion Pancake (tsong you bing) and decent Pork Chop Rice (pai gu fan) with a distinct curry flavor, although pitifully small portions. I've order other stuff, like Oyster and Thin Noodles (O A Mi Sua) and everything is consistently good, but not fabulous. I do feel the Beef Noodle Soup (niu ro mien) isn't worth your while (psht, go to Dim Sum King in Daly City for a good bowl), but overall, the menu should satisfy most of your Taiwanese needs (no bao bing though. Sob.).

Also the people working here are really nice and the service is great, but the place is always kind of empty, which is kind of makes me sad. :( Frown.
author: Kat C.

description:
I've been here half a dozen times, each time in a group so I've tried a variety of dishes at Taste of Formosa. This place has a nicer ambience than your typical Asian restaurant, better service and food presentation- hence the higher price. 
My favorite is the herb type soup they have here  - warms me up from head to toe. Also, the scallion pancake-tasty. Stirfry veggie- flavorful. Fried chicken - yum. Beef noodle soup - excellent. Cold noodle- a treat! and so on... 
I actually like their cute takeout boxes printed with their logo and sign and they have a clean bathroom!
author: T H.

description: Fried chicken check! Oyster meesua check! Hot, Sour soup Check!
author: Meredith C.

description: Everything we ordered tasted pretty good, but it was just too garlicky for me.  We ate there for lunch, and I felt it whole day long.
author: Elena L.

description:
I am in love with this place!  Let me just say.. Taste of Formosa was what I was looking for in the city.  I have been looking all over the city for Taiwanese potstickers and this place has them!  Ok this place isn't the easiest to find.  The only reason I lucked out in finding this place was because AK Subs was a block away!  The parking situation is hellish day and night... the best time to come for dinner is around 7:45pm to snag at the VIP Bus Stop parking spaces.  Ok enough with the foreplay..

I walked in with a party of 4 and was greated nicely by the hostess.  We were seated in the spacious 2nd floor almost immediately after we passed the doors.  We were seated near the windows, which have a nice view of Clement and our cars.  We were offered water and tea and also a menu each.  As we sat down, I noticed the seats were very nice and the table was very sturdy.. not like the ones you find at other Chinese restaurants that seem like motorized bulls.  They even had a Plasma looping Chinese/Taiwanese music videos and concerts!

Everything I ordered here was excellent!  I started with the Honey Green Tea drink(mmMm)  The scallion pancakes(OMG GOOD), the legendary Taiwanese potstickers, the crispy fried TOFU!, and the Savory Rice Roll! just blew me away!!  I mean everything I had on that day was super delicious!  And I was for sure that I wasn't being lulled away by Jay Chou singing on the flat panel TV screen.  The food was really really good.  The only thing to remember is although the price range is moderate $11-30... its very easy to fall within the high $20s/per person on this bill.  Everyone working here was very friendly, the owner even came up to serve us Taiwanese Pork Ball Soup!  She chatted with us about how the service was and how the food was.  I can definately say... this place is 5 stars in my book!

Oh remember to pick up a Take-Out Menu... They deliver in nice packaging!  The delivery guy is my favorite he is smiling rain or shine!
author: Benny S.

description:
This place is in my hood and I hadn't eaten there until my Taiwanese friend suggested it one morning....or actually said, "I'm eating in your hood - get you a$$ outta bed." I'm glad I did. I ate lots of things that I normally would not of ordered but loved them all.

Can you say PORK CHOP RICE!!!! Tender delicious and deep fried....ummmmmm! The soy milk was really good too....yes soy milk!

There is an upstairs and it's decorated real purty....yep gonna come back.
author: Lauren D.

description:
Green onion pancake is quite similar to "roti prata" but still good

However, the oyster pancake served with tomato sauce (not so sure of the authenticity as normally it's the dry type without the sauce) wasn't too good for the taste buds. All I could taste was the tomato sauce and not the fragrant aroma of the egg and oysters. I was quite disappointed.

Overall, it's pretty good for its price. We ordered 7 dishes for about $50.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Good Taiwanese food is hard to come by North of San Gabriel Valley, so this place will suffice. 

- The braised beef noodle soup hits the spot on a cold day (which is every day out in the Richmond)

- Onion pancake is fantastic

- Their Taiwanese bowl dumpling is spot on,  like what i bought from some street vendor around the corner from grandma's...
author: Joe C.

description:
this is my fav comfort food go-to place!  they're lucky i don't live next door.  haven't ordered delivery yet but it just feels better dining there...it'd be too long a wait for delivery anyway!  service is quick and good in the resto, so far extremely consistent.

my 2 must-get staples each visit:
fried egg with preserved greens
preserved egg and tofu

i do wish they had brown rice as an option.  nevertheless, this place is so good.  home-cooked feeling.

a tad (wait, hugely) heavy on the garlic.  so i always ask for less or no garlic...i hope they're used to me by now and i like to imagine that the kitchen rings with "ooooh, the less garlic lady is baaaaaaack!"  seriously, it's so pungent that i just want to eat ice chips for the next 24 hours.
author: s t.

description: Love the taste. I love the intestine oyster vermicelli soup. I've only tried it there though... other dishes are good, but they might use too much MSG. Every time I go there, ended up drinking so much water! A bit pricey though....
author: Pach P.

description: Solid food from the motherland. Definitely a great place to go get your fix of oyster pancakes, oil sticks (aka chinese donuts) and soy milk, beef noodle, etc.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Let's talk about the food.  Its tasty here.  The chi fan -chinese dough nut with preserved vegetables and a dried pork product wrapped with rice,  is what I like about this place.  I'm not sure of any other joints that serve this product, except for the late and great "Star Lunch" which shut down.  There are also a handful of dishes that stand out. The apps and most of their dumplings are tasty, especially the scallion pancakes.  The pancakes were nice and chewy, with that eggy fried dough crisp on the outside.  

Most of the noodle dishes were good, up to par with the very best of other noodle shops, but on the oily side.  Most of the stuff was good at best, and there wasn't anything exceptional.

Service lacks here, and prices you pay will dent your wallet.  This is overly priced Chinese food.  With the price you pay, you'd expect better service and bigger portions of food.  It's sad that you pay 7 bucks for 4 small chicken wings.  The accompanying dip is good, but hey, its just 4 dinky wings.  On top of that, the chicken isn't like organic or steroid free.  So what justifies the high price dishes? The service isn't high-end or professional, and the seating experience isn't armed tablecloth.   You can get the same quality tasting food in just about 3 other handfuls Chinese restaurants in the city. The Potsticker in Chinatown is one to name.

I know, Taiwanese, and Pekingese dishes are different.  But really, its all identical dishes but finished differently with each Chef's style and touch.  I know the $80 dollar dinner -spent here between two people, could've done more good at another Chinese restaurant with better experiences.  If you plan to pay, I don't mind coming here, otherwise, money is well spent somewhere else.
author: Phat Hippo L.

description: You know... this place is not bad. Sour cabbage soup with fish? Mmm good on rainy day. The tofu - meat dishes are nice too. This is the kind of place you may easily fall into conversation with your neighbor about what cool thing they're eating.
author: U S.

description: My friend always like coming here, I was a fan of Taiwanese food until here. Not trying to say it was bad but it just wasn't what I liked. Second time being here and still didn't like it. I prefer Taiwan Restaurant on like 7th Ave or so and Clement. Their food is better.
author: John M.

description:
Very good and authentic Taiwanese food in a cozy (read: tight) space. 

Good thing about SF is that there's no shortage of authentic ethnic foods. Case in point, Taste of Formosa. 

Definitely recommend the pickled cucmbers. Doesn't sound the most exciting but it's highly recommended especially if you're also ordering a lot of fried foods. The cucumber was sweet and crisp, without being overly tart or spicey. Green onion pancake is also very excellent. Theirs is more tender and slightly flakey and fluffy in a good way. This is a variation right between the standard more doughy and the other more dry and flakey varieties. Also don't forget the chive pockets. 

If you're temtpted to order crispy fried chicken, don't. There are plenty of other authentic and interesting foods to try. The chicken isn't bad, but it's not great either. Tapioca Express' (Fillmore) is better.

Service - what an I say? It's a Chinese restaurant. You want authenticity? Well, the waiters are as Fobby as it gets. At least they're somewhat nice though, but a bit more English fluency would help.
 
This was my first and only visit but I'm sure to be back next time I'm in town.
author: J. K.

description: I definitely heart the pig intestine/oyster vermicelli here. It is soo tasty and the intestines were cooked really well. I love mine with a big serving of black vinegar. Drunken chicken, scallion pancake and the braised beef noodles were all really good too. I am definitely stoked that this gem exists just round the corner from where I live. Service can be a lil slow as they seem short handed all the time. I saw on the wall that they offer the stinky tofu too; when I brace myself enough, maybe I will order that next time!
author: Topazskye L.

description:
read some positive reviews about this place and i had wanted to find a replacement for the Taiwan Restaurant, which has gone down in quality, so i went here to see what it was all about.  the short of it... it's all about  tapas... small dishes... but at entree dish prices.  everything we got was small in portion (not enough for a single person let alone for sharing)..  bowls of noodles half full, small sizes of other things like the chive pocket (about half the size you could get anywhere else).  they didn't have bowls of soymilk, just glasses..  they expected me to dip my you tiao (the donut) into the glass of soymilk.... ah, sorry, not how it should be.   
i really hoped this place would be my replacement for Taiwan restaurant, but I guess I'm gonna have to look further.  this just didn't make it.
author: dee c.

description:
I go there once a month.  I like the Taiwanese noodles.
Nice decor.
Price is reasonable
Staff is mediocre.  They tend to rush our table to leave when it's crowded.
author: Dan G.

description:
This restaurant was good in general, but there were a few problems. It would be nice to be greeted more warmly and served with a smile and given a better table when the restaurant was empty. 

I enjoyed most of the dishes, especially the sauteed pork liver ($7.95) and the fried rice noodle (also $7.95).  But the chef must have spilled the salt shaker into some of the sauces because I was craving for water.
author: D'Andy C.

description:
Pretty good beef noodle soup.  I wont say the best, because I still think Queens House in Mountain View is the best.  Tea Garden in financial district is pretty damn good too, I need to try both again to decide which I liked better.

Green onion pancake was very very good.  Didn't try anything else.  

Very clean modern looking place.
author: Doug C.

description:
Update 10-29-07

I went here again last night.  I didn't realize on the first visit that there was more seating upstairs ... so that's a plus.  Had the vegetable dumpling appetizer again.  It was good.  Was a little disappointed in the mango beef though.  The texture was weird.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I can't remember the names of what I ordered but they were really good -- a dumpling type appetizer and then a noodle vegetable dish.  The vegetables were nice and crisp.

Prices were reasonable.  Seating is tight though.  We were like 2 inches from the next table ... who were obviously on a first date -- not comfortable.  

I'll definitely try it again though.
author: C C.

description: I hardly see the restaurant filled up with customers and I had a hard time understanding why because their food is so delicious! I could hardly resist their onion pancakes, taiwanese potstickers, and the bird's nest made of taro and filled with vegetables (I fogot the name of the dish.) The environment is nice and comfortable to hang out for a good chat. Price range is geared towards the expensive side for such a small portioned plate. I would only come to this place when I feel that I have extra cash in my pocket.
author: Pommie S.

description: as a Taiwanese born and raised in Taiwan, food at this place is authentic. I have taken my friends to this place many times and they loved it. Very nice and modern setting on the second floor. It's not like any other dirty rundown Chinese restaurants you see in the city. I recommend Haga stir fried and Taiwan beer...not sure about stinky tofu though..it's not as the same as the ones I had in Taiwan. Overall, great, clean, friendly, and homy. Check it out yourself!!
author: Alex L.

description: I love Taiwanese food and have looked everywhere in the SF, down the peninsula, and even Cupertino for a decent Glutinous Rice Meatball thing similar to the ones I ate in the street markets of Taipei. This place has it plus more. Everytime I get a Taiwanese food craving, I go here! Try their pig ears, noodle soups, and oyster egg fries!!!
author: Laura C.

description: Came here with a few friends and was pleasantly surprised. Expected to eat at a traditional Taiwanese restaurant but the place is quite modern in decor. I'd say the menu is pretty large and the selection is good. May not be TRADITIONAL Taiwanese but would bring my Taiwanese friend's to give it a try. Only negative about this place would be parking, friend circled the block for a good 30 minutes to find a parking spot.
author: Steven C.

description: I just came back from Taiwan and I was apprehensive that I'd be disappointed after such an amazing trip. But this was a great meal with all the classic xiao tze (small eats). The stinky tofu didn't seem frozen but fresh, the fried intestines were beautifully crispy on the outside and melt-in-your-mouth dairy on the inside, and the meat dumpling (ro yeng) was nicely steamed with a nice filling. Also, while they don't have deep fried sparerib soup, their sparerib and turnip soup was about quite good in a light broth. Definitely a great place to transport you back to Taiwan at least momentarily!
author: M e.

description: The place is pretty nicely remodeled.  If you have the chance, eat on the second floor which is much more roomier.  It can accomodate larger parties.  The food is not bad.  The oyster pancake was pretty good and so was the 3 cups chicken.  The intestine noodles was lacking a little and the soup didn't seem thick enough.  we ordered something else...like a beef dish which was very tasty also.  parking is probably the only killer here during dinner, but we went kinda late so we parked right outside.  The place beats going to cupertino to get taiwanese food.
author: LittleBird 8.

description:
If this is authentic Taiwanese food then I know why I haven't been exposed to it (despite one of my closest friends being a native Taiwanese): It just did not appeal to my palate.
