Everything that came out - all 20 of them - tasted so herbal - they tasted as if the chef accidentally dropped a container of powder made of mystery roots / leaf / stem / seahorse / parts from endangered species.  

Very much like the little clear chicken soup infused with god-knows-what that my grandma used to force-fed me, growing up. 

Therefore, I don't think I would come back.  However, for the cleanliness of the place, the promptness of the service, and the nice waitresses that had to endure the yelling by a b!tch / prima donna-wannabe of a dining companion of mine (DISCLAIMER: she is NOT my friend, the dinner at Taste of Formosa was my first-ever encounter with her, and I pray to God and his seraphims that I will not ever have to suffer through dinner with her again in this lifetime), I think the rating is more than just. 

Besides, all the dishes that came out were ordered by the abovementioned individual, and as such I could hardly blame the restaurant for the food.  Maybe it was her that had a bad taste.  And incredibly poor judgment of ordering 20 dishes for a party of 10, AND had the nerve to yell at the waitress for not telling her that she messed up by ordering too much.
author: Ange L.

description: Everything you've heard about the green onion pancake is true. Especially that bit about how it'll blow you on the first date.  Totally confirmed, but you DID NOT hear it from me, okay?
author: Maria D.

description:
This is more like Taste of Formosa as transliterated by Taiwanese food aficionados from a Hong Kong culinary background. Not necessarily a bad or good thing, the basic flavors are there albeit with a tinge more sweetness and fat that I expect from HK guilty pleasure food. Sometimes this works for the better--example, the onion pancakes were phenom, coming out instead not really as pancakes but more like... zhua bing or "pulled bread" with salt, sugar and onions mixed in, very flaky like phyllo on the outside but still with much gluten past the crust, such that it was still a very chewy, almost mochi texture. 
Sometimes it did not, like the cold plate cucumbers we ordered for a starter. Way, way, way too sweet, we hardly touched this dish.
Love that they have stinky tofu, especially the fried kind; not too stinky, it's pretty good but a tad dry, and lacked the creaminess I usually associate with fried stinky tofu. Still, if hankering for a little bit of that smelly-first-date-dispelling tofu, Taste of Formosa has a decent example.
All together, for lunch for two our bill came out to $34 and included two cold plates (cucumber and pickled pig ears; pig ears I would def get again!), two starters (the green onion pancake and stinky tofu), and one entree (the beef noodle soup, actually really good, but totally different from my connotation with traditional Taiwanese beef noodle soup... I detected satay, and some other more savory flavors, yumm).
All in all, would come again, especially to try their hot pot, but at $34 for two it is a little bit pricey for my expectations. I guess they make it up with very fancy (in comparison to most local Taiwanese eateries) presentation, but still. As such, there's room to explore and definite negatives to check off, so Taste of Formosa is currently a humble "A-OK" 3.
author: Jessica L.

description: A taste of authentic Taiwanese food in my back yard.  I travelled to Taiwan for the first time last New Year's and I fell in love with the cuisine.  The aromas and freshness of the food mixed with the excitement of the night markets was a truly unforgettable experience.  I've been longing for grilled cuttlefish and stinky tofu ever since my trip.  I'm so glad I discovered this place.  I came here for a bday dinner last week and my party ordered numerous small plates to share.  The braised meats were tender and delicious and seasoned just the way I remember it.  The stinky tofu was dynamite.  The salt and pepper whole prawns were humongous and amazingly tasty.  Overall, the dishes were not as fabulous as what I had in Taiwan (how could they be, honestly) but nonetheless I truly enjoyed every single dish!  Truly a great night!
author: P.J. D.

description:
Very authentic Taiwanese food and relatively cheap.

The ground pork over rice is really good.

Parking is this area sucks though but not the restaurant's fault.
author: Dave C.

description:
This restaurant isn't as good as McDonald's.

Not authentic.  Lazy, inattentive effort at simulating Taiwanese food.

Wait staff wore black t-shirts on which you can still see (and smell) the stains and grime.  These were not fresh stains, but the kind that accumulate when you wear a shirt 5 days straight w/o laundering.  I wanted to puke.

The flatware, seats, and table had grease stains as well.
author: W. W.

description: As everyone has said, the scallion pancakes are really really really really good here.  They are flaky, crispy and comprised of layers and layers of buttery/oily goodness.  I've never had scallion pancakes this good.  But that is the only thing I can praise about from here.  Everything else is mediocre.  Their noodle soups are not very good either, especially because they overcook them and the noodles arrive in a soggy mess.  I usually like to order from their long list of Taiwanese appetizers but so far, nothing screams deliciousness like their scallion pancakes.
author: Diane L.

description:
Excellent, excellent, excellent Taiwanese food in a nice, relaxing atmosphere.

I'm a Taiwanese food expert and vouch for this place.  Their menu is ample and I have yet to find a bad dish.  On my most recent trip (Feb 18, 2009) I tried as many of the hot and cold dishes as I could cram into my and my friend's bellies .. absolutely fabulous and a trip back to the old country.

I would highly recommend the following:

- Scallion pancakes
- Hakka style sliced pork belly
- Taiwanese fried noodles
- Twice cooked pork
- Deep fried yellow fish
- homemade sausages with garlic and ginger

.. but the truth is I don't think you can go wrong anywhere on the menu.  Be sure and wash it all down with some nice green tea or a Taiwan pi-jou.

Looking for some great food, even for the un-initiated?  You need to try this place.. you won't regret it.
author: Dante B.

description:
so, for those of you who care, I'm american born and raised.  grew up in phoenix actually, in scottsdale - one of the whitest 'burbs in america (probably second to salt lake).  so why do i consider taiwan home?  

i moved to taiwan when i was 12 - a great time to move your kids, for those of you future parents - girls starting to become interesting, hormones are playing hell with your voice and skin, and self-confidence never lower.  good times.  and i hated taiwan.  i hated the humidity, the pollution, the crowdedness, the people, the smell, the bad pop music, everything.  

but as time went on, my brain started to develop, and i slowly realized that this is where i'm from.  all those stories my parents told me as a kid, the songs they sang to me, the mandarin lessons that they forced me to take, and the values that they instilled in me - this is where all of that came from.  so i found a lot more of taiwan in me than i'd originally known.

so now, years later, i say i live in san francisco, but my home is in taiwan.  home is where the heart is, they say.  or in my case, the stomach.

sitting down to the spread at taste of formosa is hard for me to describe.  luckily for me, someone already made a movie of it.  if you've seen pixar's ratatouille, me taking a bite of the green onion pancakes was like anton ego taking a bite of the ratatouille and being transported back to his childhood.

i can't wait to go home again.
author: brian w.

description:
have the sesame chicken soup...it comes with a ton of ginger (like an entire root chopped up), bits of chicken and a faceslap of flavor. 

Even better? Our server told us that apparently, the soup is very good, "for women"....we didn't ask, but GOOD for me! And the soup was delicious.
author: Alexis W.

description: food is just OK but service is really really bad here. First time it was a spoiled dish which they refuse to take it back(or to give any apologies), second time it was the waitress accuse me for not turning off the water after i left bathroom.
author: Ying X.

description: This is probably the best Taiwanese food that I've had in NorCal. The white-peppered pork chops were most delicious. I could go back here every week!
author: Chaz C.

description: The Food was pretty good, soy milk a little too sweet, the waitress was rude to us at the beginning. We wanted to sit upstairs and I guess she didn't feel like going upstairs. She became nicer to us towards then end. I'll probably give it another try, just because it's Taiwanese =)
author: Tiff W.

description:
formosa tastes wonderful.
(maybe i don't know any better because i'm not taiwanese.)
author: Cynthia P.

description:
came here the other day and tried the egg with pickled turnips and the kimchi tofu, as these were part of their limited vegetarian menu. both were  really tasty but the egg dish was outstanding. it was like a fluffy omelet with little chewy bits of salty turnip. mmmm, so delicious!! 

the kimchi tofu tasted pretty korean, but came with a weird, sweet mayo sauce slathered all over the top that looked like jizz. however, the sweet and creaminess of that jizz cut the heat of the kimchi and made for a nice salty sweet combo.

would definitely go back, but only if i happened to be in that area. and how often am i ever in the outer richmond? well, i guess i won't be going back.
author: eve l.

description: great spicy wontons, green onion pancake, beef soup noodles, and lots more!
author: Lisa B.

description:
reading past reviews, i was SO excited to come and try this place. being taiwanese, i always crave beef noodle stew, scallion pancakes, and all the good stuff. 

what a disappointment! 

i must say, the only thing that was good was the roasted salted peanuts and the fried pork chop over rice was average. the beef noodle stew had too much of an star anise (or wahtever it is they put in it) taste. it didnt have that meaty, hearty taste. the scallion pancake had too much flour and was so greasy.  half of the oyster pancake was nothing but overcooked egg and the other half was undercooked oyster nd flour. 

i say, leave the taiwanese food to taiwan street markets and taiwanese mothers.
author: Katherine C.

description: this place isn't bad. dishes tend to be on the saltier side. but the 2nd floor is quite spacious and relaxing, good for catching up with old friends.  :)
author: Ethan L.

description:
ever since taiwan point out in the sunset packed up its bags in the middle of the night and disappeared from our lives, my friends and i have been lamenting the loss of authentic taiwanese food, perfect for late nights. 

however, we've now found taste of formosa, out on clement & 25th, to fill that abyss in our hearts. 

this place is much larger, with a cool upstairs dining room that features a flat screen tv looping chinese music videos. dining here, it kinda does feel like you're in a different place...specifically, in taiwan, at odd hours in the early morning with your friends.

the braised ground pork over rice is a star. for $3.75, you get a bowl of rice topped with the stuff, mixed with some chopped up little pickled greens. order some braised hardboiled eggs to go with it, and you're all set.

the green onion pancake--a classic--is just right. crispy and crunchy edges embrace soft and chewy tendrils of dough. 

they also have green chive "box"! one of my favorite dishes ever, it's basically a pan fried contraption, like an empanada, but filled with tiny glass noodles, eggs, garlic, green chives, etc. so tasty.

price range is fairly good. they have other oldie but goodies, like liang mian (cold noodles), zhong zi (triangular bundles of sticky rice wrapped in leaves), soy milk, fried pork chop over rice, etc. 

oh, when you're seated, they bring over a little dish of red skinned roasted and salted peanuts. very chinese.

definitely worth a try. sadly, i went on a friday and saturday night (consecutively) and it wasn't a packed house. it is a fairly large place, but i wish it could attract the same crowds that its neighbor india oven does (which isn't nearly as charming as this place).
author: jennifer y.

description:
two years ago, when i still lived in san francisco, i lamented that there was no good taiwanese food in the city. spices... eh, ok. but i wanted real taiwanese food -- the oyster noodles, the sound of taiwanese speak emanating from the kitchen, people who could understand my formosan utterances. 

no such luck. i had to drive down to cupertino to get my taiwanese food.

then today, driving by, bf (who is tuned into my crazy rabid taiwanese-food cravings) said, oh look! there's a taiwanese place. i scoffed. many a place calls themselves taiwanese. and many a place has failed to prove itself rightfully so. but i gave it a whirl.

ohhhhhh!!! the joy!

this place kicks major *ss. every mouthful was followed by an "oh i am so happy" or "ahhh. this is how taiwanese food should be." bf just kept throwing food on my plate, probably to make me shut up and keep eating. i left euphoric and happy (drunk from the drunken chicken, perhaps), and so ready to go back.

yes, the service is not but-kissingly stellar, admittedly. but the place is clean... and they're authentic. so that makes 5 stars in my book.

formosans (and lovers of formosan food) unite!
author: monkey l.

description:
Very good Taiwanese restaurants with all the classics.  Flavors are clean and bright and fresh.  Or maybe I am biased from the '100" rating for the SF County health department hung on the wall.

Like cooking from home 'inlaws' where they use less oil and less pungent flavors.  Everyone seemed to order the giant scallion pancake, though I would order it for a 3+ party.
author: Michael N.

description: My fiance and I have been looking for braised beef noodle soup in San Francisco proper.  And we finally found an excellent version at Taste of Formosa!!  It's a long drive for us from Potrero Hill, but since finding it a month ago, we've already eaten there three times.  We also tried the famous green onion pancake and it did not disappoint.  I cannot speak for the other items on the menu.  It's always just "two braised beef noodle soups" for us.  Loves it.
author: Poker B.

description: I really didn't want to come back here but my friends wanted to come here for dinner.  I noticed they jacked up the price.  so expensive for small ass portion and drinks.   Don't waste your $$$ here.
author: food lover t.

description:
oh.. green onion pancake!!! so crispy, so doughy.. SO heavenly! 

I walked in and the restaurant looked completely empty. but unknown to me, all the other patrons in the know headed upstairs to be seated. Nevertheless, the food was fantastic and the service was very attentive. 

spicy beef tenderloin - just spicy enough, so yum!
mustard green fried rice cake - one of my favs!
potstickers - solid
sauteed eggplant - solid

can't wait to go back and try more dishes!
author: tessie n.

description: Here's the thing. My stepparents are Taiwanese, my stepparents are very picky about food, my stepparents were taken to A Taste of Formosa to exercise their wise judgment. The results: overall satisfied, and this is a big thing with them, if they ar satisfied the place has to be good. They have some very Taiwanese specialties, very hard to find in other places (a sort of big sausage filled with rice and tripes, dont' remember the name). So definitely go and eat, it is worth doing so in this place
author: Alex A.

description:
After a month of complaining about my Taiwanese food craving to anyone who would listen to me, I finally came here on a few recommendations. 

I expected more people here for a Sunday lunch on Clement, but we were the only customers, which was fine by me. The restaurant is clean, cute and contemporary, and could easily have been transplanted straight from Taipei. 

We ordered the braised beef noodle soup, sticky rice cake with pork, and Hakka style sliced pork belly. Everything was well-seasoned and flavored but not overpoweringly so--just the way I love my food. It's not the best Taiwanese I've had but it's still authentic and hits the spot. There's a wide variety of snacks and dishes on the menu that I'm already itching to go back and try. 

Only downside for me is that I live on the complete opposite side of SF in South Beach, so I'm out of their delivery range. :(
author: S L.

description:
I have been using yelp for a while now but have never written a review, so this is my first. I am Taiwanese and was raised in sf. I have lived in at my whole life. Our family would always go down south (Cupertino, etc.) to get our Taiwanese food. I have always looked for places in the city, but they are few and far between. 
My lady found this place on yelp so we had to come and try this place out. The interior is nice and clean with not much to complain about. The bathrooms have a motion sensor which is nice. Now when I come to a Taiwanese restaurant I expect the wait staff to at least be able to speak and understand mandarin, but not this place. They tied but
they messed up our order. When we asked for specific things they would try to speak to us in cantonese. The  food is so so at best and that is all that really needs to be said about that. I will not return.
author: Skoozi m.

description: I wanted to try Taiwanese food since I've never had it before.  Nice atmosphere except they were playing like terrible 90's music.  I tried the shrimp dumpling with onion.  Very tasty and juicy.  Came with a type of vinegar sauce which kept it light.  Because of everyone's suggestion, I tried the scallion pancake.  It was SOOO heavy and sat in my stomach like a rock.  I asked her if it was oily and she said pan fried but I should have stayed away. Maybe I shouldn't listen to Yelp reviews :)  I like that it's open late though which is a plus.  I would go back to try some other dishes.
author: Mitch A.

description:
The green onion pancakes were a testament to fried deliciousness.  It's not what you generally expect when ordering scallion pancakes...a Taste of Formosa's version is reminscent of roti, puffy with fat, chewy threads of dough.   I could eat this every day, at least until the cholesterol killed me.

I also tried the oyster crepe.  Ummm.....yeah....

Flavorwise, it wasn't bad, but I like my food to be less viscous.  I was later told that it's an acquired taste but unfortunately, I haven't acquired the taste for something that makes me think "if an alien came to this planet and sneezed on a plate, I think it would look something like this."    

Go for the scallion pancakes.
author: Lisa W.

description:
1 star for the place being really trendy and clean.
Another star for the red bean shaved ice but before it melted and tasted like sugar water.  The $4 braised pork over rice was really good, but it came in a fist-sized portion.  We accidentally ordered sesame paste noodles, which I had trouble swallowing.  The spicy chicken wings were "different" since the spiciness came from this spicy thousand island look-a-like sauce.   

I'm not Taiwanese, I don't know what's consider authentic. Maybe i'm just not ordering the right things from there.   But i know for a fact, definitely NO SESAME PASTE NOODLES.  Overall, the place is pretty expensive for minimal portions, but the restaurant made a good attempt at the food.  I will give this place a second chance.
author: Emily L.

description:
all my taiwanese people, for some reason or another, live in the south bay.  when i need a fix i have no problem coming to Taste of Formosa.  to be honest, it's not all THAT authentic, but it still tastes great and uses the ingredients i expect when i think taiwanese.

the oyster pancake is good just because you don't find that many places in the bay, and the green onion pancake, while very different, is still delicious.

i must disclaim that i am american-born taiwanese and not all THAT authentic either, but this ABT really likes this place.
author: Steven C.

description: THis place is one of my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. One, because im taiwanese i love taiwanese food ! but its not as good as the one in taiwan of course.. but this is pretty close ! They got everything i expected. So i ordered everything that i liked and it did not disappoint me at all ! The place is Clean and its a perfect atmosphere to eat in. LOVE IT !
author: Andrew H.

description:
i'm taiwanese, i came here when it first opened (first month or so) food was really slow when serviing. i knew the waitor. the food if compared to taiwan it's like okay. the only reason we gave this place a try is because TAIWAN POINT on irving closed. otherwise i don't think this place is that good. food is slow, takes forever to eat. the msot recent time i ate, seems like the chef changed. didn't have the original taste when it first opened...

________________________________________
Edit: April 21, 2007

was strongly cravin for some taiwanese food because i busy watching taiwanese film. got a takeout menu delivered to my door and i kepted it on my desk. i decided to order. food came in 45 mins. good time, but  could be better. 

the food had helluva sauce spill. horrible sauce spill because of their takeout boxes. ok. i forgive the guy, since it was a rainy day. 

i don't want the rain and the food sauce spillage to ruin my dinner. 
i cleaned up the mess. got my act together. took my first bite. AWESOME. FOOD WAS GREAT. DAMN GOOD. 

i love formosa. 

past review was 3 stars. bumping 1 extra STAR or good delivery.
author: Eric Y.

description: I've eaten delivery from here several times and I must say I really enjoyed it.  They're open late too!
author: Theron L.

description: Around 10:00 PM, what to eat in Richmond ? I ordered the Braised beef noodle soup-- DELICIOUS . Spicy, hot & yummy~ We also ordered the sauteed beef tendon . It was pretty good, very flavorful . The decor was very comforting and simple, yet unique . I would definitely come back here for the braised beef noodle soup . After the dinner, we ordered the assorted beans & rice balls sweet soup . It was so good & good for you ;D
author: Jenny Y.

description:
3.5 stars for this place... 

the first time i was here, i would have given them a 4 star... i deducted 0.5 star because after a while, i just don't find it very exciting to come anymore. 

my favorite is the pork blood and pork intestine cooked on a small pot, chicken wings, and their fried small fish.  I would try other dishes but I am kinda stuck on these dishes cuz I really like it.  Service is not the best so dont' expect much here.
author: Kapo T.

description: Pretty good, but not amazing.  A&J in Cupertino is better, but far away if you're in the city.  The braised beef noodle soup is all right - mine tasted a little strong of anise.  The scallion pancake was so-so - it was almost sweet, which is strange, and I think it might have been a little undercooked.  Ambiance is very nice and the service is super friendly.  A decent option for Taiwanese food in the city - we will probably visit again.
author: Michelle C.

description: I really like the food here!  The scallion pancakes are definitely the standout, but I also like the beef noodle soup.  It's not quite like the way they make it in Taiwan (somehow there is a lot of BBQ flavor in it and it's not as spicy), but it's still tasty.  Very attentive staff and nice setting.  It's not so great that I have to go every week but it's good enough to look forward to.
author: I-Chant C.

description:
two of my co-workers raved about this place. and i never doubt them.

this place serves pretty good taiwanese food. it definitely hit the spot.

yeah, it's pretty good. not the bomb, tho.
author: Rosalee C.

description: I thought the food here are okay not really authentic Taiwanese food but it will do the trick. The restaurant is owned by Cantonese, I believe.  Not the bomb but not bad either. The oyster pancake there is a bit different than I wanted but it is still pretty good as a quick fix to my ever endless craving (and love) for oyster pancake!
author: NK M.

description: dude, I've been searching for a place like this for so long. This is the taste I've been looking for. They serve fine Taiwanese cuisine here, and they even have Gold Medal Taiwan Beer. If you have a craving for any type of Taiwanese or Chinese food in SF, this is it.
author: Eric C.

description:
Food is just ok.
Very expensive since portion is small. 
 Service is good
author: root r.

description: I'm a Chinese ABC, born and raised in San Francisco.  I'm married to a Taiwanese girl, and when she gets Hangry, this is where I take her.  The Richmond district is the end of the universe, and parking is near impossible, but this place is the best cure for Taiwanese girl Hangriness.  I'm not sure about the stinky tofu.  I'm not Taiwanese but I'm told this food is the best Taiwanese food outside of Taiwan.  The dishes are small, and it's like Asian tapas.  I've grown to love it here, and you have to order lots of dishes.  If you are not Taiwanese, try the famous scallion pancakes, beef noodle soup, braised ground pork over rice, and Taiwanese fried rice noodles.  Also, their Taiwanese style mini dumplings are very cute and super delicious.  Top it off with a cool watermelon drink.  Definitely go upstairs to their larger second floor.  The Asian waitresses are cute and attentive.  There is a large flat screen TV that will bring you up to date to the latest in Asian Pop video.  It's fun to come in large groups and talk and linger.  It's socially acceptable to talk on your cell phone here.  The place is also kid-proof.  I noticed other Asian guys bringing their cute Hangry Taiwanese girlfriends, who are noticeably calmer after a bowl of spicy Taiwanese noodle soup, tea eggs, and stinky tofu.  Go figure!
author: Terrence G.

description: I dined here for the first time this past Monday, and I have to agree with the other reviews that the scallion pancakes were really delicious - flaky, crispy, and lots of flavor.  The other dishes, however, are less memorable.  But given the limited options on Taiwanese in San Francisco, this place will do for my occasional cravings for hometown cuisine.
author: Aileen C.

description: everything about the green onion pancakes are true!!!!  They are delicious!!! I love all the noodles they serve!  Everything is so flavorful!  And the decor is quite nice.  Taste of Formosa has the feel of a more modern eatery but with some pretty decent prices.  I'd go back.  Best place to satisfy the green onion pancake cravings.  I'm rating this a 3 because i have not tried enough dishes to warrant a 5.  I'd go back though.
author: Nicole J.

description: GREAT eats! And, they even validate for parking =) The first floor is small, but they have a huge 2nd floor dining room! Nice and comfy atmosphere. Great for couples or families/big groups. Friendly staff members.
author: Michelle C.

description:
My first experience with Taiwanese food.  I really liked it.  It seemed to be somewhere between Chinese and Japanese food.

We tried the Taiwanese bowl?, shrimp omelette, chicken salad, fried salt and pepper chicken and both kinds of pork rice.  Everything was very good.

Prices were not bad considering the amount of food we had.  Also liked the Taiwan beer.

The restaurant was clean and had a nice environment and the servers were polite and friendly.

I went last night and had to go again tonight.  Really liked it.
author: M R.

description: I was curious about this place so I went in and gave it a try! What a pleasant surprise! The atmosphere was great and the workers were so friendly. I will definitely come back! The food wasn't too greasy either
author: Nancy L.

description:
The first time I saw this place was during an Indian food run nextdoor at Indian Clay Pot. Since I already committed to Indian food, I couldn't change my mind. But if I had the chance to go back, I'd definitely go to Taste of Formosa instead. I came back two days later with my gf. We ordered the oyster vermicelli noodles and the braised beef noodle soup. I thought the oyster vermicelli noodle was done very well, very authentic whereas I've had better braised beef noodle soups at other Taiwanese restuarants in the South Bay. Don't get me wrong, the beef was tender but the broth was a bit too sweet and oily for my liking. The oyster noodle soup was the star of the meal (which was why my gf ate 3/4 of it and left me with the braised beef soup).
The decor was modern and chic but definitely doesn't reflect the streets of Taiwan- which is a good thing. We definitely will be going back in the near future...(this coming Friday).
author: Brian H.

description: So far, of what we've tried, I'd give this a 3.  The beef noodle soup had a taste of tsa cha in it I think, which kind of makes it seem like they cut corners on the true taste of the beef broth to me.  The beef was just okay, and the noodles were a bit thicker than I usually like for beef noodle soup.  But the ambiance is really nice, and it almost feels out of place to eat Taiwanese food in a cute place like that.  Most of the good places I went to in Houston weren't so nicely decorated and cute.  But the green onion pie was delicious! It had a more buttery/pastry taste than I'm used to, but I love the layers and texture of the way it turned out.  I'd definitely go back for it.  The oyster pancake was probably the best I've had in a while, and it's been a couple of years since I've gone back to Taiwan so I can't quite pin point the taste of it there.  But the oysters were a lot smaller than ones used in places in Houston, which is truer to Taiwanese style, and the sauce was more similar as well. I'd like to go back and try more dishes too.
author: Jen T.

description: Ate here last night. The boyfriend and I opted to sit downstairs. There was a man eating solo at one table and someone from the kitchen making wontons at another table, I figured I could watch and learn. Tea was plentiful, food came out steadily, we were pretty satisfied. Food wasn't the best we've ever tasted but definitely was hitting the taiwanese craving I had... then it went downhill from there. I saw who I believe to be the owner sit down at the table with the wonton maker and start chit chatting. She then stuck her finger into her shoe to scratch an itch at the bottom of her foot, she dug around for a few more seconds and that was that. The thought that IMMEDIATELY pops into my head is I hope she doesn't start making wontons.... AND SHE DOES!!! Right then, right there my appetite is lost. Everything that has just been consumed starts to rumble in my stomach and I feel sick. That is just beyond not okay. I get that restaurant staff don't do these things intentionally or maliciously but really though! I will not be coming back here to eat, I suggest people that still insist on eating here, stay away from the wontons!
author: G Y.

description:
so DISAPPOINTED!!! especially the stinky Tofu and Green Onion Pancake...

waited for a long time to order and service poorly...

not recommended!!!
author: Monica W.

description: Finally found a restaurant in San Francisco that serves authentic Taiwanese food.  Can't wait to go back.
author: DAVID C.

description: The menu doesn't really match the decor here. This restaurant is decorated kind of modern, but the menu is just ok. The menu is overwhelming, too many things and not described very well either. We had the pig ears and I thought they were cut a little too thick for my taste. not much flavor to it either. My bf ordered several types of dumplings, but they all tasted the same. We actually wanted shainghai dumplings and asked if they had any on the menu, the waitress pointed to something she thought was similar, but they were not even close. I thought the waitress could of mentioned that the dumplings we ordered were similar and that we should order something else. Potstickers were nothing to brag about. I thought that most of the little dishes that we ordered were rather greasy, not sure if that is how Taiwanese food is. The service is slow, the waitress is too soft spoken, I could barely hear her and she just wasn't up on it. Took her time bringing the dishes and it wasn't even busy. Not sure if I would come here again.... if I do maybe I need to bring a someone that knows how to order Taiwanese food.
author: carebear l.

description: had the ma yo (sesame oil) chicken soup with noodles. it was DA BOMB. consistently great tofu with preserved egg. also had cold platter appetizer (seaweed, tofu, etc) it was excellent. love the cucumbers.
author: Win H.

description: Being Taiwanese, this place doesn't really compare to my mom's home cooking at all. The staff doesn't speak Taiwanese or know the Taiwanese names to the dishes. They only speak Mandarin which makes me feel like the place isn't authentic. They put too much care into the presentation of the food (which is not a very taiwanese thing to do) and not enough into the actual dishes. The noodles were bland, the service was terrible, and my favorite Taiwanese dish - the staple of groud pork over rice was just okay. Would not come back.
author: foodbot c.

description: great for taiwanese style dim sum! i love the fact that its clean! ok ordering from a vegetarian angle, the fried dumplings, scallion panckage, braised tofu, sweet soy milk with the fried donuts was absolutely delicious. I know most dim sum is with meat, however i knocked off a star because I wish they had vegetarian congee or vegetarian turnip cake! (sweet potato or 3 mushroom) service was friendly and fast!
author: sue c.

description: Taste of Formosa is definitely out of the way from downtown San Francisco and I'm still not sure if it was worth going.  If it wasn't for being dragged along by two eager friends, I probably would've opted for something in Chinatown.  But I'm giving it 5 stars anyway because of the quality of the food.  All the dishes we had especially the oyster omelet were amazing and comparable to the cuisine in Taipei.  Although it was barely populated, I didn't get that weird "We're the only customers here" feeling.  I recommend getting the oyster omelet.
author: R C.

description: Not bad.  My wife is a Taiwanese, and she thinks this place is pretty authentic.  My favorite dish here is the pig intestine stuffed with sticky rice.  Yum!
author: JASON L.

description: the food here is pretty good. there are a lot of flavors, and being taiwanese cuisine, the food really doesnt taste the same as other asian eateries. the first time i went i was blown away! after going several times now.. i realize its not the best restaurant for a vegetarian. i pretty much order the same thing every time now because they are lacking in that department. also, the food is pretty damn expensive. i mean, no one should ever pay close to $9 for noodle soup in an asian restaurant. thats insanity!! also, even though i order the same thing every time i go, the dish itself varies a lot. sometimes my eggplant has WAY WAY too much sauce. you'd think it was sitting in soup. other times, there is noticeably less sauce. its weird.
author: Raye T.

description: One of the few Taiwanese restaurants in the city, and also the best! My roommate and I (both Taiwanese) come here sooooo often because it is so close and tasty. Have Taiwanese family/friends visiting SF? TAKE THEM HERE! They have all the classic dishes; 3 cup chicken, beef noodle soup, green onion pancake, and much more (which I can't remember because I'm an ABC). Prices are pretty cheap too. They have a huge clean nicely decorated dining area upstairs. You can't go wrong with this place!
author: M. W.

description: the flavors are unauthentic.  who uses satay sauce in their braised beef noodle soup?  i've never tried their breakfast foods, maybe that would be tastier.  i'm going to keep looking for a good taiwanese place, let me know if you find one.
author: Big e.

description: I'm so down with this place.  The service is great, and the feel is fun.  Definitely get the scalion pancakes, and the popcorn chicken.  We even had my cousin's rehearsal dinner there and everyone loved it!
author: Mark K.

description: it was ok, but we went there at the right time -- sat lunch, when i was having a severe hangover... and the oily dishes cured me right away!
author: Evan P.
